that!!

My Goodness man.. I Loved his SEt!!!  He totally played all these Anthems & 
fuuuuuckin' A man.. I Loved his tracks!!!

me... but I wasn't able 2 C her set 'cause I found a ride 2 Hercules & he 
left early!!!

OK... it was Dope 'cause the whole night... I saw aaaalll these people I 
ain't seen in a looooooong time!!!  It was neat!!  Finally got 2 hang out w/ 
CoCo after soooo long!!!  Finally Saw Scooter, that lil' Skank! =)  OH 
Gosh.... so many people!!  It was kickin' it w/ Nick again! =)  Oh Gosh

Subject: REVIEW: Estuary (Monday Open Deck Weekly)

More of you really should have come out! For a Monday night, it was
pretty rockin'. A lot of people were there and all the time slots were
taken by 9!

The venue is AWESOME. FREE POOL tables (when you buy drinks/food), huge
dance floors, a really sweet enclosed outdoor patio, hella nice
employees, STRONG drinks, and plenty of tables and chairs! And I swear
I saw 3 decks up there, but maybe I'm just sleep dep'd.

Music-wise we heard everything from floofy house & trance, to old
classics (Groove is in the heart...), to mmm-DARK jungle & DnB, to
techno! Plus, the music changed quickly enough that I just didn't get
bored at all. I didn't get to stay and see Amber spin, but everyone
else that I heard was great (well, there was that one guy... *cringe*).

All you people that spin, but haven't had a chance to "play out" or
find a gig anywhere, COME TO ESTUARY! All of you that don't spin, come
and hang out... fun people, great drinks, funky music... DELISH!!

Special headliners every week at 1am. Open decks from 9-1, in half hour
slots. C'mon... you know you wanna go...

THANK YOU HAPPY/DEVIL!!
*hugs*
Jessica

Event Space for Rent

Original URL: http://www.craigslist.org/wan/13059961.html
Posted by: anon-13059961@craigslist.org
Posted on: Tue Jul 1st 09:48 AM

Rental Space for All EventsNeed a space for your next party? You can host one thousand of your closest friends with room to spare. From Sunday Church service, wedding receptions, high school dance parties, or political fundraisers, I have over 10,000 square feet of space that is broken out into 4-5 rooms for large or small events. 

The gymnasium is fully functional and can be used for late night basketball or volleyball tournaments, social functions, dance parties or church meetings.

Venue rental is based upon activity and size of group. Hours of availability may vary but are primarily evenings, nights, and weekends.

Cheese Steak. Brotherly Love. Amir from the Roots. System Recordings
presents the Philly Connection - Josh Wink Profound Sounds v2 hits the
stores and Dieselboy launches www.djdieselboy.com!!!

JOSH WINK
---------
Josh Wink's hotly-anticipated Profound Sounds v2 is released Tuesday, July
1.  The techno legend returns with yet another mixed masterpiece. Profound
Sounds v2, Josh's first CD in four years, takes you through over 70+
minutes of floor filling, mind expanding tracks, bridging the gap between
house and techno. This double CD includes interview footage of Wink live
and in the studio explaining how he made the ground-breaking mix CD on
Final Scratch, as well as Wink classics never available before on CD,
including "How's Your Evening So Far", "Evil Acid", and "Superfreak
(Freak)".

Catch Josh Wink live this Summer:

07.11.03        San Francisco, CA       Ruby Skye
07.12.03        Los Angeles, CA         Circus
07.14.03        New Orleans, LA         House of Blues
07.16.03        Orlando, FL             Icon
07.17.03        Ann Arbor, MI           Necto
07.18.03        New York, NY            Centro-Fly
07.19.03        Washington, DC          Five
08.01.03        Boston, MA              Avalon
08.02.03        Minneapolis, MN         Quest
08.08.03        Miami, FL               Crobar
08.09.03        Milwaukee, WI           Pure
08.21.03        Denver, CO              The Church


DIESELBOY
---------
The hits from Philly just keep coming, as Dieselboy embarks on the
Summer-long Planet of the Drums 2003 tour and launches his brand spanking
new website www.djdieselboy featuring exclusive content.

Including:

* Biographical information
* Comprehensive tour schedule
* Photo of the Day Diary
* Mix tapes and back catalog available as FREE MP3 downloads
* Themed desktops from some of Dieselboy's favorite graphic designers
* Links to purchase Dieselboy/HUMAN/Planet of the Drums related merchandise
* Site continually updated

Don't miss Dieselboy + the entire POTD crew rolling through a town near
you:

the correct, professional way to speed up a record or
slow it down is to play with the pitch adjuster on the
turntable...im interesting in learning to dj and just
learning the techniques n shit so i was just wondering
people's opinion on this. 

Delia

mi numero es 510-938-1016

Subject: RE: [sfraves] dj'ing question

only if you are afraid like a little sissy to touch your vinyl.

vinyl is meant to be touched, loved, interacted with. (IMO)

TOUCH your vinyl!

there are those who just do the rapid "up down" adjustments very common in the UK. dnb / jungle
scene.
there are those who hold down the 33 and the 45 buttons (if it's a 33 record) to briefly "nudge" the
record fwd.

but seriously-it's a turntable.  its vinyl!  touch it, your music, while you can
before all we have left is final scratch pro 18.2, cdj 987234, and the Rane mp23987 which
automatically mixes for you.

;)

My $.02!

Geoff

(PS to qualify for "professional" mixing would not involve how you beatmatch your records for me,
but that you do it consistently, on demand, perfectly-then you can at least think of your
beatmatching
(which says nothing about your track selection or other dj presence) as "professional")

;)

Subject: RE: [sfraves] dj'ing question

This is great advice for House. 

But what if she is playing something over 130 BPM?

In the time it takes to correct the record with pitch control, people
are already leaving the dancefloor. 

Why do you think there are so many House dj's? Prob because the beat is
so slow a monkey could mix the records and could prob learn to do it
with the pitch too. 

Try correcting with the pitch while playing some DnB or some 150+ hard
trance or even some hard techno or acid. Good luck, hope you aren't
recording because you will end up scrappin that mix. 

You are going to need to find faster ways to correct the record before
you trigger an elephant stampede. And using the pitch is not considered
a fast way. 


Aj

 "P.S. no offense is meant by this, it is just my
opinion so no flames are necessary thank you."

X-Originating-IP: [64.161.30.243]

References: <20030702081708.66793.qmail@web20804.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Wed, 2 Jul 2003 03:26:51 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1106
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1106
Message-ID: <Law14-OE16vUyNfnrNF00059ce2@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 02 Jul 2003 10:23:50.0171 (UTC) FILETIME=[077896B0:01C34084]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] dj'ing question

Have to agree with Kevin here, the best way to smoothly mix is to ride the
pitch control, no matter what the genre.  I play house the same way I play
trance or jungle or hardcore, by riding the pitch and keeping hands off the
record.  Once you master the pitch control you can have a track matched up
and mixing within eight or so beats, and the adjustments you make can be
much more precise.  The crowd won't hear the adjustments, and the tracks
will stay together longer with less overall adjustment.  Watch any master
mixer play and you will see them riding the pitch.

I think so many DJs play house because it is the most mainstream acceptable
form of dance music right now, especially alla remix bootleg heaven, not
because it's the easiest to mix.  I find jungle and breaks much more
forgiving to mix, you can slip a little and still have it sound relatively
good.  Since house is slower and the beat is straight, it's a lot more
obvious when you slip the smallest bit.  A lot of crowds that listen to
house right now could give a fuck about mixing anyway, but that's another
thread altogether.  Besides, once you can mix one genre really well,
anything else should be cake because it's the same technique no matter what
you're playing.

-Andrew the house mixin' monkey

probe bounces, I will remove your address from the
sfraves@hyperreal.org mailing list, without further notice. You can re-subscribe
by sending an empty message to the following address:
   <sfraves-subscribe@hyperreal.org>

Subject: [sfraves] Final House Invasion w/ Lola Luv on 90.5fm Wed, 6pm-2am

--0-986194000-1057145461=:5762
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

 
If you are in the San Jose area Wednesday nite, then you won't want to miss this. . .
Say Good-bye to the Lola Luv's House Invasion on KSJS 90.5fm in San Jose, Wednesday, 7/2/03 6pm-2am. Don't miss it!  It's the Final House Invasion Ever.  
 
 
<<Hey Ya'll 

If ya haven't heard already, tomorrow is my last radio show and I'm throwing an 8 hour radio bash (6 p.m.-2 a.m.) thanks to the KSJS programming team. If you have time to hang out and stop by the station, that would be awesome! There's gonna be some snacks and drinks as well so tell me if you can come. Hope to see you there!

Thanks,
Lola 

Here's the official info:

You're invited to a very special celebration as KSJS 90.5 FM bids 
farewell to House Invasion after three and a half years of broadcasting 
house and dance music. 

There will be a broadcast for eight continuous hours on July 2, 
Wednesday from 6 p.m. to 2 a.m. to celebrate the final show. 

The show will include several guest appearances from local DJs such as 
Reckless Ryan, Forest Green, Felipe Avelar, and DJ Tronic, that have
appeared in the past and commentaries from past KSJS house music 
personalities. 

The music selected will be the essential dance tracks from the past 
three and a half years as well as current songs. Lola Luv, House 
Invasion's host and producer will team up with Geno Giovanni of Bassline
FM to host the last show.

There will be tons of prizes and goodies too so don't miss this one-time-only event 
before it's gone from the airwaves forever!






God Bless U!  Love, Your sister in Christ, Tami

Do not worry about anything, but in everything by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known to God. From: Tai Nguyen <tonicboy@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <018701c3406e$714392e0$4cccfea9@technoho>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] dj'ing question

Hey all,

I've been a lurker on this board for a week now but I just can't keep quiet when it
comes to mixing!  Personally, I like to use the slider for rough beat matching and
then spin the record or "tweak the nipple" as you guys said, for fine tuning. 
Overall, I prefer to use the slider for mixing for one main reason - it's
reproducible.  At a given BPM, you can set the slider and depending on how quickly
the beats go out of sync, you know if you're fast or slow and by how much.  Now, I
don't claim to have it mastered to the point where I can do that and say "yup, I'm
1.5BPM too fast", but I know it can be done.  The biggest name DJ I've had the
pleasure of watching up close was Derrick Carter.  I was right next to the tables
and the man was amazing.  He mixed strictly with the slider and could have songs
matched as quickly as 4 bars, with an average of 6-8 bars.  I've never spun jungle
so I can't speak for fast BPM music.

- tonicboy

Message-ID: <20030702144442.67266.qmail@web41011.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Wed, 2 Jul 2003 07:44:42 -0700 (PDT)
From: Jessica McMahan <ceridwen_ruad@yahoo.com>
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0

Subject: [sfraves] [Fwd] REVIEW: Estuary

[Fwd'd for Greg since his email is messed up. -Jessica]

>From GregVP:
-------------
NOTE: My review was a reply to an original SFraves message from Jessica
McMahan, including her review. 
************************************************************************
Hell yeah! It was a great time. I danced my ass off after having 2
stiff
long island teas (the drink special). It was also good to see
everybody.
Finally met SE/30 (dave), a cool guy who likes to play pool but doesn't
do
much dancing. He was responsible for the networked Macintosh computers
at
the F&F party (the hardware was still in his trunk!) Most of the guys
that I
meet are always hungry. SE/30 was ready for In and Out burger by the
time we
shut down that place!

Of course Dave Parlier from the old Acme crew (Ascension) was there and
he
gave me the hugest bear hug I have ever experienced. How refreshing to
be
around guys that are not so uptight like the boring guys at work. I
love the
rave scene.

Most of the girls that I meet are sweet, pretty, and not very hungry.
(or at
least food is not the first thing they mention). Becca was sporting a
beautiful Opal necklace from a relative. I got another hug in return
for a
warm compliment.

Amber is refreshingly cute to me. It was great to hear her spin again.
Talk
about a dancer's delight. I had the whole floor to myself.

Mikah was the shutterbug with his digital camera. I said, "I bet we
look
pretty silly", and he said "no way, dude" but I didn't see the shots.
Maybe
I'm too self-conscious about pictures.

I thought that the door dude (bouncer) was a bit strange but maybe
that's
because they aren't used to working on Mondays. When I walked in he ran
after me to check ID. No big deal but thereafter he kept lurking around
and
doing things like reminding you not to take your drink on the dance
flooor.
Don't worry, he "chilled out" as the evening progressed. And the
bartender
(Gil) was really nice and he poured stiff drinks.

At around 12:30 a Pleasanton police officer showed up to chat with the
door
dude (he came inside the club to check things out). I guess they like
to be
safe around the suburban shopping mall. It was funny to me because I
heard
the policeman say, "Loud" (referring to the music) and it reminded me
that
some people are sticks-in-the-mud (not open-minded about new music). He
kept
looking at me so I just smiled politely. Cops make me nervous because I
was
busted once and it sucks. But the good thing about this venue is it is
not
close to a residential neighborhood. Dave even commented that we could
have
ambient music on the outside patio.

It seems to me that for a Monday night many girls showed up compared to
other places. Not much to do in the area, I bet (Dublin/Pleasanton/San
Ramon). I noticed one or two girls kept looking at me, maybe because I
was
dancing so much. I decided to quit being shy, and I talked to a girl
with a
cast. I asked her what happened and then I said, "you are probably
tired of
hearing that one." Turns out that somehow she actually HIT the bar in
this
place. How do you break your arm doing that? Maybe she was in a fight
with
someone. I didn't ask.

It was a lot of fun. I like going out on off-days during the week
because
you have more room to dance. And, it is easier to meet people. You guys
on
sfraves should check it out if you are bored on a Monday night (and
gals,
too).

Finally, I would like to borrow a phrase from Aaron W (technolounge) on
this
list:
Energy cannot be destroyed, only transmitted.

I felt so much positive energy flowing from "Estuary" last night.  This
weekly could become another gathering like Ascension, a place where old
friends unite and new people feel comfortable. Check it out. At least
it's
not in a basement, like Blake's had in Berkeley (Man, that place got
HOT).

In Pleasanton there is a breeze on the outside patio when you get hot.

Greg VP


=====

Website: http://www.livejournal.com/users/heart_0f_g0ld    AIM: CeriRuad

Subject: RE: [sfraves] dj'ing question

--Boundary_(ID_Dt0NhLgxjgV2LNY7aXw2Yw)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7BIT

I've heard some olav basoski (sp?) sets up around 140, Same with Donald Glaude....and ummmmm Bad Boy Bill, I've heard hard house (not that lame UK crap, but real chicago hard house) played up to 160 or so....just cause ya play house doesnt mean you're locked into the 120-135bpm range....

And my opinion in the pitch adjusment is the same as andrew's, it doesnt matter the genre of your tracks when adjusting with the pitch it's just all about skill and mastering the pitch technique.  I admit i'm still struggling, i used to be a table toucher, and i've realised that you can hear it and it does suck.  I'll catch my hand going for the platter and i just remind myself to fix it with the pitch and when i do, it seems to work out a lot better, more control over how much is sped up and slowed down.  You know how sometimes you have records that are slightly warped and when you touch the platter or the record they tend to speed up or slow down more than a normal records, but using the pitch doesnt cause that problem.

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] dj'ing question

I think telling someone how to mix, is like telling them what records to
play. It is none of your business; Everyone has their own style and how to
melt to sounds together. If you can achieve the same affect by spinning
upside down, or in a pressure-tank, is that bad? Isn't Dj'ing about
self-expression as well?

I think it is great to know how to mix using all the tools. Then when it
comes time, you can use the right tool for the job. I wont go into my
personal style, 'cause the world needs another Jack Triumph, like it needs a
whole in the head. Be you.

The only advice I will give is that if you are nervous and playing at a gig,
don't touch the vinyl....you'll be a 100 times more likely to jump the
record. Other than that, it's your kitchen, make something good.
--
DJ Jack Triumph
Minister of Infinite Progressive Onslaught

and carved until I set him free"

Subject: Re: [sfraves] dj'ing question

Personally, I use a lot of pitch slider, a lot of directly manipulating 
the platter, and a little nipple tweaking.

Honestly, is there a right or wrong way???  The end result is what 
matters, and your technique can only be dictated by your own comfort 
and manual dexterity. I remember 2 distinctly different occasions where 
other, much more experienced DJs have watched me and said both, "Don't 
be afraid of the vinyl, man," and "Holy fuck, you touch your wax a lot!"

"All the top DJ's only use the slider" - yeah, and Ford Escort was the 
best-selling small car for decades and 99.9999% of major corporations 
run Windows ;) What's the point? If majority ruled, we wouldn't have... 
oh, I won't touch THAT one!

    - omid

Received: (qmail 4846 invoked from network); 2 Jul 2003 16:50:01 -0000
X-Originating-IP: [206.111.184.2]
X-Originating-Email: [secretsocietythursdays@hotmail.com]
Reply-To: jfowler@assante.com
From: "Secret Society" <secretsocietythursdays@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Wed, 02 Jul 2003 09:49:59 -0700
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <Sea1-F107kO4BfhhLnA0001cbea@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 02 Jul 2003 16:49:59.0754 (UTC) FILETIME=[F99E62A0:01C340B9]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] dj'ing question

hahah.. seems like a funny opinion to me since Terry Francis isn't american, 
and Tech-House seems anything but small.. Tech-house to me, and it may just 
be me, just describes house that's anti-progressive..

When it comes to riding the pitch.. well, I'm a little of both kinda guy.. 
if my record is going off slightly, I can use the pitch to correct it, if 
it's really off, I'll touch the record.. I'm not afraid of it.. the talent 
(to me) lies in being able to touch that record without anyone hearing 
anything..

Personally, mixing to me altogether is of less importance than quality of 
music. I think any monkey can learn to mix records.. (Look at all the 
monkeys mixing these days) it's a learned skill, you're not born with it. An 
ear for quality music might not necessarily be an aquired thing tho. I've 
heard incredible sets from world reknown djs who hardly beatmatched at all, 
but played an array of music that I felt honored to hear. You could tell the 
set was hand picked and well felt and thought out.

What's easier to mix? to me, I like breaks and jungle and find it the 
easiest to mix. I think it's a bit more forgiving when it comes to being off 
and/or quick mixing. I find faster bpms easier to mix than slower bpms in 
general. The faster the track the easier it is to get in and out quickly.. 
That's just for me tho.. I'm sure it's all subjective.

-JH - another house mixin' monkey.







Secret Society -- The South Bay's Greatest Monday Night Bash
The Legendary Club Savoy
3546 Flora Vista Avenue
Santa Clara, CA 95051
408.244.6909
Secret Society continues in loving memory of Chris "Laffy" Taflanidis. We 
miss you brother. ESCT

Mime-Version: 1.0

Subject: Re: [sfraves] dj'ing question

quoth Captain Scarlet:
> Not trying to split hairs or anything.. but I've never heard a house
> tune that was that high in bpm.  Besides, terry francis is a
> tech-house dj.  Tech house is a small genre that helps further
> fracture the American scene.  

Tech-house *is* house. And what do you know about the "fractured" house
scene? American producers and DJ's have long embraced tech-house, and
have helped define the sound. Detroit has become a source of some
ground-breaking sounds as techno artists have applied their
sensibilities to the structure of house. From SF to New York, and in
unlikely places such as Texas to Florida, American producers are
breathing new life into the *global* scene by injecting new ideas, and
fusing disparate genres with house music.

IMHO, tech-house is one of the only things keeping house fresh these
days. It's hardly a "small genre", either -- there's far more of it out
there than you're probably aware of. Actually, I'd argue that it really
isn't a genre at all, but an extension -- even an evolution -- of house
music... it's part of the world-wise realization that house doesn't
necessarily have to employ disco stabs or cheesy female vocals.

And this talk of BPM is rediculous, BTW. There's plenty of house in the
130's, and there's some stuff labeled as house that plays at r&b speeds.
Some Londoners (including Terry Francis) pitch their house way up, just
as some American DJ's are known to play really deep stuff very slowly.
And furthermore, I'm certain that Mr. Francis would take issue with your
statement that he is a "tech-house dj". FYI, he's been known to play a
wide variety of stuff, from traditional house, to breaks, progressive
stuff, and all sorts of techno.

No DJ worth his/her salt should label themselves as a DJ of a particular
genre, or even worse, a sub-genre. Limiting yourself to certain styles
is just silly when there's so much good music out there. And trying to
pigeonhole other DJ's as peddlers of a specific sound is not doing them
justice.

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Subject: Re: [sfraves] dj'ing question

one thing to keep in mind is that some vinyl moves more easily on the
platter then others, so you may need to apply more/less pressure for certain
records you have...

a more solid way to do this, if you dont like using the pitch slider, is to
use the actual platter, not only for slowing down the record, but also for
speeding the record up.

also, i have noticed that, in general, when people touch the vinyl they
normally touch it pretty close to the nipple, which is not as precise as if
you were touching it on the platter (which is much further from the center
of the circle i.e. nipple). for example, your hand will travel more distance
by touching the platter rather than using the vinyl near the nipple (both
are equal in the amount the record moves, but the distance your hand travels
is not the same); this gives you more control and it is also less noticeable
for the untrained ear.

i hope that makes sense...

Subject: Re: [sfraves] dj'ing question


i'm with you on this.

i'm reminded of this kid who played the trumpet really well, but
held it "wrong" and had it at at "wrong" angle at his mouth. 
every music teacher he had tried to correct him, but he couldn't
play as well unless he was doing it "wrong".  he got accepted to
participate in this seminar run by a world famous instructor, who
instantly noticed he was holding it funny.  he said he just played
it better that way, so she asked him to demonstrate and said it
"sounds fine to me and that's all that matters in music".  i think
that no matter what you're doing, you just have to practice a lot
and find a place that's comfortable for you.  you know, try out as
many things as you can until you find what feels right.

just my two cents.

>I think telling someone how to mix, is like telling them what
records to
>play. It is none of your business; Everyone has their own style
and how to
>melt to sounds together. If you can achieve the same affect by
spinning
>upside down, or in a pressure-tank, is that bad? Isn't Dj'ing about
>self-expression as well?
>
>I think it is great to know how to mix using all the tools. Then
when it
>comes time, you can use the right tool for the job. I wont go into my
>personal style, 'cause the world needs another Jack Triumph, like
it needs a
>whole in the head. Be you.
>
>The only advice I will give is that if you are nervous and
playing at a gig,
>don't touch the vinyl....you'll be a 100 times more likely to
jump the
>record. Other than that, it's your kitchen, make something good.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] dj'ing question


On Wednesday, July 2, 2003, at 10:13 AM, Cheese wrote:

> also, i have noticed that, in general, when people touch the vinyl they
> normally touch it pretty close to the nipple, which is not as precise 
> as if
> you were touching it on the platter (which is much further from the 
> center
> of the circle i.e. nipple). for example, your hand will travel more 
> distance
> by touching the platter rather than using the vinyl near the nipple 
> (both
> are equal in the amount the record moves, but the distance your hand 
> travels
> is not the same); this gives you more control and it is also less 
> noticeable
> for the untrained ear.

I like the (pardon the technical term) little bumpity-bumps around the 
platter - they're very tactile, you don't bump the vinyl itself (less 
potential for a skip, harsh speed change), and for slowing stuff down, 
you can control it to various degrees with the slightest amount of 
pressure from a fingertip. 'Course, when doing this, you have to be 
mindful of whether you're at 33 or 45 RPM, how much resistance in 
general the turntable has (I've noticed older 1200's can be a lot 
"looser"), how sweaty your fingers may be, etc.

For these reasons, the pitch slider IS more consistent, and I'm not 
going to disagree with those who say it's a safer means of speed 
adjustment. However, I really really really enjoy the variable, 
touchy-feely aspect of directly touching the moving parts, and a big 
reason I enjoy spinning is my own physical interaction with the music.

  - omid  :)

Personally, I use a lot of pitch slider, a lot of directly manipulating
the platter, and a little nipple tweaking.

Honestly, is there a right or wrong way???  The end result is what
matters, and your technique can only be dictated by your own comfort
and manual dexterity. I remember 2 distinctly different occasions where
other, much more experienced DJs have watched me and said both, "Don't
be afraid of the vinyl, man," and "Holy fuck, you touch your wax a lot!"

"All the top DJ's only use the slider" - yeah, and Ford Escort was the
best-selling small car for decades and 99.9999% of major corporations
run Windows ;) What's the point? If majority ruled, we wouldn't have...
oh, I won't touch THAT one!

    - omid

Subject: RE: [sfraves] dj'ing question

Let me clarify my point about the fractured scene in America (I know
Terry is British btw).  My experience when I lived in germany was that
germans have our a handful of styles they play in the big clubs.
Whereas, here in America, there are waaaayyy too many styles to get a
large crowd together consistently.  Couple that with the fact that the
majority of clubs (that I've been to) only have one dj spinning techno
so it limits the appeal to a broad audience.  I believe 1015 has
multiple dance floors with multiple djs but that isn't as common as it
should be.  I was at a club in berlin that had at least 9 separate dance
rooms AND at least 15,000 people in it.  Yes, 15,000 dancers and ravers.
It was amazing to see.

Most people in the audience wouldn't know you had a train wreck anyway
so I agree with your point that music selection is most important.  You
should be trying to impress the dancers in the club not the djs.

-----Original Message-----
From: Secret Society [mailto:secretsocietythursdays@hotmail.com] 
Sent: Wednesday, July 02, 2003 9:50 AM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: RE: [sfraves] dj'ing question

hahah.. seems like a funny opinion to me since Terry Francis isn't
american, 
and Tech-House seems anything but small.. Tech-house to me, and it may
just 
be me, just describes house that's anti-progressive..

When it comes to riding the pitch.. well, I'm a little of both kinda
guy.. 
if my record is going off slightly, I can use the pitch to correct it,
if 
it's really off, I'll touch the record.. I'm not afraid of it.. the
talent 
(to me) lies in being able to touch that record without anyone hearing 
anything..

Personally, mixing to me altogether is of less importance than quality
of 
music. I think any monkey can learn to mix records.. (Look at all the 
monkeys mixing these days) it's a learned skill, you're not born with
it. An 
ear for quality music might not necessarily be an aquired thing tho.
I've 
heard incredible sets from world reknown djs who hardly beatmatched at
all, 
but played an array of music that I felt honored to hear. You could tell
the 
set was hand picked and well felt and thought out.

What's easier to mix? to me, I like breaks and jungle and find it the 
easiest to mix. I think it's a bit more forgiving when it comes to being
off 
and/or quick mixing. I find faster bpms easier to mix than slower bpms
in 
general. The faster the track the easier it is to get in and out
quickly.. 
That's just for me tho.. I'm sure it's all subjective.

-JH - another house mixin' monkey.

The Legendary Club Savoy
3546 Flora Vista Avenue
Santa Clara, CA 95051
408.244.6909
Secret Society continues in loving memory of Chris "Laffy" Taflanidis.
We 
miss you brother. ESCT

Thanks for clearing that up shawn.  Btw, if terry takes issue with me

the best tech-house dj last year.  For your information, my definition
of house is probably dated since I don't listen to it much, house in
germany is different from the states/uk, and the last time I really
listened to house techno hadn't been invented yet.  And I never said in
know anything about a "fractured house scene".

As for it being a small group, small is a relative term.  By small, I
mean in relation to the more established groups of trance and
progressive trance.  Do a search for one of terry's mixed sets and then
try to find any of his songs on kazaa or whatever file share proggy you
use.  I bet you won't get a single hit.  In fact, I've never even heard
of the names that are on his cd.  So I would have to conclude that it is
a small genre.  Just my opinion.

  

-----Original Message-----
From: shawn allen [mailto:shawn@alterior.net] 
Sent: Wednesday, July 02, 2003 10:09 AM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] dj'ing question

quoth Captain Scarlet:
> Not trying to split hairs or anything.. but I've never heard a house
> tune that was that high in bpm.  Besides, terry francis is a
> tech-house dj.  Tech house is a small genre that helps further
> fracture the American scene.  

Tech-house *is* house. And what do you know about the "fractured" house
scene? American producers and DJ's have long embraced tech-house, and
have helped define the sound. Detroit has become a source of some
ground-breaking sounds as techno artists have applied their
sensibilities to the structure of house. From SF to New York, and in
unlikely places such as Texas to Florida, American producers are
breathing new life into the *global* scene by injecting new ideas, and
fusing disparate genres with house music.

IMHO, tech-house is one of the only things keeping house fresh these
days. It's hardly a "small genre", either -- there's far more of it out
there than you're probably aware of. Actually, I'd argue that it really
isn't a genre at all, but an extension -- even an evolution -- of house
music... it's part of the world-wise realization that house doesn't
necessarily have to employ disco stabs or cheesy female vocals.

And this talk of BPM is rediculous, BTW. There's plenty of house in the
130's, and there's some stuff labeled as house that plays at r&b speeds.
Some Londoners (including Terry Francis) pitch their house way up, just
as some American DJ's are known to play really deep stuff very slowly.
And furthermore, I'm certain that Mr. Francis would take issue with your
statement that he is a "tech-house dj". FYI, he's been known to play a
wide variety of stuff, from traditional house, to breaks, progressive
stuff, and all sorts of techno.

No DJ worth his/her salt should label themselves as a DJ of a particular
genre, or even worse, a sub-genre. Limiting yourself to certain styles
is just silly when there's so much good music out there. And trying to
pigeonhole other DJ's as peddlers of a specific sound is not doing them
justice.

Cheers,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "judas judas" <judas@helpmejebus.com>
To: "SFRaves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; "Jack Triumph"

Sent: Wednesday, July 02, 2003 1:13 PM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] dj'ing question



i'm with you on this.

i'm reminded of this kid who played the trumpet really well, but
held it "wrong" and had it at at "wrong" angle at his mouth.
every music teacher he had tried to correct him, but he couldn't
play as well unless he was doing it "wrong".  he got accepted to
participate in this seminar run by a world famous instructor, who
instantly noticed he was holding it funny.  he said he just played
it better that way, so she asked him to demonstrate and said it
"sounds fine to me and that's all that matters in music".  i think
that no matter what you're doing, you just have to practice a lot
and find a place that's comfortable for you.  you know, try out as
many things as you can until you find what feels right.

just my two cents.

>I think telling someone how to mix, is like telling them what
records to
>play. It is none of your business; Everyone has their own style
and how to
>melt to sounds together. If you can achieve the same affect by
spinning
>upside down, or in a pressure-tank, is that bad? Isn't Dj'ing about
>self-expression as well?
>
>I think it is great to know how to mix using all the tools. Then
when it
>comes time, you can use the right tool for the job. I wont go into my
>personal style, 'cause the world needs another Jack Triumph, like
it needs a
>whole in the head. Be you.

On Wed, 2 Jul 2003, shawn allen wrote:

> quoth Captain Scarlet:
> > Not trying to split hairs or anything.. but I've never heard a house
> > tune that was that high in bpm.  Besides, terry francis is a
> > tech-house dj.  Tech house is a small genre that helps further
> > fracture the American scene.
>
> Tech-house *is* house. And what do you know about the "fractured" house
> scene? American producers and DJ's have long embraced tech-house, and
> have helped define the sound. Detroit has become a source of some
> ground-breaking sounds as techno artists have applied their
> sensibilities to the structure of house. From SF to New York, and in
> unlikely places such as Texas to Florida, American producers are
> breathing new life into the *global* scene by injecting new ideas, and
> fusing disparate genres with house music.
>
> IMHO, tech-house is one of the only things keeping house fresh these
> days. It's hardly a "small genre", either -- there's far more of it out
> there than you're probably aware of. Actually, I'd argue that it really
> isn't a genre at all, but an extension -- even an evolution -- of house
> music... it's part of the world-wise realization that house doesn't
> necessarily have to employ disco stabs or cheesy female vocals.
>
> And this talk of BPM is rediculous, BTW. There's plenty of house in the
> 130's, and there's some stuff labeled as house that plays at r&b speeds.
> Some Londoners (including Terry Francis) pitch their house way up, just
> as some American DJ's are known to play really deep stuff very slowly.
> And furthermore, I'm certain that Mr. Francis would take issue with your
> statement that he is a "tech-house dj". FYI, he's been known to play a
> wide variety of stuff, from traditional house, to breaks, progressive
> stuff, and all sorts of techno.
>
> No DJ worth his/her salt should label themselves as a DJ of a particular
> genre, or even worse, a sub-genre. Limiting yourself to certain styles
> is just silly when there's so much good music out there. And trying to
> pigeonhole other DJ's as peddlers of a specific sound is not doing them
> justice.
>
> Cheers,
> --
> shawn allen
>   mailto://shawn@alterior.net
>   phone://+1.415.577.3961
>   http://alterior.net
>   aim://shawnpallen
>
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
>

On Wed, 2 Jul 2003, Kevin James wrote:
-&e->  Uhm yeah actually it is, and from one of my favorite
-&e->records from last year too, "Android" from Wyatt Earp
-&e->and Little Mike on Hotchokai recordings...........sick
-&e->sick record ;)
-&e->
-&e-> Oh and for the record (no pun intended), I would have
-&e->to agree........... tech-house IS an evolution of
-&e->house music

Well duh...

One one hand there is some dope tech house out there... but like most
genres, a lot of it is crap, and bad tech house drives me nuts.
Especially when it fails both as house (not funky or soulful enough) and
as techno (not passionate or creative enough in the sound design
department).

It's awesome music to link different vibes, but few people spin whole sets
of what I'd consider tech house in a way I find compelling.  My faves in
the genre tend to be DJs like Guthrie and Chad Minddrive... who mix mostly
tech house with slow funky techno and some choice older midwest-flavored
house cuts.

andyw

From sfraves-return-103469-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Jul 02 20:10:17 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-103469-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>

Date: Wed, 2 Jul 2003 13:10:13 -0700 (PDT)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari

cc: Kevin James <djkevinjames@yahoo.com>,

  <geoff@trancenation.org>, 'Delia' <velouria83@yahoo.com>,
  <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <Law14-OE16vUyNfnrNF00059ce2@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0307021236491.17463-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] dj'ing question


Ah yes, my favorite subject to flip out on...  :)

On Wed, 2 Jul 2003, Andrew Phelan wrote:
-&e->Have to agree with Kevin here, the best way to smoothly mix is to ride the
-&e->pitch control, no matter what the genre.  I play house the same way I play
-&e->trance or jungle or hardcore, by riding the pitch and keeping hands off the
-&e->record.  Once you master the pitch control you can have a track matched up
-&e->and mixing within eight or so beats, and the adjustments you make can be
-&e->much more precise.  The crowd won't hear the adjustments, and the tracks
-&e->will stay together longer with less overall adjustment.  Watch any master
-&e->mixer play and you will see them riding the pitch.

HAHAHAHAHA.

Why the fuck is the dance music side of this town a bunch of Jeno
clones?

Can I smooth mix?  Yes!  I can, really.  I can put a record down and get
it in, and then go back and check it again, and by the time I throw it in
for cue, I don't have to touch it anymore.  Sometimes I can even throw in
and not have to touch the record again (esp if I'm playing house or
simpler techno in a close bpm range).

But if I'm playing hip hop, or ghetto tech, or bustin a record every 45
seconds with some frantic techno, it's a very good idea to touch the
vinyl.  Let the music and the situation decide... if the music has gaps in
it, and lacks any sort of whine or tone between the beats, you're actually
going to fix cleaner and faster by bumping the vinyl/platter than by using
the pitch.  Really.  Meanwhile, if the record has long sustaining tones of
mid to high frequency, any contact with the record will be noticeable...
hell even pitch slider changes are noticiable in some cases.  Ideally,
once the volume is up on that record, you shouldn't be fixing at all...

Suffice to say as notebooks and "virtual djing" start showing up as an
acceptable means of mixing for people, smooth mixing as this technical
marvel is going to die.  That can be easily done by a computer with 4/4
beats (Native Instruments Traktor DJ software can beatmatch and phrase
your mixes already if they're even remotely 'DJ friendly' tracks).  The
realm of the vinyl DJ will open up to a more skills oriented situation,
where crazier and more technically difficult shit is rewarded as both
crowds and other djs want to see what the masters have up their sleeve
next.  You can alrteady see this happening in cities that are well steeped
in DJ Culture... in Detroit for example, DJs like Gary Chandler, Godfather
and Assault are revered on account of a combination of superbroad
selection (hip hop, jungle, house, tech, electro, whatever), sick mixing
abilities, and unreal tricks (doubles, scratching, 2/1 or 1/2 bpm jumps,
etc).

If you are a DJ, learn to beatmatch, cause that's the glue that makes all
other things work... but learn to use the stop button, learn to backspin,
learn to just stop a record cold and punch the other one in on beat,learn
to mix into a record that can't be beatmatched into, learn to use a break
from the middle of a record, learn to play with loops and tools, learn to
beat juggle and freeze and stutter and scratch and don't let anybody tell
you it's all about this one little thing cause I KNOW it's not.  Stress
yourself, it's the only way to force growth!

For over ten years now, the bay area has been host to two scenes.  On one
hand, we've had the most innovative turntablists in the world... on the
other we have a cleanmixing culture (well and then there's the thomas
trouble/mars/mystere thing that i fail to understand to this day but I
don't like clowns either).  Why can't they see each other, and meet in the
middle?

-&e->I think so many DJs play house because it is the most mainstream acceptable
-&e->form of dance music right now, especially alla remix bootleg heaven, not

Argh!  If you wanna drop an 80s track, drop the original version.  Most of
those 80s rehacks are fucking trash, and many of the originals have way
superior production and are entirely beatmatchable thanks to click tracks
and drum machines becoming common place in the 80s... hell, at Delve a few
weeks ago I dropped PYT by Michael Jackson right off the Thriller LP smack
on top of an old Chicago house tune and you better believe the place went
*boing*.

-&e->because it's the easiest to mix.  I find jungle and breaks much more
-&e->forgiving to mix, you can slip a little and still have it sound relatively
-&e->good.  Since house is slower and the beat is straight, it's a lot more
-&e->obvious when you slip the smallest bit.  A lot of crowds that listen to
-&e->house right now could give a fuck about mixing anyway, but that's another
-&e->thread altogether.  Besides, once you can mix one genre really well,
-&e->anything else should be cake because it's the same technique no matter what
-&e->you're playing.

See above.  I can see your point within a certain style of club/dance
DJing, but I see a way brighter future in a world where that culture mixes
with turntablism and artistic bravery.

Smash genres, smash conventions, and maybe, just maybe you'll get noticed
for doing something different in this town.  Send dancers home with your
ideas in their heads... transcend what a fistful of producers have put on
vinyl and force a higher agenda.  Understand what a groove is and how to
set it up, but also understand that if that's the only goal of the DJ
before you, the DJ after you, and the DJ everybody heard last week...
you're just a signpost on a dark back road and you're not bringing
anything new to the lives of the people you claim to play for.

The notion of playing this year's popular utility dance music in a dark
corner somewhere is akin to muzak in an elevator... like resigning to the
death of creativity, and I refuse to admit that.  Music is alive, and
DJing is collage.  Take the old words and old images you find and say new
things with them.

andyw


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

one sweating and freaking out in the middle of the dancefloor, twirling 
my nightstick as if it were glowing.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] CYBERFEST Tickets Are now On-Sale! bsp...



You know, I don't have a problem with undercover cops or DEA agents
being at Cyberfest.

its a big, well promoted event.  The DEA says they don't want to shut
down ligitment dance parties, they just want to stop the drugs.  Ravers
say its all about the music and vibe, not the drugs.  So its time BOTH of them
put their money where their mouths are.

its obvious that kids can't handle themselves at these parties... 2 kids
died at the last big Cow Palace event.

So spread the word!  make Cyberfest drug-free.  Kids get their party,
and the DEA sanctions it.  Win-win.

I don't think drugs belong at such a above-ground event like Cyberfest 
anyway.  It only leads to more high-profile ODs that give the anti-party
crusaders more ammunition to shut us down.

-troy

I think what troy said is actually pretty valid. There are pros and cons to everything in life. I think it's important to ensure the integrity of the event and the safety of our patrons.
 
Cyberfest has been around for over a decade and every year we face new challenges, etc. This years promises to be one of the most eclectic diverse line up's we have produced in quit some time.
 
The line up will be released this weekend and i'm sure many of you old and new Cyberfest attendees will appreciate it.
 
Also, we have just released a small limited number of $25 tickets that are now available in all your usual indy stores/outlets here in the bay area. 
 
You can also purchase a limited amount of tickets @ the Cow Palace box office with NO service charge. After this weekend the ticket price will increase slighty...
 
Coolworld
 
 
 
 
  

Troy Sheets <tsheets@atari.saturn5.com> wrote:


You know, I don't have a problem with undercover cops or DEA agents
being at Cyberfest.

its a big, well promoted event. The DEA says they don't want to shut
down ligitment dance parties, they just want to stop the drugs. Ravers
say its all about the music and vibe, not the drugs. So its time BOTH of them
put their money where their mouths are.

its obvious that kids can't handle themselves at these parties... 2 kids
died at the last big Cow Palace event.

So spread the word! make Cyberfest drug-free. Kids get their party,
and the DEA sanctions it. Win-win.

I don't think drugs belong at such a above-ground event like Cyberfest 
anyway. It only leads to more high-profile ODs that give the anti-party
crusaders more ammunition to shut us down.

-troy

References: <001801c34090$d404ab90$b15cea0c@yahshipseki>
 <20030702081708.66793.qmail@web20804.mail.yahoo.com>
 <001801c34090$d404ab90$b15cea0c@yahshipseki>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_2597040==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] dj'ing question

--=====================_2597040==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

At 10:08 AM 7/2/2003 -0700, shawn allen wrote:


>No DJ worth his/her salt should label themselves as a DJ of a particular
>genre, or even worse, a sub-genre. Limiting yourself to certain styles
>is just silly when there's so much good music out there. And trying to
>pigeonhole other DJ's as peddlers of a specific sound is not doing them
>justice.
>

I agree.   In the late eighties and early nineties most DJs mixed wildly 
eclectic sets, and I believe the dancers loved the spontaneous serendipity 
of it all.  I used to throw down house, industrial, punk, and new wave in 
the same set.  Much fun.

Fun.  Yes.  I think what drives many people to DJ, including myself, is the 
need to share music that rocks their souls with other people.  If that is 
the motive, the rest will come.  Above all it is important to have fun 
spinning -- selecting tracks you love; playing with them at home;  and then 
sharing your beats with friends.

As for genres, there were none at the beginning and I think we are entering 
a time when the musical paradigms erected during the last decade are 
breaking down.  Exciting.  There are no "rules."  House, whatever that is 
these days, is evolving with everything else.

Love,

Apollo


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U  
--=====================_2597040==.ALT--

Subject: [sfraves] final word on dj techniques

--0-1423866964-1057193083=:67295
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

The only correct way to beatmatch is to hit the turntable repeatedly until the needle just falls in place. then you can correct it if it slips out by gently licking the record (only lick it the area of the runout groove. don't want spit in the beats, and 9 out of ten records have lsd on the label). any other method is useless. this is the only way!!!!

Subject: [sfraves] ROOM AVAILABLE @ A HOUSE IN OAKLAND ($400 pm+utilities) 

   Seemz like we have a r/m who makes good money but would rather spend
it being a sugar daddy to the young females than pay the rent on time, so
it looks like he has to go. The way it looks now, there will be a room
available by August 1st.
  Here's whatz up. It's 400 a month plus utilities (averages about
$40-70). You would be required to pay first & last month's rent including
a $150 refundable (if you don't trash your room) deposit to move in, were
not gender specific, but you must be financially/maturely stable and able
to pay your bills on time, able to comprehend the word "moderation" in
every thing, able to clean up after your self, is tolerant and able to
get along with others (therez 2 punk rock girls, tekno me and new r/m)
and likes dogs too. We have 3.
  The house is really nice and roomy with a nice size back yard, located
right next to China Town and over the hill from Lake Merit. The
neighborhood on a whole is well kept, little crime, and usually quiet
except for Asian kids setting off fire works during holidays and a
neighbor occasionally doing his own side show trying to impress his
younger cousins. Oakland has a wild energy to it, but no more violent
than SF or SJ. I've walked the streets at night with no problems. If you
understand Oakland's MO, it's a hella great place to live. The hills are
just a 30-45 minute walk away.
  More details... you can e-mail my r/m Chelsea at
safedogsbythebay@hotmail or call her @ (510) 534-7225. (don't call after
12am) or hit me back.
  Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [Fwd] REVIEW: Estuary

    I'd like to thank everyone who came out for the first night of Estuary.
The vibe was everything that I had hoped for, and I was happy to see so many
people having such a great time! There was a good mix of people from the old
Ascension crowd, as well as a bunch of new people. We got to hear a good mix
of music from djs of varying talent and experience, and transitions from
slot to slot were practically flawless. Amber tied the whole night together
with her postive energy and passion for her music. I stood there watching
her mix and saw so many things that I had never thought to do! I think that
people were afraid to get too close and trainspot, but after all, this night
is all about new experiences and learning new things, so don't be afraid to
watch!
    Here is the playlist from June 30th:

Happy    (Jungle)
Gavin Wright    (Prog House/Trance)
Summer K    (Breaks)
Phaedrus    (Jungle)
M!kah    (Jungle)
Devil    (Jungle)
DJ Jacob B    (Hard House)
Jagged Mettal O    (Techno)
Amber    (Sick Sickness of the Sickest Kind)

    I look forward to seeing you next week, July 7th, Special Guest to be
announced.


Happy  :-)
www.happycandykid.com/estuary

Subject: Re: [sfraves] I'm Baaack! Jesus and the DEMF

 If I was a rabid fundamentalist/Pentecostal, I would call it looking for
a scriptural loop hole to have fun (sin), but for Jesus! I remember way
back in the late 80's when we had a "Christian" punk rock club, playing
"Christian" punk rock. Didn't do much witnessing for Jesus, the atheists
and anarchists had the argument, but doing the worm or moshing to "praise
god" was still fun. We listened to CRASS, Circle Jerks, Bad Religion in
private, to supposedly "understand where the world (the unsaved) were
coming from", but the real truth is that we liked them. All a scam,
really.
  I think this is a sad example of religious repressio, not spiritual
expression, and people wanting to still be humans, and do  normal,
natural things called having fun despite all the born again facade and
it's fun squashing legalisms.  Obsession about sin and the devil's snares
and trying to convince yourself that you are better than everybody else
because you have Jesus and they don't sure takes a lot of hard work, and
going to a rave and dancing sure can help you reconnect to the real self
and the real world and give that burdened mind a rest. 
  I mean, going to a rave and taking your bible with you and having a
bible study sounds like to me like someone being prepared just in case,
of all times, the rapture takes place during a rave and not being left
behind, like if Jesus comes and catches me raving, I have an excuse.
"Mom, we're not having sex, we were practicing CPR!" I'm not saying that
this lady is a hypocrite or anything like that, but maybe, like hundreds
of other "born again" kids going to parties, she's trying to "have her
cake and eat it too". I've had too many kids, many fucked up on drugs,
trying to tell me about Jesus at a rave. These often times were the
saddest kids I saw at a party. 
  Jesus must be so sad to see his name become so synonymous with
repression. Good example of the difference between religion and
spirituality.
  Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^

Subject: Re: [sfraves] dj'ing question for the real

the pitch. Get your fingers all over the recs. Also play with the metal plate, 
touch it like you touch a clit; sometimes hard sometimes soft all depends on 
the need. Sometimes the vinyle is thin so you have to touch it light, there is 
no one way to cut the grass or brush your hair. So why should there be one way 
to play records. I say do what you need. Pitch is good for the milisec mix. The 
shit is just a hair off and you need to dail it in. I can play three records 
and when that is the case i will just use the pitch cause those bad boys run 
off sometimes. Like a cat with a fresh bag of nip. TECHNO IS ONLY SO STOP 
FRONTING AND PAY SOME RESPECT TO THREE RECORDS ON THE REGULAR.  

KDB

10:30pm - 6:30am, $10 before 11 PM, $15 thereafter, 21+



MALACHY ON HOUSE

"When used with positive intention, Group energy has the potential to help 
restore the plan of Love on Earth...When you open your heart, and trust the 
whole group you dance with; when you feel love with everyone, and they 
return it, a higher vibration can be reached. This happens when a crowd is 
deep into the vibe of House...In the true sense of rhythmic movement, the 
effect is to align the physical, mental and emotional bodies with the 
Oneness of All that Is...Don't put out negative energy and feelings. Leave 
the old ways behind. Throw yourself into the winds of transformation and 
sow the seeds for a new world -- one where the human family is together 
again. When people respect each and care for each other as a 
community-organism...Spread the Peace!"

Come share another evening of unity through music and dance
with San Francisco's oldest house family.


Love,

Apollo






Moksha Tribe: www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Many persons have a wrong idea of what constitutes true happiness.  It is 
not attained through self-gratification, but through fidelity to a purpose."
-Helen Keller

"I know what the great cure is:  it is to give up, to relinquish, to 
surrender, so that our little hearts may beat in unison with the great 
heart of the world."
-Henry Miller

"Loyalty is the realization that America was born of revolt, flourished in 
dissent, became great through experimentation. Our tradition is one of 
protest and revolt, and it is stultifying to celebrate the rebels of the 
past while we silence the rebels of the present."
-Henry Steele Commager

Subject: [sfraves] (bsp) c o i n c i d e - NEW weekly - starting July 17th in monterey

Hello all,

Just wanted to give all of you an early heads up
on a NEW FREE weekly starting up on

Thursday July 17th - in Monterey- Cannery Row

This event we showcase various styles and genres of
music and art. This weekly will involve various diverse djs,
crews, and abstract artists. So here's the lowdown for this month.

july 17th = residents: matt uchida ( transitions )&
            i:van ( underground audio ) + guest djs
            Opening nite - giving you some funked out house

july 24th = residents: kiyoshi one, kelau, sunshine, per ski
            ( scientists of sound nite )
            + monthly guests artists and djs
            dropping some breaks based sounds on you.
            downtempo, breakbeat, 2step, dancehall, to jungle

july 31st = resident: daniel v ( cloud factory ) techno - house
            + monthly guest djs.

So come out and support our local artists, meet a few new
friends, munch on a couple tacos, & listen to some groovin djs.
At our new weekly event every thursday nite:

C O I N C I D E
Downstairs
C A S A Linda restuarant
638 wave street
cannery row - monterey
93940

18+
admission : free - just bring a positive vibe
time: 8 pm to 12 mid

email us back if you have any questions
peace....

Subject: Re: [sfraves] where is rabbit in the moon playing and when?

On 3 July 2003, Mack Smith wrote:

> Hi all,
> is it true that rabbit in the moon is in the sf area this weekend? when
> and where will it be held and how can i purchase tickets?

Yup, there a but tickets link at http://www.thebraintree.org

What:   BrainTree 'Mythology' Multi Media Art Event
Where:  1015 Folsom
When:   Thursday, July 3, 2003; 9:30pm-5am
Cost:   $15 Advance ticket sales: www.1015.com 21+up w/id

RABBIT IN THE MOON DJ's CONFUCIUS and BUNNY w/ Gavin
Hardkiss aka HAWKE.

San Francisco, CA, July 3, 2003:  The BrainTree
presents Mythology, an evening of chaos and bliss
featuring a rare performance/ DJ set from RABBIT IN
THE MOON DJ^s Confucius and Bunny.  Based in Tampa,
Florida, Rabbit In The Moon is hailed as one of
electronic music^s most innovative acts.  They have
deeply influenced American dance culture, and
developed a huge underground following with their
innovative shows.  They have also re-mixed tracks for
artists such as Garbage, Orbital, the Smashing
Pumpkins, and Sarah McLachlan to name a few. On July
3, for the first time in San Francisco, Confucius and
Bunny will perform with an array of choreographed
artists; including,  OVT visuals based in Chicago,
Mellodia a performance artist from San Diego, and a
group of San Francisco dancers and fire performers.
This rare performance will blow your senses sky high!

Legendary producer and electronic music innovator,
Gavin Hardkiss aka HAWKE(six degrees/sunburn), will
perform a live set of all new music with members of
his rotating band. Gavin says, "I've been working
really hard, and this is some the best music I've ever
produced."

ESP, extra sensory projection, a cutting edge, live
audio/visual trio that contains members of the
innovative Dimension 7 will perform their original
content to kick off the evening.

Also Performing: DJ Lorin (bassnectar.net), Alibi
(house of lotus), DR.LUNG, Laron, and DJ 34.

About the BrainTree:  The BrainTree creates
opportunities for artists and promotes collaboration
between artists of various genres. Every first
Thursday at 1015 Folsom, The BrainTree provides a
multi media environment for creative expression,
showcasing the best local and international visual
artists, musicians, and performers. Creative
Convergence.

>
> peace
>
> Mack Smith

The whole time @ Hemisphere was fun!!  It was Groovy finally kickin' it w/ FABLE!  LoL... I swear man.. he got alotta good energy!

then we went 2 a few other Bars in Berkeley & Wow.. it was the 1st time in a while I did that... LoL

Have a Happy 4th y'all & a Groovy weekend! =)

Subject: [sfraves] RE:  help elect a President who is against the Drug War

   I do like what David says, but the issue is elect ability. I'm afraid
that if he get's the Democratic nomination, he would be successfully
labeled a "left wing radical", exactly what they did to Dukakus and
McGovern, and we would have a guaranteed reelection land slide for Bush,
and that really frightens me the most. With that, the Neo conservative
agenda would really take off and accelerate, and a more obvious Nazi
America (opps! Not allowed to say that word! Oh well... fuck it!)  would
emerge. Right now, the Neo conservative's control of government is in
it's infancy, and a reelection of Bush, especially a land slide one 
would be interpreted by the Neo-Cons as a vote for their agenda for
America, which means the acceration of more wars, more low wage jobs
without rights or benefits, no health care for the masses, poor impotent
schools, the emasculation of the middle class, corporate take over of
farms, water supplies and other utilities, the compete or starve
mentality for disadvantaged Americans, more prisons, the re emerging of
racism, homophobia, sexism and other str8, white male domination
paradigms, and the extended criminalization of dancing and other forms of
fun.
  People are frightened and that fear is being exploited by the Neos to
divert toward the war on terrorism, while the same people who think Bush
is a great president are loosing their jobs (unemployment shot up to
6.4%) and falling in the obis of surfism; waving the flag and getting all
emotional about patriotism while being bent over and raped by these real
radicals!
  Fear will be their strategy for reelection, and what we have is issues.
But when people are kept in a state of fear 24/7, people aren't
interested in issues. That how the reptilian/fight or flight brain
operates, and without the reptilian brain functioning they (the Neos)
can't win. That is why many people on the "left" say that without a
diversion of wars and patriotic fanaticism, people would be forced to
look at the issues and run these real traitors out of town! 
 Again, as much as I like David, like I said earlier, he would be
successfully turned into another fear factor and would loose big time.
Right now, we don't have the luxury of nominating a strong left candidate
or voting for 3rd parties. Bush and his hard right radicals are that
dangerous and that scarry. 
 Right now anyone, even ("me too!") Democrats like Liberman, Gephart or
Kerry are a superior alternative to Bush. I'm not saying that I would
vote for them in a primary, but if either of them would be nominated, I
would hold my nose and vote for them just to get Bush out of office and
save America and the world. The problem with David Kucinich is not his
policies, I'm for most of them, the problem is America is not mature
enough to embrace him and his policies. We're still a infant country
still acting like a child, that hasn't experienced the devastation and
other troubles Europe had experienced that made them grow up and become
30-50 years ahead of us. We think war is cool because we haven't had our
cities bombed and millions killed by a war, and we think fascism is cool
too because we haven't experienced a hard core fascist government yet,
until we got Bush, and his reelection will show his real colors. It took
Hitler 5 years to be Hitler at his "finest". He knew the importance of
slow implication of his policies, and it was done by persistent
propaganda, fear, creating enemies, the destruction of civil rights in
the name of national security and radical German patriotism. Sound
familure?
 My strategy, I think will best serve us for now, is to be willing to
compromise some and support the best candidate who can beat Bush. I don't
know who this person is yet, but who ever he will be, we need to get this
person elected at all costs and then put the "progressive" pressure on
him if it turns out to be someone like Liberman or Gephart. Right now,
Howard Dean looks like someone who could make "progressive" issues more
palatable and beat Bush. But then, in the reptilian state of mind this
country is in, he may not be electable too. True, he is for the war on
drugs, but I think we can turn him around if we engage him on the subject
and make that an issue with him. 
 I just hope the rave scene will wake up and be part of the process,
because we are effected by who will be President in 2004. We can't hide
in our parties and keep the world away. Ashcroft in a 2nd Bush
admistration will certainly be crashing in on our parties and we will
expirence the big party bust of all time.
 I know i'll get flamed again for being "NRR", but what good is there to
get your $4,000 tax cut while the poor suffer for it, and Bush and his
wars makes us feel like men again when at the same time we are loosing
our rights, especialy to dance? To call yourself a raver and a Bushite
still sounds like s&m to me!
 Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^   

                                                                         
~~~*GO "LEFTY" GO!!!!*~~~

Friday, July 4, 2003 ** WISH Presents...Signs From Above *UPDATE* **

WISH Presents.....>>>SIGNS FROM ABOVE<<<.......Friday July 4th, 2003!!
Celebrating SKILLS RECORDINGS 10th Record Release titled "Signs From
Above" by The SPEAKER PIMPS..... Embark on our maiden voyage with your
Galactic Guides for the evening: WARP BROTHERS (Dos or Die, Y2K-Germany),
DYLOOT (Skills & Dancing Spirit Recordings-SF), TOMSLIK (Skills & Dancing
Spirit Recordings-SF), MYSTRE (Dancing Spirit & Frequency 8
Recordings-SF), DENISE (djdenise.com), ENEMY (Skills Recordings-SF),
SASCHA23 (XTORT-Sac) .....This party will be ALL AGES, going from 9pm to
4am. Located in a beautiful, safe, secure, indoor/outdoor permitted venue
in the SF bay area! We will be giving away FREE fruit, candy, water,
mixtapes and CDs throughout the evening.....Tickets go on sale JUNE 1st,
there will be a limited amount of discount $20 tickets available, then $25
thereafter. Check with your fine local record stores for availability:
Skills, Frequency 8, Solid Grooves & In The Mix....Sound by JK, lasers by
UV99.....For more information call 415.487.7444 or email us at:
info@skillsdjworkshop.com .....Stay tuned in!

Friday, July 11, 2003 ** LEFTLANE **

TWELVES AND LEFTLANE PRESENTS...Cherrywine Tour
Cherrywine (Butterfly of Digable Planets)

In the early '90's, Ishmael "Butterfly" Butler was at the forefront of a
new wave of urban music as the founder and leader of Digable Planets.
Along with fellow members Mary Ann "Ladybug" Viera (aka Mecca) and Craig
"Doodlebug" Irving (aka Knowledge), they created music charged with
classic jazz samples, hip hop beats and politically greased lyrics. They
released two definitive albums, their platinum selling debut album
Reachin' (a new refutation of time and space) in 1993 and it's follow-up
Blowout Comb in 1994, before disbanding in 1996. They also won a Grammy in
1993 for best rap performance by a group for their MTV-friendly single
"Rebirth of Slick (Cool Like Dat')."

Plus specila performances by: Larry's Lounge Lizards (Off the Wagon)
Addict Merchants feat. Orginal Headz and Storytellas

Friday, July 11th Elements 805 15th Street $10-$12 21 + up 9pm-2am
LEFTLANE A Unique Urban Experience Bring the soul of the underground to
the stage

http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D611
Sacramento California, USA

Thursday, July 17, 2003 ** Sacred Insitution presented by Enuriye **

Join us this summer as enuriye productions has put together a Sunday
experience that will be featuring weekly guest DJ^=D2s, 4-deck progressive
battle sessions, and ^=D3FireLand^=D4 who will bring ^=D3fire-and-light^=D4=

to bed types can still make this event. Join our family and experience
what an awesome year it has been musically for our DJ^=D2s of this
up-and-coming progressive collective.

Come out, enjoy some drinks from the overly stocked bar @ the Poppi and
catch a night of pulsating progressive anthems that will prepare you for

From sfraves-return-103544-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sat Jul 05 20:03:52 2003

From: Sarah Schumm <sarah_schumm@yahoo.com>
To: max phillips <teknobuddha@juno.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20030702.234210.-148863.3.teknobuddha@juno.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="0-557201384-1057435430=:79478"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] I'm Baaack! Jesus and the DEMF

--0-557201384-1057435430=:79478
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

I try not to be so cynical about it, After all, if you had told me when I was 5 and going to sunday school that I would eventualy find spirituality by dancing all night listening to electronic music, I wouldnt have belived you, because until recently, I didn't understand that spirituality and religion were, at least for me, and I think for a lot of people,  two separate things. I have read interviews with this lady and she seems to have the kind of zeal that only the truely faithful posess, she is also considered by many to be a total nut, and is no longer in charge of the festival. It reminds me of this great Hindu Quote: 
 
The world calls me mad. I am mad. You are mad. The world is mad. Who is not mad? Still these madmen call me mad. Some are mad after name and fame. Some are mad after money. Some are mad after flesh. But blessed is he who is mad after God. Such a madman am I!

-Rang Avadhut

The point is that she started something really cool, and if *God* called upon her to do it, so be it. I don't have to belive it, you don't have to belive it, Detroit doesnt have to belive it, only she had to belive it enough to be compelled to get it done, and fortunately have the good sence to realize when her role was over and step aside. I was thinking about that with the front page article on the cronicle about the crop circles the other day, if it works for you to belive that crop circles are messages from higher bieings from space, and that gives you fulfillment, who am I to argue with your happiness? Even if they were made by pranksters, which they probably were, on a personal level, if it brings people joy, does it really matter who *really* put them there? "I Want to Believe" Like I am really disgusted with how some people (read John Ashcroft or any insert any hypocritical "Christian" you like here) have twisted cristianity, but occasionaly I will meet a Christian of strong
 faith that I realy admire, someone who does things like voulenteer  work and donates blood, and really lives an inspiring life, and I feel like if the Idea of "Jesus" is what helps inspire this person to be the kind of great person they are, does it really matter if "Jesus" is really the "Son of God" or even "real"? When I Had my "major depressive episode", I was riding my bike down the street crying, looking for a place to kill myself, and this Catholic, (at least I think she was catholic) Hispanic woman put her hands on me and prayed for me, Now, I personaly have always thought Catholocisim was the weirdest religion, but I know that this woman who I had never seen before and would never see again taking the time to pray for me helped, wether it was the fact that a total stranger cared, (which it was for me) or her faith that if she called on her God and saints to save me doesn't really matter, the point is that I am still here, and I really think that it made a difference. Strange
 that an old Catholic woman praying for me would lead me to Eastern Philosophy and raving, but eventaly it did. I think everyone needs to find their own path to spirituality, and wether you belive in ghosts, aliens, Yawah, Jesus, Buhdda, Astrology, or Science, doesn't realy matter, as long as you don't abuse it and force it on other people, I agree Jesus must be sad to see what some people have done with his name, but I like to think that at least a few are sincere and doing their best although "Christianity" just isn't the kind of spirituality that works for me. It's like teaching children to paint, some kids need to hold the brush one way, some kids need to hold the brush another way, some kids want to render copies of (groan) Thomas Kincade, others just want to (groan) mix every color on the pallette together, but when you see a kid's face light up with joy because you have helped him figure out the right way for him to hold the brush, and the painting is starting to look the way
 he wants it to look, even if it is still a bad painting by most standards, you know that putting up with "stage parents" and people who want to cure their kid's Adhd with oil painting is worth it because you've shared a little bit of your gift with someone who Really wanted to learn and is NEVER EVER going to forget that now they can do something they couldn't do before. 


max phillips <teknobuddha@juno.com> wrote:
If I was a rabid fundamentalist/Pentecostal, I would call it looking for
a scriptural loop hole to have fun (sin), but for Jesus! I remember way
back in the late 80's when we had a "Christian" punk rock club, playing
"Christian" punk rock. Didn't do much witnessing for Jesus, the atheists
and anarchists had the argument, but doing the worm or moshing to "praise
god" was still fun. We listened to CRASS, Circle Jerks, Bad Religion in
private, to supposedly "understand where the world (the unsaved) were
coming from", but the real truth is that we liked them. All a scam,
really.
I think this is a sad example of religious repressio, not spiritual
expression, and people wanting to still be humans, and do normal,
natural things called having fun despite all the born again facade and
it's fun squashing legalisms. Obsession about sin and the devil's snares
and trying to convince yourself that you are better than everybody else
because you have Jesus and they don't sure takes a lot of hard work, and
going to a rave and dancing sure can help you reconnect to the real self
and the real world and give that burdened mind a rest. 
I mean, going to a rave and taking your bible with you and having a
bible study sounds like to me like someone being prepared just in case,
of all times, the rapture takes place during a rave and not being left
behind, like if Jesus comes and catches me raving, I have an excuse.
"Mom, we're not having sex, we were practicing CPR!" I'm not saying that
this lady is a hypocrite or anything like that, but maybe, like hundreds
of other "born again" kids going to parties, she's trying to "have her
cake and eat it too". I've had too many kids, many fucked up on drugs,
trying to tell me about Jesus at a rave. These often times were the
saddest kids I saw at a party. 
Jesus must be so sad to see his name become so synonymous with
repression. Good example of the difference between religion and
spirituality.
Peace, Bodhi ^ _ ^


--
Sarah Schumm <sarah_schumm@yahoo.com>
