Received: (qmail 34242 invoked from network); 6 Jul 2003 17:58:39 -0000
Message-ID: <20030706175837.24143.qmail@web40707.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Sun, 6 Jul 2003 10:58:37 -0700 (PDT)
From: Susan Gwartney <sooziqueue@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org, straylightproductions@topica.com
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] to the spirit of independence [nrr]

in the last year, i've thought a lot about what it
means to me to be an american.  after september 11,
2001, i watched a hysteria-induced patriotism sweep
the nation as millions plastered decals and
mass-produced american flags onto any kind of surface
area imaginable and i wondered to myself how many of
those people were concerned with anything other than
what their neighbors would think if they didn't.

a year later, those same decals had faded into
oblivion and i would look around to see shredded
pieces of fabric that once were an american flag
fastened to the antennas of cars and since forgotten. 
it made me sad.  a lot of things made me sad at that
time, i think.  president bush made me sad.  the idea
of products being sold on the merit of their
advertising, instead of the intrinsic value of the
product, made me sad.  capitalism made me sad.  up
until recently, i don't think i could have honestly
said that i was proud to be an american.  that made me
sad.

in general, i've never really had a taste for
nationalism, and particularly as a hippie-raver chick,
i've supported unity through diversity and opposed
elitism in most forms.  recently, i've come to
discover a real spirit of independence within myself,
the kind that imbues you with (or perhaps better said,
coincides with) a sense of faith in the future and the
kind of respect that you can only share with other
people.  and for once in my life, i began to identify
with my country.

this last friday, i thought about my dad's
grandfather's great-great-grandfather and how he and
his family must have felt to be alive as their newly
formed country signed a declaration of independence,
celebrating freedom from oppression and tyranny.  i
thought about my mother and her sister in vietnam in
the 1970s during the war, waiting for the opportunity
to come to this place where women have the right to
vote and families have homes to live in with indoor
plumbing.  

i thought about me and my sister and the time and
place in which we live.  i thought about renting a
movie and i thought about getting on the internet
today to post this message and i thought about what
party i was going to next and i thought about where i
wanted to live and how i was going to go about getting
there.  and i realized that i have the power and
freedom to choose.  and i felt lucky to be an
american.  

it was a good feeling.

happy belated fourth, yo.

:)sooz






__________________________________

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 17383 invoked from network); 7 Jul 2003 01:08:13 -0000
X-Originating-IP: [69.3.242.195]
X-Originating-Email: [ipr_rob@hotmail.com]
From: "Robert Chen" <ipr_rob@hotmail.com>
To: rhythmzslave@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Sun, 06 Jul 2003 18:08:09 -0700
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <Law8-F16wOyHuzDkDEt0005f620@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 07 Jul 2003 01:08:10.0268 (UTC) FILETIME=[3B67DDC0:01C34424]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] documentaries?

i would say "better living through circuitry" is one of the better docs so 
far.  i have "american massive," and it's decent.  talks more about the 
industry more, featuring carl cox, keoki, ak1200, dara and other moonshine 
artists.  "scratch" was definitely great, especially if you're into hip 
hop/turntablism. lots of history.  then there's "rave nation" by 
floor9films.  wasn't all that in my opinion, basically footages from raves 
with music in the background.  "groove" was a movie, not a documentary.  but 
it was good. a lot of ppl claim the movie is not an accurate depiction of 
the 'underground scene,' but i just found it entertaining.

couple of recent ones are paul van dyk's "global" dvd.  haven't watched it 
yet, so can't say much about it.  don't even know if it's a documentary.  
and finally, on my to-get list, tiesto's new dvd "another day at the 
office".  talks about his life on tour.  i can't wait to watch this one!


rob

In a message dated 7/6/03 12:53:12 PM, antitux@netscape.net writes:


No, see, here's the thing. When I see something our country does as a
problem, I use my voice to make known my opinion. I tell my congressman
or congresswoman my opinions on matters all the time. I *DON'T*
constantly blab on mailing lists which have nothing to do with politics
about my personal opinions on political matters.
If you have a problem, fix it. Don't bitch and moan about it, just fix it.


     Then what you don't understand is that, to some people, the rave scene 
has everything to do with politics. To some people the rave scene is a 
movement. It is a gathering, in the tribal traditions that our government has 
destroyed. It's purpose is to oppose that power. The rave scene is not some fantasy 
la-la land where people go to forget about politics, and a Rave discussion list 
is not some fantasy la-la land where people only talk about DJ's and Venues. 
There are greater issues at hand, and they obviously have caught your interest 
because you read them. 
     These discussions also catch the intest of SF rave's younger readers who 
are just begining to understand politics. I know because that was once me. It 
was the rave scene that made me start thinking politically, it was the rave 
scene that made me have hope in democracy. Before the rave scene I never 
thought that I could make a difference, but after seening tens of thousands of 
people every weekend who supported a lot of the same ideas as I did, I started to 
think that eventually these ideas would rock the vote, that things would 
change. The only problem to this thereoy is that despite the fact that tens of 
thousands of people rave every weekend, this is by no means mainstream. Lots of 
people talk shit about how raves and electronic music are too mainstream and it's 
bullshit. They are just begining to become mainstream, don't believe me? Go 
out and do a survey ask every single american what kind of music DJ Dan spins, 
I bet you less than 10% answer correctly. Believe it or not most people either 
don't know or have an extream distorted view of what a rave is, and I bet you 
less than 5% of americans actually have attended more than one rave in their 
life. In my high school I'd say I was one of maybe 25 ravers out of over 500 
students at my school in 98 when I graduated. And trust me I took a lot of 
verbal abuse just for being known to go to raves.
      The other 95% of people who have been to one rave or less in their 
lives generally oppose raves. They ban their children from going, they frown upon 
their employees going to raves they don't let their g/f or b/f go to raves 
because they (like the government and the media) thinks raves are "bad". 
Therefore with that kind of public support the government can pass any laws they wish 
against us. 
     The rave scene is still in it's <A HREF="http://dictionary.reference.com/search?r=2&q=infancy">infancy</A>, I know most of you don't want 
to believe that becuase it's giving all these dumb young party kids out there 
more credit and it takes credit away from those of you who started it all. But 
it's true, just like hip hop, the rave scene is not a "Fad" or a "Phase" or a 
"Trend", and just like hip hop was, the rave scene has been labeled all of 
these words. And when you talk about large groups of people who are a part of a 
movement.... It blows my mind how someone can say it's not related to politics. 
It is politics, in it's most raw stage, it's politics in the pure and 
original form that it came from... revolution.
     The reason we write these ideas here on the list and not to our 
government representative is #1- most of us (espectailly the younger ones) don't know 
exactly how to go about doing that or if it will even be read if we do. #2 we 
seek constructive critisism (not mindless insults) from fellow ravers before 
standing on a soap box and preaching these ideas to the government. & #3 
because we know that lots of people read the list and we want to bring up good ideas 
and questions that will hopefully spread around to more people. 
     It's not bitching and moaning, it's intelectual conversation. It talking 
about what matters, getting our ideas out and sharing and listening to other 
peoples ideas. You have to do that first, then you can perfect them into 
something that will appeal the actual government.
     


> 
> 


--part1_4c.1f4bcbc2.2c3a6829_boundary--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) help elect a President who is against the Drug War

quoth CPT Scarlet:
> the only thing the Left has now is the "hate america" agenda that only
> appeals to other lefties and euro-weenies like the french.

I *love* how you refer to the collective sum of people that don't think
like you as the "Left" -- it really makes me feel like I'm part of
something, and that ideas like "liberty" are finally starting to get
under people's skin. Who are you to tell me that I "hate america"? I
certainly don't, but I'll tell you what *do* I hate: people telling me
what I think, or what *to* think. The whole idea that people
dissatisfied with our country right now "hate america" is divisive
propaganda, intended to force Americans into these bizarre camps of
right and wrong, left and right, or liberal and conservative -- and I
won't stand for it. Do your part to help avoid the next Red Scare: stop
spreading the propaganda.

> the left is relegated to a minor supporting role and will only benefit
> from republican mistakes but they won't earn it because they deserve
> it.  it will be like getting table scraps.

This left/right rhetoric is getting really boring. We get it: you're a
political conservative, and you're damned proud of it. Welcome to
sfraves! Now say something of substance, or take your silly labels and
fanatical views elsewhere. And next time, remember to add "NRR" to the
subject line so people can skip over your bullshit. Thanks! :)

PLUR,

Subject: [sfraves] (NRR)Re: [sfraves] (NRR) help elect a President who is against the Drug War

there you go with labels.  after all that emotional
hyperbole about me labeling you.. you call me a
conservative.  my my my.  a quick scan of my voting
record, which you aren't privy to, would show you that
i voted for clinton twice and bush zero.  if you take
offense to what i say, then perhaps i struck a nerve,
which was my intent.  i subscribe to the belief that
if it walks like a duck, quacks like a duck, it's a
duck.  of course i am saavy enough to know that i used
a broad generalization that doesn't fit everyone from
the left.  christopher hitchens and michael totten are
great examples of lefties that believe in the war on
terror.. and have been spit upon by the left.  IMO, if
all i hear out of someone is "i hate our government,
military, economy, progressiveness, or whatever else
is great about america" I come to the conclusion that
you "hate america".  the only thing i hate is whiners.
 whether left or right.

in case you missed the intent of my original email,
which you certainly did, it was to inform any of you
with half a brain about what is wrong with the left in
politics.  if you disagree, i'd be glad to show you
how you are wrong.  the pillars of the democratic
party are falling apart: the fight against racism is
dead, feminism is dead, the environmental movement is
being run by a bunch of kooks that should have stopped
a long time ago, and the fight to help the poor has
turned into the biggest financial fiasco in american
history.  what else do the dems/left have to run on? 
multiculturalism (not likely)?  raising taxes?  being
weak on foreign policy and national security (granted
bush needs a little help here too sometimes)?  there
is no appeal whatsoever to the dems/left that i can
see, even for a person that finds it difficult to vote
republican.

so next time you sign off with PLUR, you might want to
THINK about the content of your email.  otherwise, you
lose any credibility in my eyes and it makes me wonder
if you even know what it means.

It's not electronica or rave but "Freestyle: The Art of Rhyme" is a fantastic

it at film festivals.  Much better than Scratch.

Date: Mon, 07 Jul 2003 08:42:47 -0700
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <Law11-F57fu7P88pyNt0003aae4@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 07 Jul 2003 15:42:48.0157 (UTC) FILETIME=[6AAA40D0:01C3449E]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves]So, I met Osby(Hemisphere Review)

Wassup all, this past Thursday was really cool.  Since it was basically a 
Friday for me, I really wanted to go out dancing.  I didn't really want to 
leave the East Bay though, so I gave a shout out on the board.  Osby 
responded and told me about Hemisphere on Shattuck in Berkeley.  Anyway, I 
guess Hemisphere is the event that is put on at the Jupiter Restaurant.  Me 
and my two friends didnt know what to expect.  So we parked off of Shattuck 
and headed in.  The first thing you see is the neon blue Jupiter sign(I 
think it was blue..lol).  Then there is this enclosed brick hallway, with a 
dude sittin there checkn ID's and what not.  So we continue on walkn and I 
really dont know what to expect, I mean, this looks like a fancy restaurant 
and I didn't see any party kids or nothin.  Well, we get to the patio 
outdoor area and we immediatley hear some sick jungle beats and I already 
pick up on Audio Angel's voice.  This was tight!  I had always wanted to 
hear Audio Angel sing live and WOW...her voice is everything I had hoped it 
would be.  So I see a few people swayin back and forth, but all in all, the 
dance floor is basically non-existant...my friends were prepared to do 
something about that, but first I had to grab a beer.  So I drank my beer as 
fast as possible.  I am not sure who the DJs were, but I was totally feelin 
the beats and just listening to Audio Angel and this other girl sing(dont 
know her name, sorry).

So I look up and I immediatley see Osby!  He was socializing with several 
people and had this BEAUTIFUL girl by him named Doris.  Anyway I went up and 
told Osby who I was and he immediatley gave me a fat ass hug.  I was happy 
to finally hear him talk, because I remember talking to Rayn a couple months 
ago and he said that Osby speaks exactly how he does in his emails.  So 
anyway, Osby, your a cool kat, your everything that you come off as being on 
email(by the way, thank you for introducing me to Doris =)

So anyway, I finally felt a little buzz off my beer and I could tell that as 
soon as you step foot on the floor all eyes will be on you.  This was okay, 
because I feel comfortable with jungle, Im always dancing to it in my room.  
So I went up towards the front and just got down, I started breakn a sweat 
but I was really feelin the music and I just needed a release so I was happy 
to find an outlet.  My buddy got down on the dancefloor with me and at one 
point Osby cheered me on...I wished that his homegirl had been 
dancing(grin).  I downed another beer, and kept dancing until there really 
wasn't anymore room.  It was great seeing everyone dance, and this one guy 
was really gettin down he was doin some really coordinated kicks and spins 
and what not...it was a cool crowd.

Anyway, the shindig was comin to an end at around 11 and Audio Angel and the 
other singer were closin out and what not.  At one point Audio Angel was 
talkn to someone next to me and I took the opportunity to say hello.  Man, 
Audio Angel is HELLA COO!  She aint bigheaded or nothin, she is just an all 
around genuine person.  I hope to see her in the near future, she is 
seriously a big impression.  I just realized now that I hadn't said goodbye 
to Osby and Doris, so..Sorry Osby!  I will see yah soon I know it!!  Tell 
Doris I said hi!

After Hemisphere we headed over to Blake's and proceeded to get down and 
dirty to some horrible mainstream hiphop.  Then I had some breakfast at 
Denny's and realized at that point I should not have been in public because 
I had two beers and three long islands inside of me(eh).

Well, this coming weekend Im kickn it with my homegirl Reverie, Im lookin 
forward to some house maybe...hmmm(what yah think Rev?)

All in all it was a cool Thursday night.

fable....

http://www.angelfire.com/hiphop/fablefour

http://join.msn.com/?page=features/virus

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR)Re: [sfraves] (NRR) help elect a President who
 is against the Drug War


I think you still missed -his- point entirely.

'Left' and 'Right' are artificial labels created by what has developed
itself into a two-party system. Most of us with half a brain don't
identify ourselves as 'lefties' or 'right-wingers'.

It is this left/right, democrat/republican, liberal/conservative
distinction that causes us so much trouble and determines why we have
almost no choice at the ballot every year. It is why voting 'independent'
seems so useless and pointless to people.

We've come to group not just our politicians, but the entirety of our
society, into two camps. Human beings are not so easily categorized. If we
continue to categorize ourselves, however, we will fit more snugly into
the moulds we create for ourselves. And that way leads a lack of
individual initiative.

Why develop your own opinions when they can be determined by whether your
'left' or 'right'?

TRH

On Mon, 7 Jul 2003, CPT Scarlet wrote:

> there you go with labels.  after all that emotional

> if it walks like a duck, quacks like a duck, it's a
> duck.  of course i am saavy enough to know that i used
> a broad generalization that doesn't fit everyone from
> the left.  christopher hitchens and michael totten are
> great examples of lefties that believe in the war on
> terror.. and have been spit upon by the left.  IMO, if
> all i hear out of someone is "i hate our government,
> military, economy, progressiveness, or whatever else
> is great about america" I come to the conclusion that
> you "hate america".  the only thing i hate is whiners.
>  whether left or right.
>
> in case you missed the intent of my original email,
> which you certainly did, it was to inform any of you
> with half a brain about what is wrong with the left in
> politics.  if you disagree, i'd be glad to show you
> how you are wrong.  the pillars of the democratic
> party are falling apart: the fight against racism is
> dead, feminism is dead, the environmental movement is
> being run by a bunch of kooks that should have stopped
> a long time ago, and the fight to help the poor has
> turned into the biggest financial fiasco in american
> history.  what else do the dems/left have to run on?
> multiculturalism (not likely)?  raising taxes?  being
> weak on foreign policy and national security (granted
> bush needs a little help here too sometimes)?  there
> is no appeal whatsoever to the dems/left that i can
> see, even for a person that finds it difficult to vote
> republican.
>
> so next time you sign off with PLUR, you might want to
> THINK about the content of your email.  otherwise, you
> lose any credibility in my eyes and it makes me wonder
> if you even know what it means.

From: miss g <rhythmzslave@yahoo.com>

MIME-Version: 1.0

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr focking monday

--0-130841503-1057598002=:53661
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

party hard?? nooo we only had 3 nights we could have danced until dawn why should we take the opportunity???
 
thursday night i think i read something.... friday (only because it was free) i wanted to see how tall tall paul was and see if he was any good....2,0000 molestations later i left ruby skye with 2 new friends under my belt (sweet bartender and clockworks promotors) and a rather jaded and awful opinion of tall paul
 
had more fun pounding my feet on concrete, gravel, and ballroom floors watching lasers on cargo ships out in the bay at the kelly's bash....lots of uk hard house and nrg, cyber trance, breaks, even early happy hardcore (not a fan but hey, others liked it), a darker Bonham set than i've ever heard...and uberzone's wicked electro percussion and digital 'scratching'  on the cdj.  random set up though...hard house set led into a hiphop set with 50 cent playing...all in all a great night with lots of variety, and fun fun people.  great vibes....woke up at 12:45 this morning with my roommate pounding on my door because she didn't have the key to the damn deadbolt.  that's what you get for going camping for the weekend and coming home late...she should have been home listening to thumpradio.
 
my body is tingly all over and has been for about 24 hours, and i even partied sober...i like that tingly soreness though...it's a bittersweet memory of the previous nights and keeps me going until the next...superqool wednesday and thump saturday....
 
peace all...i feel yeah, but it's worth it isn't it?
 
miss g (lauren)

Delia <velouria83@yahoo.com> wrote:
man mondays after a three day weekend are the worst...

anyone having a hard time getting going at work today?

i partied hard this weekend, it was worth and all but
damn...

anyone with me? COMMON! i need support here...

:(
Delia

Subject: [sfraves] ATP: Review of John '00' Fleming @ Whisper

------=_NextPart_000_0093_01C34474.319CA370
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Well, I don't know what happened but here goes. No one showed. It looked =
like 'beyond thunderdome' at Whisper. There was maybe 25 people there. =
No line to get in, still had to fork out 15 though.=20

This was my first time going to that club. Nice place, a lot of =
potential for big events. Lot of bars, lot of bathrooms. Good combo. =
There was a cat downstairs spinning rap, not my cup o tea, so I....

I went upstairs and DJ Moda was laying down some nice proggy beats. No =
one on the dance floor; Which doesn't bother me, I took that floor and =
made it mine. I danced for about 45 minutes, still no one out there. Saw =
John '00' come in and went over to say hi. Met him and DJ Moda. What a =
nice bunch of guys. They really were, completely approachable. It is =
always nice, when there are dj's you admire and you can actually talk to =
them. Shot the shit for a moment. Then John walked out of the room.=20

Then all the lights went on. They shut down the room. No hard feelings =
for John what-so-ever. I understand why he didn't play, but, that didn't =
make me feel any better.I will just have to catch him next time. I guess =
he was playing Vancouver the next day and wanted to get some r n r.=20

So, not feeling the rap vibe, we left.

Got to my car, and it was completely bashed in. Everything taken. They =
couldn't just break the window, they had to completely rip off all my =
trim and really just make a mess of things. My stereo, me speakers, =
clothes, smokes, and anything that wasn't bolted down. The bastards even =
took my steering wheel cover. The worst is that they snagged my 2 year =
collection of John Digweed Kiss 100 show(s), that I tape religiously =
every Friday. poop. Not that it matters, 'cause I have no stereo, but, =
now I have no cd's.

So all in all, I had a really sh*tty 4th. Not only did I pay 30 bucks to =
*not* see a DJ, but, I got jacked too.
--
DJ Jack Triumph
Minister of Infinite Progressive Onslaught

and carved until I set him free"
- Michelangelo

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) help elect a President who is against the Drug War

quoth CPT Scarlet:
> there you go with labels.  after all that emotional hyperbole about me
> labeling you.. you call me a conservative.  my my my.

Labels are, obviously, what you're comfortable with. I'm trying to speak
in your language, and it's apparently not working. Why is it that you
are so quick to label me, but I can't label you?

> a quick scan of my voting record, which you aren't privy to, would
> show you that i voted for clinton twice and bush zero.

So what? I don't care who you voted for, it doesn't give you the right
to disrespect people. What *do* you believe, then? All I've heard from
you is how much you hate the "left" -- what other conclusion am I to
reach other than that you are, in fact, a political conservative? You've
given me nothing to go on except contempt for other people's beliefs.

> if you take offense to what i say, then perhaps i struck a nerve,
> which was my intent.

Then you're trolling. You're intentionally striking a nerve by making
broad generalizations and blasting people's personal and political
beliefs on a rave-releated mailing list. It's off-topic and disruptive
behavior. If your only intent was to "strike a nerve", then you
shouldn't have posted at all. Again, say something substantive or take
your nonsense elsewhere.

> i subscribe to the belief that if it walks like a duck, quacks like a
> duck, it's a duck.  of course i am saavy enough to know that i used a
> broad generalization that doesn't fit everyone from the left.

If you're so savvy, try avoiding such generalizations next time --
you'll save yourself a lot of grief from people that don't enjoy being
targets of your unprovoked rediculousness.

> IMO, if all i hear out of someone is "i hate our government, military,
> economy, progressiveness, or whatever else is great about america" I
> come to the conclusion that you "hate america".

Then you've got some logic issues. I don't think many people can
honestly say they hate their country, but is it wrong to say that you're
not satisfied with the administration's policies? The government and the
military are *NOT* what is "great about america" -- what's great about
this country are the people and the freedoms that they enjoy. What
worries me is that the people are getting greedy, angry, and scared, and
they're giving up their freedoms because of money and a temporary, false
sense of security. What I hate, again, is that you and I are even
arguing about this. I find it ludicrous that other people can't see what
is going on in this country. You're defending the very people that seek
to destroy everything that *is* "great about america".

> the only thing i hate is whiners.  whether left or right.

Whiners? I don't think you'll find any whiners here, pal. Everyone that
I know on sfraves is very passionate about what they believe. Many of
them (myself included) actively fight for their rights by raving,
participating in rallies and marches, sending emails and faxes to all
levels of government, and making themselves heard in public forums. It's
just stupid to label somebody who voices their opinion on a mailing list
as a "whiner" because you assume they don't do anything else
politically. So stop it.

> in case you missed the intent of my original email, which you
> certainly did, it was to inform any of you with half a brain about
> what is wrong with the left in politics.

Gee, that sounds like whining to me! And no, I didn't miss your intent
-- but I very obviously disagree with it.

> if you disagree, i'd be glad to show you how you are wrong.  the
> pillars of the democratic party are falling apart: the fight against
> racism is dead, feminism is dead, the environmental movement is being
> run by a bunch of kooks that should have stopped a long time ago, and
> the fight to help the poor has turned into the biggest financial
> fiasco in american history.  what else do the dems/left have to run
> on?

You've got some serious problems if you think that the fights against
racism and feminism are dead. Environmentalism certainly isn't dead
because of kooks tying themselves to trees -- the EPA still exists, and
there's quite a bit of work to be done to reverse the harm that Bush's
policies (not signing the Kyoto Treaty, for one) have done so far.

What else to they have to run on? Education. Social welfare, including
assistance for the homeless and destitute, and better public health care
(including health insurance for all Americans). The reinstatement of
civil rights tarnished by the Patriot Act. Better (err, "actual")
foreign policy and diplomacy, instead of military threats and
unconditional demands. Equal rights for all Americans. Restrictions on
the privacy-infringing Office of Homeland Security. Campaign finance
reform, and all the other things that affect politicians' abilities to
act on behalf of their constituency. Drug reform, including harm
reduction and therapy as alternatives to illegalization and prison terms
for soft drug offenders. The shriveling economy, the rising jobless
rate, and corporate accountability. I could go on and on... there are
plenty of issues to "run on" in this day and age, and they're all
substantial, important issues that affect the majority of Americans in
their day-to-day lives. What more do you need?

> there is no appeal whatsoever to the dems/left that i can see, even
> for a person that finds it difficult to vote republican.

Oh well. I think it's sad to think of an American that doesn't consider
any of the issues I've mentioned (among others) as "appealing".

> so next time you sign off with PLUR, you might want to THINK about the
> content of your email.  otherwise, you lose any credibility in my eyes
> and it makes me wonder if you even know what it means. 

Your ignorace astounds me. How can you pretend to know what PLUR is
about if you're preaching the death of civil rights and feminism? What
do I care about my credibility in your eyes when you have no credibility
in mine? You just popped up out of nowhere as "Captain Scarlet",
proclaiming the demise of the "left" and bashing "leftists" as you saw
fit. You hide behind this bizarre fanatical pseudonym, spouting off to a
rave-related mailing list about abstract politics, and you demand
credibilty from *me*? Nice try.

But I guess that's what I get for feeding the trolls. :\

--

Subject: =?X-UNKNOWN?Q?Re=3A_=5Bsfraves=5D_RE=3A=A0_help_elect_a_Pre?=
 =?X-UNKNOWN?Q?_sident_who_is_against_the_Drug_War_=28NRR?=

There you go with 'wing' delineations again.

Rock and roll was political too.

Guess what. All those hippies who dropped out of society? Who ate all that
acid and we make 'dirty hippy' jokes about? They were political, too.
Until they decided that politics were just playing into the man's game,
and the only way to fight back was to opt out.

Nonetheless, all political and social issues aside...
There are certain powers in our government who DO NOT LIKE US.
This is not a personal issue with Howlin' Bob, or Apollo, or Sean, or
anyone else.
Some people think 'ravers' are a bunch of drug-addled buffoons. Others
think we're dangerous criminals. Others thing we're a threat to the moral
fabric of society. Most simply don't care -- aside from cracking down on
'BAD ECSTASY SUPERNINJA RAVE 3000' will make me look like I'm fighting the
drug war and win me some votes.
Some, perhaps, are even existential enough that they despise seeing human
beings behave and feel like human beings.

Their motivations are irrelevant. If a small but vocal portion of these
groups have their ideal (and, hopefully, impossible) way, there would be
no sf-raves. There will be no intimiate underground beneath the streets of
San Francisco, there will be no Cool World, there will be no DJ Howlin'
Bob. The fact that there are people who would love to crush the electronic
music scene (or commercialize it to the point where there is absolutely no
soul left in it) is a very real fact that you need to come to terms with.

This is not a matter of left or right wing politics. It is not a matter of
nationalism or loyalty to a leader.

It's a matter of protecting your right to dance.

--The Rational Hatter

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE:  help elect a Pre sident who is against the Drug War (NRR)

>(Sean)There you go with 'wing' delineations again.

yet another version of the mini-meme i've been seeing more andmore: people 
who are *obviously* arguing from the politicalpersepctive long known as 
"Left," but who demand not to be called "leftist."  undoubtedly this has 
more to do with the desire to avoid the stigma of failed policy that has 
adhered to the Left over the past half-century than with any desire to 
expand the argument..

>The fact that there are people who would love to crush the electronic
>music scene (or commercialize it to the point where there is absolutely no
>soul left in it) is a very real fact that you need to come to terms with.
This is not a matter of left or right wing politics. It is not a matter of
>nationalism or loyalty to a leader. It's a matter of protecting your right 
>to dance.

seriously, do you think that isn't obvious?  perhaps you haven't noticed 
that the RAVE Act was originally proposed by Senators Leahy (Democratic, 
left-liberal) and Biden (Democratic, left-liberal) and finally attached to 
the AMBER Alert bill by the aforementioned Biden?  sounds to me like it's 
the people you'd have me *support* that are the biggest threat to my "right 
to dance."

additionally, the conflation of those who would allegedly "crush the 
electronic music scene" with those interests who wish to "commercialize" it 
is utterly specious.  after all, isn't it the large commercial interests who 
have the most to lose economically if the EDM scene is "crushed"?

you're so afraid of the Ashcroft Boogeyman that you can't even see your 
liberal congressional Democrats selling you out for another shot at the 
power they have so signally abused for most of the last fifty years.

--hb

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE:  help elect a Pre sident who is against the Drug War (NRR)

additionally:

>Guess what. All those hippies who dropped out of society? Who ate all that
>acid and we make 'dirty hippy' jokes about? They were political, too.
>Until they decided that politics were just playing into the man's game,
>and the only way to fight back was to opt out.

this is historically inaccurate.  the "hippie" scene (i hesitate to use the 
term "movement," since there was no leadership nor any generally understood 
principles) was decidedly ANTI-political, and the SDS-type ideoplogues used 
to decry this constantly circa 1970, when i started high school.  by the 
way, i was/am one of those "hippies."

--b.

Not registered as a democrat. :)
I am not part of your 'left'.
I do not support a political party.
I am not asking you to vote for whatever unfortunate candidate the
Democrats come up with. I say 'unfortunate' because it's very unlikely the
nearly-crushed democrats will have a canditate that will be capable of
winning the next election.

I do not cheer or boo people based on their political party.

I make my decisions on character individually, rather than blindly
following a party line.

Your argument fails.

On Mon, 7 Jul 2003, DJ Howlin' Bob wrote:

> >(Sean)There you go with 'wing' delineations again.
>
> yet another version of the mini-meme i've been seeing more andmore: people
> who are *obviously* arguing from the politicalpersepctive long known as
> "Left," but who demand not to be called "leftist."  undoubtedly this has
> more to do with the desire to avoid the stigma of failed policy that has
> adhered to the Left over the past half-century than with any desire to
> expand the argument..
>
> >The fact that there are people who would love to crush the electronic
> >music scene (or commercialize it to the point where there is absolutely no
> >soul left in it) is a very real fact that you need to come to terms with.
> This is not a matter of left or right wing politics. It is not a matter of
> >nationalism or loyalty to a leader. It's a matter of protecting your right
> >to dance.
>
> seriously, do you think that isn't obvious?  perhaps you haven't noticed
> that the RAVE Act was originally proposed by Senators Leahy (Democratic,
> left-liberal) and Biden (Democratic, left-liberal) and finally attached to
> the AMBER Alert bill by the aforementioned Biden?  sounds to me like it's
> the people you'd have me *support* that are the biggest threat to my "right
> to dance."
>
> additionally, the conflation of those who would allegedly "crush the
> electronic music scene" with those interests who wish to "commercialize" it
> is utterly specious.  after all, isn't it the large commercial interests who
> have the most to lose economically if the EDM scene is "crushed"?
>
> you're so afraid of the Ashcroft Boogeyman that you can't even see your
> liberal congressional Democrats selling you out for another shot at the
> power they have so signally abused for most of the last fifty years.
>
> --hb

Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) help elect a President who is against the Drug War

--0-1352197706-1057610215=:16698
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

I really wish people would stop calling environmentalisim a "left" cause. It is not. I learned a long time ago that there are plenty of people of all walks of life who want to save the environment. I used to really hate hunting, for instance, untill I realized that the big woods behind the house where I grew up was saved from rabid developers and a landfill company by (dat da da da!) Hunters! Shure there are some Idiots with guns, but When I realized that the majority of hunters really legitimately cared more about preserving open space than being rabid killing machines and just wanted to have a woods to hang out in like me, I realized we had more in common than I thought. I would rather stay out of the woods for two weeks a year and have it safe from developers than not have the big ass hunting lobby on my side. So get to know your "enemies" it may turn out that you really want the same thing. 


--
Sarah Schumm <sarah_schumm@yahoo.com>

At 01:01 PM 7/7/2003 -0700, Sean Griffith wrote:


>Not registered as a democrat. :)
>I am not part of your 'left'.
>I do not support a political party.
>I am not asking you to vote for whatever unfortunate candidate the
>Democrats come up with. I say 'unfortunate' because it's very unlikely the
>nearly-crushed democrats will have a canditate that will be capable of
>winning the next election.
>
>I do not cheer or boo people based on their political party.
>
>I make my decisions on character individually, rather than blindly
>following a party line.
>
>Your argument fails.

Funny thing.  I really haven't been following this thread carefully, but I 
would think electing a President who is against the WOD would be a good 
thing, especially for those old apolitical hippies:)  BTW, I don't know 
what the "hippie" poster (poseur?) was smokin' back in those days, but most 
of those I knew as hippies saw themselves as counterculturalists who were 
in clear opposition to the values of the established 
culture.  Political?  Who can take seriously the views of  a person who 
thinks the Democrats have run the country for the past fifty years:)?  One 
wonders what some of these folks actually stand for....

What distresses me about some of the political discussion on this list is 
that it consists of name calling and little else.   The worst kind of 
bigotry:  making blanket assumptions about the values and beliefs of 
individuals;  dumping everyone and everything into neat categories so they 
aren't required to challenge themselves intellectually or enter into some 
discussion with specificity.

I have found that when I talk to people I've had heated discussions with 
off line as individuals there is not much separating us.  Useless terms 
like lefty and neocon evaporate when one moves beyond the level of radio 
talk show mentality.

Love,

Apollo

the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

-Pema Chodron

IT’S COMING… 

The festival you have waited all year long for! 

Saturday September 20th, 2003 

CYBERFEST 03 
11th annual Music & Arts Festival 
 
Featuring...
 
KRAFTWERK (Germany)

Initially viewed as a quirky band of German nerds propounding the values of a mechanized state through systematic electronic pop music, Kraftwerk have gone on to influence countless genres and musicians, including the driving techno of Aphex Twin and Juan Atkins, the surreal ambient of the Orb and the rumbling hip-hop of Afrika Bambaataa and Public Enemy. 
Formed by music conservatory students Ralf Hutter and Florian Schnieder in 1970, the pair went on to form permutations with various other artists (who in turn formed Neu! and Doldinger), releasing albums such as Kraftwerk, Kraftwerk 2, and Ralf And Florian. It was with electronic percussionist Wolfgang Flur and violinist Klaus Roeder that the band found their winning formula of mechanized beats and plainly electronic, but weirdly human-sounding melodies. Influenced by the Bauhaus school of German impressionism that existed before World War II, this group recorded Autobahn, which was an international hit with a single of the same name. Hutter, ever the group spokesman, talked of having a band of instruments that could tour without human control, leaving the band to sunbathe or read. Through the remainder of the '70s, Kraftwerk released Radio-Activity, Trans-Europe Express (which Bambaata sampled for his ground breaking "Planet Rock"), The Man Machine (the accompanying tour featured
 robots on stage), Computer World (1981), Electric Cafe (1986), and The Mix (1991).

around right now...i'm still hacking stuff up from weekend before last,
and 
still hear a lot of intermittent coughing around the office i work in.

--b.

>So now today I am still coughing
>shit up out of my lungs and then this morning on the news they are
>talking about cases of whooping cough possibly in my area as I am
>hacking to the point of almost puking. I wish they wouldn't show that
>shit when I am sick it makes me freak out a little bit.

what you call knitpicking, i call facts.  and you
proved my obtuse/filter comment perfectly.  thanks. 
you say i couldn't address your points.. i didn't have
to.  you don't have one.  you didn't even acknowledge
the fact that kyoto is a sham.  you just focued on the
fact that bush didn't sign it.  guess what?  clinton
didn't either.  and no POTUS in his right mind would. 
but you wouldn't understand that issue because you are
uninformed.

CPT Scarlet out,

quoth CPT Scarlet:
> man, you really are obtuse. you have such a myopic
narrow world view
> it is impossible to discuss this issue with you. 
you only see your
> side and you filter out anything i say that doesn't
fit your views.

LOL. You've got me all wrong, buddy. Guess what I said
"struck a 
nerve",
eh? How can you say I'm filtering anything out when
you're the one
glossing over the important parts of my emails, then
nit-picking things
like this:

> for example, what do you know about kyoto?  you know
that we didn't
> sign it.

That's all I should have to know: the Kyoto Treaty set
forth standards
for, among other things, internationally reducing air
pollution. Do
*you* know why Bush refused to sign it? Because
corporate lobbyists won
out over environmentalism and common sense. Not that I
don't care about
the fact that China's not living up to their part of
the bargain (which
I was well aware of, thank you very much), but I'm
much more concerned
that our president would refuse to sign it at all.
We're not talking
about China, we're talking about America. This point
is so
insignificant that I feel silly having to defend it.

My view is myopic? How is the simplistic belief that
nobody be denied
their individual rights to life, liberty, and the
pursuit of happiness
"myopic"? Idealistic, perhaps... But I'm not the one
trying to sort
people into these cookie-cutter molds of "liberal" and
"conservative",
"left" and "right", or Democrat and Republican.
*That's* myopic. You're
so sure that everything I have to say is diametrically
opposed to your
opinions that you're willing to brush everything I say
aside (which
you've done several times) and just insult me
personally. Nice
"perspective".

> there has been almost 30 years of case law to back
up claims of
> discrimination in the workplace and other areas. 
the old generation
> of racists and woman haters are (for the most part)
gone AND those
> classes have equal protection under the law.

News flash: ethnic minorities have had equal
protection under the law
for decades, and descrimination still runs rampant in
this country. But
it's not just about ethnic minorities now, either:
it's also about gay
rights, and the perpetual struggle to maintain a
woman's control over
her own body. Civil rights extend to staying out late
at night, or
whatever it is we like to do for fun. If civil
liberties aren't an 
issue
anymore, why is it still seen as subversive to be a
"card-carrying
member of the ACLU"?

> if you think our government and military are bad, go
live in africa.
> there the government will supress you because you
are not african and
> the military will extort money from you.  see, it's
all about
> perspective.  which you have none.

Why must you insist upon comparing America to other
countries in an
attempt to belittle our problems? Things are *always*
horrible 
somewhere
else, but that doesn't mean we can't complain when
things get 
relatively
worse at home. Even worse yet, a "bad" American
military has the 
ability
to inflict harm upon innocent civilians all over the
world without our
say-so. Are you really comfortable with anyone
controlling the entirety
of America's military might -- let alone somebody that
refers to
millions of protestors worldwide as a "focus group"?

> more on perspective.  has the US ever found it
necessary to restrict
> the liberties of it's citizens?  of course it has. 
do you think W 
and
> co are the only ones in american history to do this?
 you probably 
do.

Erm, no -- that's another rediculous presumption on
your part. People
threw a fit when Lincoln suspended Habeas Corpus
during the Civil War,
with good reason. But we're not at war -- we're
dealing with the same
terrorist threat that existed since the day we got
involved with 
Israel,
and our unilateral actions overseas have only given
religious
fundamentalists another reason to hate us.

In a traditional war, I might be more willing to
accept restrictions of
personal liberties, knowing that as soon as the war
was over, they 
would
be lifted. But the terrorists will never stop, and I
will *not* accept 
a
perpetual PATRIOT Act that allows the government to
track my every 
move,
and threaten my friends with "no-fly" lists. My only
hope for this
presidency is that Bush can push that Road Map through
and give
terrorists one less reason to hate us so much.

> every swinging president during a war has done the
same thing.  every
> decade or so, we get a group in our government that
makes mistakes
> like the Rave act or patriot act BUT the thing that
is great about 
our
> government is that eventually, it rights itself.

So you admit that the PATRIOT Act was a mistake, but
you reconcile its
existence because you think it'll just "right itself"?
Like Hiroshima,
the WWII Japanese imprisonment camps, Bosnia and
Hersegovina, the
botched Operation Iraqi Freedom, and every other
political "mistake" 
the
government's made, right? I don't care what party any
of the 
politicians
belonged to when they made these mistakes, but the
government shouldn't
be allowed to make them at all. When American policy
makers make
mistakes these days, people tend to get hurt or die.

You know, I don't really care too much about being
able to party all
night legally -- I don't even get out that much. But
it's the
*principle* of it. Going out and dancing all night is
a fundamental
right that people all over the world enjoy. Yet
Americans were so
frightened by the media fanaticism over ecstasy that
they allowed night
life to be all but threatened out of existence by
(among other things) 
a
law that passed without a vote in Congress. And while
I don't believe
marijuana's going to be legalized any time soon, I
find it frightening
that the same legislation intended to combat club
drugs has found its
way into the hands of officials who used it to
threaten a NORML event
into cancellation.

People protested in the past when things like this
happened, and
thankfully things were "righted". But we can't depend
on the 
floundering
checks and balances system when government's
controlled by a single
party. I don't care if it's Democrat or Republican,
it's never a good
idea. Ours is a representative government, and people
that share my
wishes and concerns are not being represented fairly
at this point in
time. I'm trying to keep things on-topic here, so this
stuff is going 
to
sound trivial compared to other issues -- but it's not
unimportant. And
if you think it is, then you're going to be pretty
surprised when your
apathy allows this government to trample all over the
rights that 
you're
fond of.

> you and i have the "misfortune" of living in a time
of restricted
> liberty for the sake of national security.  i have
accepted it 
because
> i want to keep my family safe.

Do you really feel safe though? Has the war on Iraq
saved us from a
madman with a massive arsenal of WMD's? No. Rather,
they've put 
hundreds
of thousands of Americans in harms way, and given
Islamic
fundamentalists another reason to hate our country.
Our new school of
pre-emption has alienated us from the rest of the
world, and encouraged
countries like North Korea and Iran to accelerate
their weapons 
programs
so that they might be able to fend us off, or at least
kill a bunch of
Americans on their way out. Now is not a good time to
have a family to
feed, when unemployment's at its highest in nearly a
decade. And by the
time your kids are old enough to need it, there won't
be any Social
Security because we'll have squandered it trying to
protect fossil 
fuels
and on multi-billion dollar weapons to "defend" our
country.

You may accept restricted liberties, but don't you
dare expect the rest
of us to take it lying down. Call me idealistic, but I
wouldn't be in
America if I didn't believe we were capable of
becoming a genuinely 
free
nation. I'm here because I think things can and will
get better for
*everyone*, and I'm doing everything I can to make
sure that happens as
soon as possible. What are *you* doing to help your
fellow Americans?

> you have not because you want to whine about
everything and it is 
more
> important to you that you get to party however you
want.

There you go again, putting words in my mouth...

> almost every issue you brought up proves to me that
the dems only 
hope
> is for republican mistakes.  you are running on the
anti-republican
> platform because you have no other issues.  

Is that a broken record I hear?

> finally, in closing, and this will be my last email
on the subject
> because it is pointless to debate someone so biased
and uninformed on
> issues...

That's a really common position for people that have a
hard time 
getting
their position across: "So, rather than explain
myself, I'll just pick
apart a few of your points, then duck out with
something that sounds
witty so I have the last word." Nice.

> to cap everything off, to show everyone here that
you know little or
> refuse to understand the topics you are debating..
you say that the
> dems are the last hope for your rights in this
country..  where did
> the RAVE act come from?  oh yeah.. a democrat.    

Please, try to find an email in which I said "the dems
are the last 
hope
for your rights in this country". I double-dog dare
you. You're so
blinded by your hatred of the "left" that you're
making up things to
argue against. It's kind of disturbing, actually.

To: slipstream341@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] (NRR) help elect a President who is against the Drug War

"CPT Scarlet" wrote:

> what you call knitpicking, i call facts.
...
> you didn't even acknowledge the fact that kyoto is a sham.  you just 
> focued on the fact that bush didn't sign it.  guess what?  clinton didn't 
> either.

Well, for one who wants to bash others for not knowing their "facts", you sure
seem to be lacking on yours:

http://www.cnn.com/2002/ALLPOLITICS/07/25/column.novak/

Clinton DID, in fact, sign the Kyoto treaty.  Bush has effectively caused the
US to renege on the deal by exploiting cheney's position as president of the
senate to prevent its ratification.  He has done the same thing to the CTBT
(Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty)  And he "unsigned" the ICC (International
Criminal Court), so as to place US soldiers above the law, when they commit war
crimes.

Now, Kyoto WAS flawed.  It actually allowed, for example, Russia to INCREASE
CO2 emissions to 1990 levels (Said emissions had dropped between 1990, and the
time Kyoto was negotioated.).  And it exempted many "developing" countries
(including China and India) altogether!  Obviously those loopholes needed to be
slammed shut, the Kyoto provisions made universal, and with severe trade and
financial penalties for any violation.  Kyoto wasn't perfect..  But it was a
step in the right direction.

And when you come right down to it, those treaties were negotioated in good
faith, and bush should have not have been a spiteful little prat and abrogated
them just because they were signed by a democrat.  What does it say about the
integrity of the United States as a whole if the treaties it signs are so
fleeting as the whim of whoever is president four years later?  Would the US be
so elastic with other countries?  Or would we expect them to hold to agreements
they committed themselved to even when their leadership DID change?  Is Iraq,
for example, now and forever exempt from the non-proliferation treaty, and the
UN provisions barring its possesion of other WMDs, simply because Saddam
Hussain is no longer in charge?  Or will THEY be held to the terms of the
treaties they signed, even though the presidency has passed?  I suspect the
latter, even though bush obviously doesn't seem to feel that *HE* has to live
up to the obligations of treaties signed by previous US presidents.

Seems that, under the bush regime, the era of good faith negotionation is gone,
replaced with: "might makes right".


cya,
john

point for you, however clinton was in office for 8
years before he signed it.  the only reason he did was
to leave a flaming sack of shit on bush's desk.  IMO,
it was politics as usual and the signature wasn't
worth the paper it was written on.  

might makes right is one way of looking at it.  but
put yourself in bush's place... you have an ever
growing nuclear proliferation problem that clinton
helped make worse.  couple that with nKorea selling
long range missiles to anyone that wants them and a
recent terrorist attack that killed 3000 people on
american soil.  would you honestly put americans at
risk because of a treaty that was signed during the
cold war?  i wouldn't.  the same people that didn't
want us to back out of that treaty, were the same ones
that benefited from having nukes to threaten us with. 
russia and china.  china is especially ticked because
now they don't have the ultimate equalizer to help out
their pitiful armed forces.  for those of you that
don't know, a first strike with nukes WAS the
centerpiece of the chinese army's game plan to fight
the US.  

when you are the POTUS, you have to make some tough
decisions. 

and to shawn, i didn't realize that the last email i
responded to was straight to me.  i'm not using my
usual email proggy, outlook, but the crappy yahoo
default program.  i'm currently overseas at an
undisclosed location on vacation trying to blend in
among people that don't necessarily like me.

Subject: [sfraves]NRR: Collecting Money for School?

Hi all,

I need around $8000 dollars to attend an International Business School in 
Holland, I have already been accepted, but the void in cash has forced me to 
postpone my trip 6-12 months.  What I am wondering is, do students ever 
lobby for 'donations' or 'grants' from legit companies, or wealthy people?  
I was thinking I could write up a letter of request to send out to companies 
and people and what not, what have I got to lose?  Someone may want to make 
this opportunity happen for me.

I don't really have good credentials though, thats the only thing.  I am not 
currently attending any college classes, I have a horrible high school grade 
point average...  But I have three years of administrative work experience 
if that is worth anything.  I dunno, maybe people will just take it as a 
joke kid who wants to smoke weed on a free ride for four years(grin).  In 
all seriousness though, I want to pursue this Business Degree.

Thanks for any and all responses.

fable....

http://www.fastweb.com/
 
check out the local library and college libraries, go to the reference department and look through those big books full of private scholarships and grants...
 
i signed up for fastweb once before..you can find a lot of stuff on there, it's not amazing, but it's not bad. i would set up a 'junk' email account for it though because after you fill out your profile with ethnicity info, location info, money info, what kind of dog you own info..you end up getting a lot of notices, so i would set up a separate account...
 
there are lots of scholarships for women studying abroad i remember seeing those when i was registered with fastweb.... also type that shit into google...good luck if i have some spare time i'll see what i can find. 
 
cheers,

MIME-Version: 1.0

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] (nrr)Re: [sfraves] Brian Behlendorf in Salon...

you sound like you've done some good research on the
subject.  i don't have a subscription to salon so i
won't be able to see the rest of your letter.  i agree
that education is the key to helping solve the "third
world" issue.  well, it is the second step.  however,
democracy should be there first and it should be
backed up my a similar moral code like we have in the
west.  

i know that sounds snooty.  who are we to tell what
morals are?  we aren't and i don't want to begin to,
however, how can you explain that america is the
strongest, most powerful, and rich country in the
world when we aren't the biggest and most educated?  

look at india.  they are the largest democracy in the
world.  they have enough people that received formal
education to compete with the US however their
literacy rate isn't that great.  yet out economy is 5
times bigger than theirs.  

people with similar belief systems get along better. 
the west tends to stick together and if you look at
india's system of government (a british style
democracy) along with who their largest trading
partners are you see there is a connection.  india's
economy is driven in part by the UK/US machine.  but
then look at china, their greatest gift is cheap labor
that is exploited by every country in the world.  in
the news, we put down china for human rights issues
but maybe china has a legitimate reason for cracking
down on falun gong.  we can easily look at china and
creat a demon because we don't understand them or
think like them.  the lack of understanding of other
cultures or the lack of similarity between cultures
can be a trade barrier as well.  IMO, multiculturalsim
or trans-national progressivism won't work.  i can
accept the fact that every human has certain basic
human rights.. that's a no brainer.  but if i don't
understand you, your laws, your beliefs, i'll go the
path of least resistance and sign a contract with
someone safer.  

this would be a basic building block of helping other
countries to grow more rapidly without having to
outsource from america/the west.  if you need a
working case study to drive this point home, look at
any surviving communist country or most middle eastern
countries and compare them to your average western
style economy.  

--- Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.org> wrote:
> 
> Wow, it was just a midnight rant as a letter to the
> editor.  Maybe I
> should lay off the Altoids.
> 
> 	Brian
>

> >
> >
>

> >
> >
> > A man of many talents...
> >
> > Although I am little scared of my job getting
> outsourced now...
> >
> > -troy

---------- Forwarded message From curls ----------

**************************************************************


please pass this on to your friends and family... and join us for another
amazing event this weekend!


*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-
Cloud Factory Design Collective presents

                 RE:FUSE

         July 12th, 2003

a fashion performance brought to you by the best underground designers...

*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-

Listless and lacklustered from a year of bulldozed war, unheard
protests, and insidious attacks on our freedoms?

Never fear!  The cfdc returns with a fashion performance fueled to
reinspire and refire the spirit.  Always ones to (b)uck the trends
and reject the status quo, re:fuse is our recommittment to live out
loud!  To re:fuse hopelessness, the 'security' of acquiescence, and
the tyranny of the normal ~ we raise our needles in the air!!!

Revel in the beauty of the underground, as the cfdc shakes your booty
and brain to pieces, re:fuses and revives you!


Doors open at 7:30pm

**Music provided all night long (for you to shake your booty!)

Joe Rice (Circuit Breaker)
AudioEl (Cybrid)
DJ Enki (Future Primitive Sound)
Fred Funk (Brass Tax)
Stonie (Cloud Factory)

Fashion show starts at 8:00pm

Dancing and grooving until 2am

Presale tickets are $10 and available online at Ticketweb
http://ticketweb.com/user/?region=sfbay&query=detail&event=443347

http://www.cfdesign.net/

*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-

StudioZ
314 11th Street @ Folsom, San Francisco
415.252.7666 www.StudioZ.tv
21+ w/ID
Tickets available on www.Ticketweb.com

Join the Cloud Factory Design Collective announcement list at
http://cloudfactory.org/cgi-bin/mailman/listinfo/cfdc-announce/

*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-

-> -> -> CFDC- emerging fashion FRESH from the underground!

The Cloud Factory Design Collective (CFDC) is comprised of an inventive
group of up-and-coming designers, burning with vision, talent, and
creative energy.  With roots in the Bay Area underground dance culture,
the CFDC molds a post-rave fashion experience, at once heady and
whimsical, yet rooted in a disciplined expression of hard-earned
street-learned skills.

The collective creates, arranges, produces, and
performs its work, with one major annual spring show held over the last
five years. With a belief that real style is art, and art is life- a CFDC
performance is a visual, aural, and sensory treat that marries fashion to
theater, dance, and music.  The Cloud Factory Design Collective originates
and disperses fashion into the hands of the young, the fun, the real, the
good, and the true.


*CFDC*
www.cfdesign.net

At 02:58 PM 7/8/2003, CPT Scarlet wrote:

>you sound like you've done some good research on the
>subject.  i don't have a subscription to salon so i
>won't be able to see the rest of your letter.  i agree
>that education is the key to helping solve the "third
>world" issue.  well, it is the second step.  however,
>democracy should be there first and it should be
>backed up my a similar moral code like we have in the
>west.
>
>i know that sounds snooty.  who are we to tell what
>morals are?  we aren't and i don't want to begin to,
>however, how can you explain that america is the
>strongest, most powerful, and rich country in the
>world when we aren't the biggest and most educated?
>
>look at india.  they are the largest democracy in the
>world.  they have enough people that received formal
>education to compete with the US however their
>literacy rate isn't that great.  yet out economy is 5
>times bigger than theirs.
>
>people with similar belief systems get along better.
>the west tends to stick together and if you look at
>india's system of government (a british style
>democracy) along with who their largest trading
>partners are you see there is a connection.  india's
>economy is driven in part by the UK/US machine.  but
>then look at china, their greatest gift is cheap labor
>that is exploited by every country in the world.  in
>the news, we put down china for human rights issues
>but maybe china has a legitimate reason for cracking
>down on falun gong.  we can easily look at china and
>creat a demon because we don't understand them or
>think like them.  the lack of understanding of other
>cultures or the lack of similarity between cultures
>can be a trade barrier as well.  IMO, multiculturalsim
>or trans-national progressivism won't work.  i can
>accept the fact that every human has certain basic
>human rights.. that's a no brainer.  but if i don't
>understand you, your laws, your beliefs, i'll go the
>path of least resistance and sign a contract with
>someone safer.
>
>this would be a basic building block of helping other
>countries to grow more rapidly without having to
>outsource from america/the west.  if you need a
>working case study to drive this point home, look at
>any surviving communist country or most middle eastern
>countries and compare them to your average western
>style economy.
>

friday, july 18th 2003
all ages : 09.00pm - 04.00am
$7 Presale Tickets!

[Celebrating the Resistance Recordings record release of "Get Up!" by DJ 
Tronic & Valerie Sparks]

Limited 350 Capacity
Virgin San Francisco Location!
1 room : 1 vibe.


Gettin Your Ass Up!:

CLOUDSKIPPER vs. DJ TRONIC [on 4 Turntables and 3 CDJ's!!]
[liquidvinyldjs.com/raw elements vs. resistance 
recordings/liquidvinyldjs.com]
Ok... 2 turntables is cool... 4 turntables rocked the house... but c'mon.. 4 
turntables and 3 CDJ's?! This is a set that will be as entertaining as it is 
challenging for these twin brothers! Get ready for the Hard House, the 
Hardcore, the Gabber, and everything else these two will drop.. sure to have 
the place in total madness!

VALERIE SPARKS [CD Release!]
[resistance recordings/valeriesparks.com]
Showcasing her incredible vocal talent on the Resistance Recordings release 
"Get Up!", Valerie has proved that she's more than one of the most talented 
DJs on the West Coast. She'll be dropping her signature style of energetic 
tracks to make ya get up, get movin!

BAZOOKA JOE
[djbazookajoe.com]
Those who have been waiting to see a solo set from this man.. wait no 
longer. With his incredible scratching and great variation behind the 
decks.. Bazooka Joe will keep ya rockin until the very last beat!

NO LEFT TURN vs. DJ REESE
[liquidvinyldjs.com/dynamic chinamen vs. liquidvinyldjs.com]
Proving that even if Nice Guys Finish Last, good skill will take you places! 
These two are coming out to rock just a bit harder, a bit faster, and a bit 
stronger!

J-MARR vs. CARLOS ALFONZO [J-Marr CD Release of "It's About Damn Time!"]
[liquidvinyldjs.com/bayraves vs. deciblast.org/bayraves]
Where the Ghetto Fried Rice™ man meets Mr. Carne Asada himself.. this set 
should be one to remember. With both coming out with free food during their 
set.. it'll be hard to decide whether to dance or to eat!

LEON COOK vs. PETER GO-ZANIA!
[hard science/hcftp vs. hcftp/gozania.com]
With a name like Leon Cook.. you'd think he'd be the one coming out with 
free food. That's not the case though.. as he teams up with his partner in 
crime Go-Zania to bring you a set full of the hardcore rush!

DOUBLE DAY vs. THE DOCTOR w/MC FADER
[swatchdog recordings vs. bayraves/deciblast.org]
Droppin drum & bass bombs on your mom's... that's what this set is gonna be 
all about. If you like your bass hard hittin and low.. this is gonna be the 
set for you!

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_12108131==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Canada to Sell Medical Marijuana to Seriously Ill 

--=====================_12108131==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Canada to Sell Medical Marijuana to Seriously Ill

Wed July 9, 2003 01:52 PM ET
By David Ljunggren

OTTAWA (Reuters) - Canada became on Wednesday the first country in the 
world to start selling marijuana to several hundred seriously ill people 
but said the pot project could be halted at any time.

Ottawa announced in July 2001 that some patients would be able to use 
marijuana provided by the government. But plans to grow official pot hit a 
series of snags, prompting a court in Ontario to give Ottawa until July 10 
to come up with a solution.

The new plan is Ottawa's response to that ruling. Federal officials said 
more research into the claimed benefits of medical pot was needed and they 
would therefore appeal the court ruling, a decision that angered critics.

"My first obligation is to ensure the safety and efficacy of this product. 
Marijuana is not a proven therapeutic product," said Health Minister Anne 
McLellan.

"I remain committed to (Ottawa's) medical marijuana research program, which 
promotes research on the medical value of marijuana while taking a 
compassionate approach to Canadians who suffer from serious medical 
conditions."

The 582 sufferers granted dispensation from criminal laws to use the drug 
will be able to buy dried marijuana for $3.70 per 0.04 ounce -- about half 
the current black-market rate -- or a pack of 30 seeds for $20 so they can 
grow their own plants.

"Although this interim policy can be amended or suspended at any time, it 
is anticipated that it will remain in effect until...(Ottawa's) roles and 
responsibilities with respect to a supply of marijuana for medical purposes 
have been clarified by the courts," the health ministry said in a statement.

McLellan said despite the planned appeal, Ottawa would press ahead with 
clinical trials to probe whether marijuana could really benefit the ill.

The drug -- grown in a special federal facility in a mine shaft in central 
Canada -- will be given to patients by their doctors. Officials recommend 
that patients do not smoke pot but rather put it in food, drinks or use 
other methods.

Alison Myrden, who has multiple sclerosis, a disorder of the brain and 
spinal cord, took part in a demonstration in Ottawa and condemned the 
government for appealing the court ruling.

"This country has to act now...nobody wants us to play this political 
football game any more. People are suffering and dying out there," she said.

Canada's approach is markedly different to that of the United States, where 
the Supreme Court in 2001 upheld a federal ban on medical marijuana.

U.S. authorities have strongly criticized Canadian plans to decriminalize 
the possession of small amounts of marijuana, arguing it could result in 
highly potent pot flooding across the border.


Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U  
--=====================_12108131==.ALT--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  Canada to Sell Medical Marijuana to Seriously Ill

Exactly, probably a little ticked.  (And I totally agree with you on the
developing mind, I'm really glad I didn't do anything until I was 18.) If it
were legal it would actually be harder for teens to get.  Right now its
easier for teens to get weed than it is to get alcohol.  With it legal it
would most likely still be illegal to grow your own or monitored in much the
same way that beer supply stores are monitored.  It would be sold in stores
with an 18 or 21+ age limit needed so they'd have to have someone else buy
it for them much the same way alcohol is bought now.  It would be cheaper
than street value (it'd have to be to get rid of illegal sales) and a new
way would have to be developed to tell if you're high right then and there
and incapable of driving instead of any ol' blood test which will show
you've smoked within' the last month.  All in all my guess is that less
teens would actually be smoking it than they do now because of the hassle of
getting it and switch to the next easiest thing to find most likely.
Probably a combination of lung capicty and skill tests.  Or, if its legal
and you're a pothead you'd probably just reek of it ;)

-Rayn

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  Canada to Sell Medical Marijuana to Seriously Ill

On Wed, Jul 09, 2003 at 08:24:21PM -0700, Geri Dahl wrote:
> if marijuana were legal across the board, much like alcohol is,
> how would you feel if your pre-teen came home from school stoned?

Probably pretty damn upset. There's be a sense of betrayal, a sense
of somehow failing my child. Wondering where they got it. Why? Why?
What do I do?

But, it *does* happen. Kids smoke cigarettes, too, which is much
more harmful. Kids find liquor, too.

So then I think, what happens a while down the line?

Down the line people will be more familiar with it. Rather than
*DRUGS*, will it be more like cigarettes or liquor, familiar and
off-limits, but not dramatically stigmatized?

What happens when the horror reaction to MJ as *drugs* wears off?

Sean

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] Square Root of America

--part1_1e0.d00af26.2c3e42ee_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

So when it boils down to it, the real root of the two sides of America at 
their most extream measures. You have one thereoy I would like to call the 
"Imagine" theorey based on the lyrics of the song of course. Proposing that people 
can govern themselves because every human being is good deep down within their 
hearts. Proposing that perhaps we (heaven forbid) forfiet our military and 
that out of this kind gesture the rest of the world would leave us in peace and 
possibly become peacefull themselves. Suppose we deactivated all of our own 
nuclear weapons first, then asked other nations to do the same? Would waring 
nations just say "haha you naive fools! muhahhahah" and proceed to bomb us after 
our peaceful gesture? Taking over our land killing and raping us all? 
And then you have the other thereoy which states the fact "Thank god for US 
military or we'd all be nazi's by now" pointing out that, in fact America saved 
the entire world from Hitler. Learning from our mistake of not taking him out 
sooner, we now search and destroy all potential "Hitlers" by being bigger and 
badder than them. 
I mean we are forturnate to truely be the most powerful nation in the current 
global waring networks, nobody is arguing with that, but how do we use this 
power? Can we really expect other nations to just get rid of their nuclear 
weapons just because we tell them to, in the meantime while we have more nuclear 
weapons than anyone else? It seems we only trust ourselves because we know that 
America is good at heart and means well and good and is globally moral, while 
other nations who have nuclear weapons aren't to be trusted. but who is it to 
judge that? 
If we chose the "Imagine" theroey stoped funding for weapons and military 
equipment, spent that money on environmental issues and our ecconomy for building 
jobs for jobless and houseing the homeless. Would then, terrorist still die 
to attack us? perhaps terrorist attack us for a reason, because they see our 
spending as selfish they see our power and intimidating and unfair. Does that 
make terrorism ok?   no of course not but you do have to unstand that terrorist 
isn't just madmen, it's people who have taken extream measures agaist our 
ways. They believe in it so fiercly that they die for it. Our growing military 
makes us more vulnarable to these attacks because it gives them incentive, motive 
and reason to be agaist us and they can do so convincinb themselve they are 
doing the right thing. If we were a truely inocent giving loving country that 
doesn't focus on self defense perhaps they wouldn't attack us in the first 
place. 
Of course there is a chance we could try to take this so called "Imagine" 
thereoy into effect and it could very well backfire on us supposing that they 
disreguarded our peaceful gestures and decided to bomb us or invade us while our 
guard was down, I think that is the big fear in the back of our minds.... But 
somewhere down the line you have to figure, a world where you make a profound 
peaceful gesture and in result get shot for your effort is a not a world worth 
living in. On the other hand you have to wonder "what if"... what if we used 
all our nuclear weapons for energy... what if north korea and iraq folled in 
our path. Are we gonna set an example? or are we just gonna implement "Do as i 
say not as i do" to the rest of the world??? What if...

--part1_1e0.d00af26.2c3e42ee_boundary--

Subject: [sfraves] .: New Jungle Sets a'la Dirtbox Radio :.

what's up y'all?

The last two weeks' Dirtbox Radio broadcasts are now archived and up for
y'all to listen to.  Just follow the links below to jam out 'n stuff.
Archives are stored in 56k real media format, so all you modem kiddies can
listen too:)

FTP will be up soon, so you can grab a 128k mp3.  Yeah, i Know i've been
promising for a while, but time is short, ya know?  Anyhow - click a link
below to enhance your workday, or sit down with Dirtbox, some champagne,
and your old lady.  DNB is good for snoggin;)

Ze archives, in chronological order:

2 wks ago:

We do this ish every week, so make sure to tune in:)  This week we have
J-Roe & Teknition, and the Winterman himself comin' back.
www.dirtboxradio.com is where it's at.

Oh yeah, and for all y'all in ze urrea, come out tonight to
A.L.I.A.S./Alchemy @ Nation.  Twisted Individual's gonna be in the front
room (boh!) from 11:30-1, with yours truly closing up the night.  Just got
a buncha vinyl when i was out in San Fran last week.  Hit me up if you'd
like to get on the reduced price list, but make sure it's before 6pm!

Also, a big BIG up to my homies Jerel, Hooligan, and the one Evancipation
for holdin' down the fort!  Also to big moe Winterman for fillin' in, and
Jumpin' Joe Migraine for makin a guest appearance (dude, that's a lot of
fuckin gum!).

Jackson (ODJ)
