Subject: [sfraves] signs, bars and people nrr

--0-1220377337-1057871262=:23477
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

something to consider: do you want a relationship that is based purely on signs? you can have one at anytime, because signs are something that are pretty much based on your imagination...relationships are based on trust...do trust and signs go hand in hand? i don't know. maybe if your partner is constantly yawning and is totally honest, then yes, she is in fact tired...bars are places where people go to hear music sometimes, especially when there is music playing that has been formally announced and everything. people need to believe what they need to believe to get by. i suppose that life is tedious for some without the extra stuff. filters aren't just for computers and programmers did not invent the idea of filtering. football fans have been filtering out their loved-ones in the easy chairs for decades. dream on. :)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ATP: NRR: P2P File Sharing


On Thursday, July 10, 2003, at 04:34 PM, Jack Triumph wrote:

> Anyone else hear word round the campfire about RIAA shutting down 
> Kazaa and others and then file lawsuit(s) to have the companies 
> release their user lists? Remember, RIAA sued Verizon to just get ONE 
> username.
...
> yes, I know I am one in 60,000,000 who use the software, but, I don't 
> want to be the one who RIAA decides to f**k with. Just seeing what 
> y'alls opinions are...

Being a Mac user means I use less-targeted P2P and file-sharing 
clients, so I think my chances are even lower of being dragged in by 
the DAs on the RIAA's payroll. However, part of me kind of wishes they 
would. Oooh, how I'd love to call a big-name bloodsucker.. er.. 
attorney, alert all the media, and show how the music industry is going 
against one of its best customers. I'd produce thousands of dollars of 
receipts (which I've kept) and show that even though I do download 
music, I buy more than their demographically "best" customers combined.

There was somebody on Slashdot or somewhere similar that said something 
along the lines of "They think that by suing us, we'll buy more 
records?"  That's the non-sensical scare tactic behind all this.  If 
they come and bust people like me (and I'm sure hundreds of others on 
this list who blow most of their income on records, CDs, etc.) then 
they'll really be asking for the worst PR possible.

So as our fearless leader has so eloquently said..  "Bring 'em on."  
Bitches.

  - omid

Ahh the days of private ftp servers will once again rule. The days of ratio
downloads where you HAD to contribute to download will be back enfore. I
dunno about you but all the user info in Kazaa is complete BS. I personally
wouldn't stress over it. Did you read the article about Kazaa and how it's
setup? It's not located in any *one* place. The places that it is located in
and how it's run have all this privacy *fuck you america* policies in place.
It was really rather clever. The woman that functionally acts as head of
Kazaa won't step foot in our country because if she does then they can come
after her. The article is from a few months back. If you can find it, then
read it. I'll be curious to see how jurisdiction works with Kazaa because
from what I read the US can't do dick nor can RIAA.

Kind of like having your site hosted at Haven Co in Sealand...

From sfraves-return-103710-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Jul 10 23:53:08 2003

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 66375 invoked from network); 10 Jul 2003 23:53:06 -0000
Date: Thu, 10 Jul 2003 19:48:00 -0700
Message-Id: <200307101948.AA1933705776@helpmejebus.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
From: "judas judas" <judas@helpmejebus.com>
Reply-To: <judas@helpmejebus.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
X-Mailer: <IMail v7.14>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] ATP: NRR: P2P File Sharing

people downloading music hasn't significantly reduced record 
sales.  i think that what the RIAA is really afraid of is having 
lost their near monopoly on exposure.  having the fewest musicians 
making the most amount of money for them has been the business 
strategy of many major labels.  in order for that to work, 
*everyone* has to be hearing the big hits put out by the major 
labels alone.  no one in that business considered indie labels to 
be a threat until mp3s came on the scene.  what scares these 
people is not having as much control over what we listen to.

about a year ago the RIAA paid a lot of money for a study to be 
done on whether or not internet music piracy could be effectively 
stopped.  mind you the study wasn't on HOW, but on whether or not 
it's possible.  the results -- well, i can only guess that it 
suggested that it's unstoppable because the results were promptly 
supressed.

mean, they don't hug back, but it can almost feel like you're 
connecting to something special .... jesus, i'm such a dyke."
-Samuel Comstock Zoranovich

Date: Thu, 10 Jul 2003 16:58:36 -0700
From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <20030710235836.GH7335@pion.local>
Mail-Followup-To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>,
	SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
References: <BAY8-DAV438yxdZjfNL00000230@hotmail.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline
In-Reply-To: <BAY8-DAV438yxdZjfNL00000230@hotmail.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] ATP: NRR: P2P File Sharing

quoth Jack Triumph:
> Anyone else hear word round the campfire about RIAA shutting down
> Kazaa and others and then file lawsuit(s) to have the companies
> release their user lists? Remember, RIAA sued Verizon to just get ONE
> username. 

Actually, the deal is that the RIAA has been unable to shut down Kazaa
et al, and is now resorting to litigation against individual users. At
one point, they were lobbying for legislation that would allow them to
DOS (or worse) people they suspected of sharing copyrighted works, but
that didn't make it very far. :) Then, of course, was Orin Hatch's
recommendation that they be given the technology to physically destroy
copyright violators' machines... *sigh*

> yes, I know I am one in 60,000,000 who use the software, but, I don't
> want to be the one who RIAA decides to f**k with.

Your chances are pretty slim, but from what I hear they're just
targetting the big "dealers" -- people offering up lots of stuff for
download. If you're just downloading, you're probably in the clear. Of
course, the general consensus is that the whole thing's just a scare
tactic.

> Where the hell am I supposed to get decent 'stuff' now ;) ?

C'mon, could you *ever* really get anything decent from a filesharing
network? I gave up on that shit before Napster bit the dust... low-
bitrate, incomplete, poorly labeled crap, the lot of it. And to top it
all off, the people with the good "stuff" were either on dialup (so your
transfers were slow as all hell), or PPPoE connections (so they lost
their dynamic IP's all the time).

Trying to find music (or anything else, for that matter) on P2P networks
is an unreliable, unbelievably time-consuming exercise that I'd just
rather not bother with anymore... YMMV, of course. ;)

And regarding Soulseek... I've heard good things, alas, I was unable to
find a Mac client last time I looked. But we've got the iTunes Music
Store, so neh neh neh neh :P

-- 
shawn allen

  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

amen!  you hit the nail on the head.  it was so long ago, no one in the world
remembers the time when the music industry WASN'T controlled by multi-million dollar
monopolies.  the fact is, the music industry will ALWAYS thrive because music is so
important to our human nature.  what's really in peril is the record labels' iron
grip over what we should listen to, think, wear, speak, etc.  and i for one am
looking forward to the day when record labels lose their ability to create superstar
artists on the wing of a marketing department.  because when that day comes, all
artists will be indie artists and maybe it will actually be viable to make your
living as one when you don't have to compete against Britney Spears and Justin
Timberlake.

-tonicboy

--- judas judas <judas@helpmejebus.com> wrote:
> people downloading music hasn't significantly reduced record 
> sales.  i think that what the RIAA is really afraid of is having 
> lost their near monopoly on exposure.  having the fewest musicians 
> making the most amount of money for them has been the business 
> strategy of many major labels.  in order for that to work, 
> *everyone* has to be hearing the big hits put out by the major 
> labels alone.  no one in that business considered indie labels to 
> be a threat until mp3s came on the scene.  what scares these 
> people is not having as much control over what we listen to.
> 
> about a year ago the RIAA paid a lot of money for a study to be 
> done on whether or not internet music piracy could be effectively 
> stopped.  mind you the study wasn't on HOW, but on whether or not 
> it's possible.  the results -- well, i can only guess that it 
> suggested that it's unstoppable because the results were promptly 
> supressed.

"_ fable _" wrote:

> Like Coolworld, its hard to hate them 

Eh... not really.  But...

> because for every snide comment directed toward them, there is a 
> personal response explaining how they could possibly make it better.

Yeah, I do gotta give them credit on that one.  Whoever they employ to monitor
and post to SFRaves is sure dedicated to his job.  He/she finds the smallest
criticism, even in threads that aren't specific to coolworld, and is quick to
try to spin things around to make it look like coolworld is an honest,
intimate, friendly promoter that's a positive and integral part of the local
scene, instead of a greedy and exploitave out of town corporation that throws
massives.

And talk about turnaround time.  This guy's on the ball.  Last week, when I
posted a (admittedly, kinda snide and trollish) remark on the cyberfest flyers
thread, as to wether or not coolworld was actually going to DELIVER all the
talent they promise this time around; it was less than thirty minutes before I
got a reply pointing out that: "all headliners for PNY03 were at the Cow Palace
and on time".

Of course, said reply didn't mention the talent that weren't "headliners".  And
it didn't mention LAST year's cyberfest, and Richard Humpty Vision and Donald
Glaude; whom they promised on their flyers, but didn't deliver.  Nor did they
mention eminem and his D12 "supergroup" which they promised at some party or
another, but "kicked off the lineup".

It's wierd as hell dealing with people who have actually "drank the Kool-Aid",
so to speak.  PR drones are just something else.  The engineer and cynic in me
just screrams "bullshit" at most of what comes out of them.  But they just seem
to believe it like the gospel.  If the corporation says it's so, then it's so. 
And any attempt to question or challange them is just beyond their
comprehension.  When I get caught in exchanges like this:

(Regarding DanceSafe)

coolworld drone:  "The organization you belong to is illegal.  What you do is
illegal.  You are a criminal."

me:  "Then why have both the district attorney, and a lawyer I once retained
myself, said otherwise?"

coolworld drone:  "The district attorney is irrelevant.  Your lawyer is
irrelevant.  The law is irrelevant.  The organization you belong to is illegal.
 What you do is illegal.  You are a criminal.  Your biological and
technological distinctiveness will be added to our own.  You will adapt to
service us.  Resistance is futile."

... it really does make me wonder if there *IS* an actual human being at the
other end, or not.


cya,
john

Okay... this is not even REMOTELY rave related.  And I'm sorry.  But SFRaves is
the largest cross-section of people scattered throughout the whole of The Bay
Area that I know.  And I was hoping someone would know the answer.

So, you know those little crushed red pepper flakes you get in shakers at pizza
places?  Well, back in Florida, there used to be this place that had the same
kind of crushed and dried pepper flakes... but with habanero peppers instead of
the tamer red peppers.

Well, I used to get regularly resupplied in care packages from my mom.  But the
place we used to get them closed down, neither of us has found a new source,
and after streaching out my stockpile as long as I could, I'm out.

So does anyone know where I can get those little shaker jars, but with habanero
flakes instead of regular peppers???

Thanks bunches, and I'm sorry about such a horrible NRR.

On Thu, 10 Jul 2003, John B. wrote:

> > Like Coolworld, its hard to hate them

Read your own reply...Yep.

> ... it really does make me wonder if there *IS* an actual human being at the
> other end, or not.

Yep, and Nope.

Depend's on what you're trying to do.

Taco Bell analogy:

A. I'm ordering 2 taco's: they come out butt-crappy.
 1. Complain to the cashier/drone, get an apology
 2. Complain to the manager/drone, get 2 replacement tacos

Result: Tacos are still crappy

B. I'm ordering 2 taco's: they come out butt-crappy.
 1. Complain to Customer Relations/drone, receive apology
 2. Also receive coupons for more crappy Taco Bell

Result: A few bucks richer, but tacos are still crappy

C.I'm ordering 2 taco's: they come out butt-crappy. Abandon
establishment, make own tacos.
 1. Figure out how to make good taco
 2. Make good taco, Invite friends
 3. Everyone experiences good taco (on a small scale)

Result: Good Tacos, Good Friends

The problem is...?

Granted, this is a simplistic solution, but <spin aside>, can you expect
massives to acknowledge and embrace harm-reduction with what's on their
public plate w/ current threatening legislation?

Tell 'em to take out Trans-fats while you're at it...or just work to
replace the tacos.

 -t

p.s. Sorry for the analogy, it's late, and I'm hungry =)

Q: Is there a Linux version of the Soulseek client?

A: Alex Kanavin is maintaining an open source python port of the Soulseek
client that's available at http://www.sensi.org/~ak/pyslsk/

Q: Is there a Mac version of the Soulseek client?

A: I heard tell that the Linux client mentioned above could be made to run
on a Mac, provided that you can get python running on it. Any solid info on
that would be much appreciated.

away to my friends, since I have no use for that landfill-fodder after
I rip it.  All my music listening is done off .mp3 now.

Putting music on big chunks of plastic is just so wrong now that we
have the techonogy of the Internet.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] ATP: NRR: P2P File Sharing

At one point this was true.  But this has definitely changed.  Between
economic factors and file sharing they have started seeing huge
decreases in record sales.  Doesn't make me like them anymore but they
really have started feeling the hurt (if millions in profit can be
considered the hurt).  On a side note though, indie labels that have
been around forever have had to start hiring employees because their
record sales have never been higher.  

-----Original Message-----
From: judas judas [mailto:judas@helpmejebus.com] 
Sent: Thursday, July 10, 2003 7:48 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] ATP: NRR: P2P File Sharing


people downloading music hasn't significantly reduced record 
sales.  i think that what the RIAA is really afraid of is having 
lost their near monopoly on exposure.  having the fewest musicians 
making the most amount of money for them has been the business 
strategy of many major labels.  in order for that to work, 
*everyone* has to be hearing the big hits put out by the major 
labels alone.  no one in that business considered indie labels to 
be a threat until mp3s came on the scene.  what scares these 
people is not having as much control over what we listen to.

about a year ago the RIAA paid a lot of money for a study to be 
done on whether or not internet music piracy could be effectively 
stopped.  mind you the study wasn't on HOW, but on whether or not 
it's possible.  the results -- well, i can only guess that it 
suggested that it's unstoppable because the results were promptly 
supressed.

mean, they don't hug back, but it can almost feel like you're 
connecting to something special .... jesus, i'm such a dyke." -Samuel
Comstock Zoranovich
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Subject: RE: [sfraves] paging dj seven

Not to try and redeem coolworld and the problems they've had over the
years.  Eminem and D12 had made themselves publicly violent at a show
about a week or two before Cyberfest.  Coolworld wasn't the only one to
drop them from the bill after that.  As much as I would've loved to see
Eminem, I can't fault them for not wanting violence at their event.  And
this is from a dude who was stranded in Fresno because our bus drivers
were asleep and the cops shut the event down early.

Another funny thing that I mentioned to Fable offline earlier is that
ever since they posted the teaser with Kraftwerk and Heiroglyphics as
the headliners, I haven't seen one word of criticism. ;)  Unless I was
dunk and hit delete on replies to it.  All in all I have had as much fun
at coolworld events as I have had at school dances.  Can be kinda fun
but overall you'd much rather be somewhere with a more intimate vibe,
some good locals and actually go all night.

I wasn't going to go, but no way in hell am I going to miss Kraftwerk.

-Rayn

-----Original Message-----
From: John B. [mailto:svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com] 
Sent: Thursday, July 10, 2003 11:18 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org; fable4our@hotmail.com
Subject: Re: [sfraves] paging dj seven


"_ fable _" wrote:

> Like Coolworld, its hard to hate them

Eh... not really.  But...

> because for every snide comment directed toward them, there is a
> personal response explaining how they could possibly make it better.

Yeah, I do gotta give them credit on that one.  Whoever they employ to
monitor and post to SFRaves is sure dedicated to his job.  He/she finds
the smallest criticism, even in threads that aren't specific to
coolworld, and is quick to try to spin things around to make it look
like coolworld is an honest, intimate, friendly promoter that's a
positive and integral part of the local scene, instead of a greedy and
exploitave out of town corporation that throws massives.

And talk about turnaround time.  This guy's on the ball.  Last week,
when I posted a (admittedly, kinda snide and trollish) remark on the
cyberfest flyers thread, as to wether or not coolworld was actually
going to DELIVER all the talent they promise this time around; it was
less than thirty minutes before I got a reply pointing out that: "all
headliners for PNY03 were at the Cow Palace and on time".

Of course, said reply didn't mention the talent that weren't
"headliners".  And it didn't mention LAST year's cyberfest, and Richard
Humpty Vision and Donald Glaude; whom they promised on their flyers, but
didn't deliver.  Nor did they mention eminem and his D12 "supergroup"
which they promised at some party or another, but "kicked off the
lineup".

It's wierd as hell dealing with people who have actually "drank the
Kool-Aid", so to speak.  PR drones are just something else.  The
engineer and cynic in me just screrams "bullshit" at most of what comes
out of them.  But they just seem to believe it like the gospel.  If the
corporation says it's so, then it's so. 
And any attempt to question or challange them is just beyond their
comprehension.  When I get caught in exchanges like this:

(Regarding DanceSafe)

coolworld drone:  "The organization you belong to is illegal.  What you
do is illegal.  You are a criminal."

me:  "Then why have both the district attorney, and a lawyer I once
retained myself, said otherwise?"

coolworld drone:  "The district attorney is irrelevant.  Your lawyer is
irrelevant.  The law is irrelevant.  The organization you belong to is
illegal.  What you do is illegal.  You are a criminal.  Your biological
and technological distinctiveness will be added to our own.  You will
adapt to service us.  Resistance is futile."

... it really does make me wonder if there *IS* an actual human being at
the other end, or not.


cya,
john

right on.  i love what neurological studies have shown about our 
reaction to music.  music is unique in that it simulataneously 
stimulates all parts of our brains.  it's not like, oh the

etc... music gets us using everything at once.

>At one point this was true.  But this has definitely changed.  
Between
>economic factors and file sharing they have started seeing huge
>decreases in record sales.  Doesn't make me like them anymore but 
they
>really have started feeling the hurt (if millions in profit can be
>considered the hurt).  On a side note though, indie labels that 
have
>been around forever have had to start hiring employees because 
their
>record sales have never been higher.

>-----Original Message-----
>From: judas judas [mailto:judas@helpmejebus.com] 
>Sent: Thursday, July 10, 2003 7:48 PM
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] ATP: NRR: P2P File Sharing
>
>
>people downloading music hasn't significantly reduced record 
>sales.  i think that what the RIAA is really afraid of is having 
>lost their near monopoly on exposure.  having the fewest 
musicians 
>making the most amount of money for them has been the business 
>strategy of many major labels.  in order for that to work, 
>*everyone* has to be hearing the big hits put out by the major 
>labels alone.  no one in that business considered indie labels to 
>be a threat until mp3s came on the scene.  what scares these 
>people is not having as much control over what we listen to.
>
>about a year ago the RIAA paid a lot of money for a study to be 
>done on whether or not internet music piracy could be effectively 
>stopped.  mind you the study wasn't on HOW, but on whether or not 
>it's possible.  the results -- well, i can only guess that it 
>suggested that it's unstoppable because the results were promptly 
>supressed.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] paging dj seven

CoolWorld and Cyberfest type events are not *raves* nor are they *parties*
anymore. It's a concert now. A lollapalooza of the dance music variety. The
same can be said about the Skills parties now with the slight difference
that Skills attracts a more foo foo crowd due to bookings//history. All the
same they're both dance music festivals that share more in common with a
Live105 BFD than a *rave* or *party*  now. If you go to one of these with
the mindset that you're going to a concert to see a few acts I bet you will
walk away with a better feeling about the event. When I think about the last
BFD I went to in 2000 with all of the kids running around, the 21+ crowd
getting trashed at the bars, and the masses of people in general it sounds
just like a massive. Biggest differencence? Your typical concerts aren't
having laws passed to ban them...

:: r y a n ::

----- Original Message -----

Sent: Friday, July 11, 2003 9:51 AM
Subject: RE: [sfraves] paging dj seven


Not to try and redeem coolworld and the problems they've had over the
years.  Eminem and D12 had made themselves publicly violent at a show
about a week or two before Cyberfest.  Coolworld wasn't the only one to
drop them from the bill after that.  As much as I would've loved to see
Eminem, I can't fault them for not wanting violence at their event.  And
this is from a dude who was stranded in Fresno because our bus drivers
were asleep and the cops shut the event down early.

Another funny thing that I mentioned to Fable offline earlier is that
ever since they posted the teaser with Kraftwerk and Heiroglyphics as
the headliners, I haven't seen one word of criticism. ;)  Unless I was
dunk and hit delete on replies to it.  All in all I have had as much fun
at coolworld events as I have had at school dances.  Can be kinda fun
but overall you'd much rather be somewhere with a more intimate vibe,
some good locals and actually go all night.

I wasn't going to go, but no way in hell am I going to miss Kraftwerk.

-Rayn

-----Original Message-----
From: John B. [mailto:svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com]
Sent: Thursday, July 10, 2003 11:18 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org; fable4our@hotmail.com
Subject: Re: [sfraves] paging dj seven


"_ fable _" wrote:

> Like Coolworld, its hard to hate them

Eh... not really.  But...

> because for every snide comment directed toward them, there is a
> personal response explaining how they could possibly make it better.

Yeah, I do gotta give them credit on that one.  Whoever they employ to
monitor and post to SFRaves is sure dedicated to his job.  He/she finds
the smallest criticism, even in threads that aren't specific to
coolworld, and is quick to try to spin things around to make it look
like coolworld is an honest, intimate, friendly promoter that's a
positive and integral part of the local scene, instead of a greedy and
exploitave out of town corporation that throws massives.

And talk about turnaround time.  This guy's on the ball.  Last week,
when I posted a (admittedly, kinda snide and trollish) remark on the
cyberfest flyers thread, as to wether or not coolworld was actually
going to DELIVER all the talent they promise this time around; it was
less than thirty minutes before I got a reply pointing out that: "all
headliners for PNY03 were at the Cow Palace and on time".

Of course, said reply didn't mention the talent that weren't
"headliners".  And it didn't mention LAST year's cyberfest, and Richard
Humpty Vision and Donald Glaude; whom they promised on their flyers, but
didn't deliver.  Nor did they mention eminem and his D12 "supergroup"
which they promised at some party or another, but "kicked off the
lineup".

It's wierd as hell dealing with people who have actually "drank the
Kool-Aid", so to speak.  PR drones are just something else.  The
engineer and cynic in me just screrams "bullshit" at most of what comes
out of them.  But they just seem to believe it like the gospel.  If the
corporation says it's so, then it's so.
And any attempt to question or challange them is just beyond their
comprehension.  When I get caught in exchanges like this:

(Regarding DanceSafe)

coolworld drone:  "The organization you belong to is illegal.  What you
do is illegal.  You are a criminal."

me:  "Then why have both the district attorney, and a lawyer I once
retained myself, said otherwise?"

coolworld drone:  "The district attorney is irrelevant.  Your lawyer is
irrelevant.  The law is irrelevant.  The organization you belong to is
illegal.  What you do is illegal.  You are a criminal.  Your biological
and technological distinctiveness will be added to our own.  You will
adapt to service us.  Resistance is futile."

... it really does make me wonder if there *IS* an actual human being at
the other end, or not.


cya,
john

Subject: [sfraves] Audiopad tech

This is your SFR tech updated.

http://web.media.mit.edu/~jpatten/newaudiopad.html.

"...It is a composition and performance instrument for electronic music
which tracks the positions of objects on a tabletop surface and converts
their motion into music. One can pull sounds from a giant set of samples,
juxtapose archived recordings against warm synthetic melodies, cut between
drum loops to create new beats, and apply digital processing all at the
same time on the same tableIt is a composition and performance instrument
for electronic music which tracks the positions of objects on a tabletop
surface and converts their motion into music. One can pull sounds from a
giant set of samples, juxtapose archived recordings against warm synthetic
melodies, cut between drum loops to create new beats, and apply digital
processing all at the same time on the same table."

--TRH

Actually, Ryan, the only event that has been shut down so far because of the

Billings, Montana) and not a rave.

I think the larger point here is that there's nothing transcendentally
special about events where electronic/dance music is played; a massive
40,000 person event will be less intimate than a 500 person gathering
regardless of what type of music is coming over the speakers.

Uh yeah right - but what scene spawned that hideous law? I'll give you a
hint - the bill has the name of the scene in it. Actually the point of this
thread is that you can't compare a giant concert//massive to a *rave* or
*party*  They aren't the same and aren't meant to be something intimate and
special. You don't go to an Ozzfest to get intimate with people there
because it's a concert. Well, actually if you're in the pit I bet that's
pretty damn initimate. =)

Two different beasts that can't be compared on the same ground.

:: r ::

----- Original Message ----- 
From: "Sean Griffith" <srg@pdx.edu>

Subject: [sfraves] Audiopad tech


This is your SFR tech updated.

http://web.media.mit.edu/~jpatten/newaudiopad.html.

"...It is a composition and performance instrument for electronic music
which tracks the positions of objects on a tabletop surface and converts
their motion into music. One can pull sounds from a giant set of samples,
juxtapose archived recordings against warm synthetic melodies, cut between
drum loops to create new beats, and apply digital processing all at the
same time on the same tableIt is a composition and performance instrument
for electronic music which tracks the positions of objects on a tabletop
surface and converts their motion into music. One can pull sounds from a
giant set of samples, juxtapose archived recordings against warm synthetic
melodies, cut between drum loops to create new beats, and apply digital
processing all at the same time on the same table."

--TRH

On 24th street  at Florida is a 'Mexicatesson' called la palma.
They have the most authentic menu in town. It is possible to buy freshly
made (Hecho en Mano) tortillas with a pint of your favorite fillings,
refritos, arroz, chile Colorado.  And have a rich culture filled Mexican
picnic.
None of that  chintzi Cuban stuff though.
Real soul food for real caballero's

Oh and I asked about Habanero peperrs and the senorita said that stuff is
for fattening Gator bait. Not good for food.  ; )
Just kidding.
They have freshly ground red pepper for about a $1 a pound. It will do till
you find a gator bait shop. (ooops racial slur , my bad)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ATP: NRR: P2P File Sharing / Python

--------------060209070009080504090707
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

On OSX, getting the latest python (and other linux stuff) going on is 
relatively easy...

download and install the developer tools, after a free signup at apple:

http://developer.apple.com/tools/download/

then go over to the fink project, and get that going:

http://fink.sourceforge.net/

then you can use fink to update python if needed, and get whatever other 
packages you're interested in that they've ported...

-joshua

From: Brian Lafferty <brianandallison@yahoo.com>

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] SRR: California Court of Appeal Decides "All Night Rave Parties Not Inherently Dangerous"


While not an antidote to the current Anti-rave
legislation at the federal level, this opinion does
show that the California Courts have some common
sense.  It also might have some positive effect on
property owners who are concerned about 'liability'
for providing spaces:

NJURY AND TORT LAW
SAKIYAMA v. AMF BOWLING CENTERS, INC., No B151800
(Cal. 2d App. Dist.
July 10, 2003)
In an action arising out of injuries occuring after a
"rave" party at
defendant's facilities, the trial court properly
granted defendant
summary judgment because 1) all night rave parties are
not inherently
dangerous, and 2) defendanthad no duty to prevent its
facility from use
for such a party, even if it knew or could assume that
drugs would be
used by some of the attendees.

To read the full text of this opinion, go to:
http://login.findlaw.com/scripts/callaw?dest=ca/caapp4th/slip/2003/b151800.html

Thats why you gotta love SFRAVES...someone pages a dj and the next thing you know were talking about massives vs. undergrounds, past Coolworld Events, and Coolworld Public relations. 

For starters, Rayn...your pretty much on the money. After Eminem and D12 decided to rumble in the Bronx, we really didnt have a choice but to cut them from the show. With law enforcement factors, etc...are hands were pretty much tied.

Yes, last years Cyberfest had some issues with some of our artist, but not with malice or ill intent. John almost makes it sound like we wanted are artist not to perform, or that we had some other agenda in having artist not play? What would we stand to gain from that, but some criticism on list like SFR as we've now seen.

It really doesn't add up John? We've been in business in the bay area for 13 years. We've had countless events where all of our artist played and performed as billed. 

Planet New Year 2003 did in fact feature all artist as advertised and for the most part all artist played as scheduled. 

What I find most interesting though John is your portrayal of myself, cause I don't really feel like you know me enough to be able to determine if i'm a drone, a real person, or an alien.

Fact is john, I probably have partied at some of the same Underground events that you do. We may have even danced side by side? I've helped and assisted countless organizations and continue to host smaller events that some of your friends probably have come too. hey maybe we'll see each other at the Moksha Tribe party?

It's also interesting how you characterize Coolworld, almost as if Coolworld was a large Corporate company with offices inside the Transamerica building? 

Well John, we don't have 50 employees and were not some corporate conglomerate either. Coolworld has gone through so many changes over the last 3 years that there are only two original employees from the old crew.

I've been with Coolworld for 2.5 years now and I oversee operations and marketing. I wouldn't say that I am "quick to try to spin things around to make it look like coolworld is an honest, intimate, friendly promoter that's a positive and integral part of the local scene", more so I would say that I am very passionate about what I do, and what ever has happened in the past with Coolworld is no longer happening now.

Since I am an integral planner and at the nucleus of Coolworld development I help shape and decide the direction of the organization. I can assure you that I have spent countless hours personally turning this organization inside out in an effort to create positive events that not only benefit the community, but are good events with excellent talent and superb music.

As you can see, Kraftwerk is booked for the show....in Addition to the Hieroglyphics....the Metal Heads Tour with Goldie and Storm, Mix Master Mike, and Planet Asia....and this is just the beginning of the line up.

Finally, your perception that Coolworld is a "greedy and exploitive out of town corporation that throws massives" is false. First, non of us are greedy, second were based in Alameda (and all of us who work for Coolworld, grew up here in the bay area), and last were not exploiting anything but are events.

No other scene in any genre fights over big parties vs. smaller parties. You don't see the Hip Hop community talking about how the Rock the Mic Tour is 20,000 people each event. You don't hear rockers complaining about the Ozzfest and how many people they have at there show. Yet, to some of you, it's almost a sin to have an event over 500 people?

I would have to re-utter ryans comments that Coolworld doesn't produce small 500 person shows, we never have. We produce large scale events that I would characterize as a concert festival...much like other festivals that you see today...

theres more then meets the eye john...you just have to dig a little deeper to see it. no harm no foul....I guess you see things one way I see them another. i wish you well either way.

In any case, if you have questions send them my way...I'll be happy to answer them. 

coolworld drone


Rayn <acydrayn@hotmail.com> wrote:Not to try and redeem coolworld and the problems they've had over the
years. Eminem and D12 had made themselves publicly violent at a show
about a week or two before Cyberfest. Coolworld wasn't the only one to
drop them from the bill after that. As much as I would've loved to see
Eminem, I can't fault them for not wanting violence at their event. And
this is from a dude who was stranded in Fresno because our bus drivers
were asleep and the cops shut the event down early.

Another funny thing that I mentioned to Fable offline earlier is that
ever since they posted the teaser with Kraftwerk and Heiroglyphics as
the headliners, I haven't seen one word of criticism. ;) Unless I was
dunk and hit delete on replies to it. All in all I have had as much fun
at coolworld events as I have had at school dances. Can be kinda fun
but overall you'd much rather be somewhere with a more intimate vibe,
some good locals and actually go all night.

I wasn't going to go, but no way in hell am I going to miss Kraftwerk.

-Rayn

"_ fable _" wrote:

> Like Coolworld, its hard to hate them

Eh... not really. But...

> because for every snide comment directed toward them, there is a
> personal response explaining how they could possibly make it better.

Yeah, I do gotta give them credit on that one. Whoever they employ to
monitor and post to SFRaves is sure dedicated to his job. He/she finds
the smallest criticism, even in threads that aren't specific to
coolworld, and is quick to try to spin things around to make it look
like coolworld is an honest, intimate, friendly promoter that's a
positive and integral part of the local scene, instead of a greedy and
exploitave out of town corporation that throws massives.

And talk about turnaround time. This guy's on the ball. Last week,
when I posted a (admittedly, kinda snide and trollish) remark on the
cyberfest flyers thread, as to wether or not coolworld was actually
going to DELIVER all the talent they promise this time around; it was
less than thirty minutes before I got a reply pointing out that: "all
headliners for PNY03 were at the Cow Palace and on time".

Of course, said reply didn't mention the talent that weren't
"headliners". And it didn't mention LAST year's cyberfest, and Richard
Humpty Vision and Donald Glaude; whom they promised on their flyers, but
didn't deliver. Nor did they mention eminem and his D12 "supergroup"
which they promised at some party or another, but "kicked off the
lineup".

It's wierd as hell dealing with people who have actually "drank the
Kool-Aid", so to speak. PR drones are just something else. The
engineer and cynic in me just screrams "bullshit" at most of what comes
out of them. But they just seem to believe it like the gospel. If the
corporation says it's so, then it's so. 
And any attempt to question or challange them is just beyond their
comprehension. When I get caught in exchanges like this:

(Regarding DanceSafe)

coolworld drone: "The organization you belong to is illegal. What you
do is illegal. You are a criminal."

me: "Then why have both the district attorney, and a lawyer I once
retained myself, said otherwise?"

coolworld drone: "The district attorney is irrelevant. Your lawyer is
irrelevant. The law is irrelevant. The organization you belong to is
illegal. What you do is illegal. You are a criminal. Your biological
and technological distinctiveness will be added to our own. You will
adapt to service us. Resistance is futile."

... it really does make me wonder if there *IS* an actual human being at
the other end, or not.


cya,
john

Then Amber Soun some hard shit also & managed 2 slid in some acid in there!!  It was Dope!!

The Back room!!  OK... this Dude opened... from Orangeage I  guess!!  Dope Dope Dope!!  OK.. Then DJ SNM spun next... Fuckin' A man... Bad Ass!!  He totally blew me away as he always does!!!  I mean... it's a rarity 2 see SNM spin these days & I felt lucky 2 catch him lastnight!!  YAY

OK... Kalamity Jane was on next... GOOD FUCKIN SHIT MAN!!!  I mean... I kept goin' in & out a few times when she was on... but I was in there aloooooooot of her set & man... the room was HOT!!  Literally!!!  I mean... the Huge ass crowd that the Tachno DJ built up who spun B4 ther Live PA Dudes totally flooded the room upstairs & it was HOT in there like a suana almost... Really!!!  But Kalamity Jane's set totally fucked me up as usual & she had the Break Beats goin' dropped some tribal house, I think I mighta heard a UK Hard house track or something in there!!  WOW!

Unfortunately... I wasn't able 2 stay 4 Samira's set!!!  But I know she kicked Monda ass when she spun as she always does!!!  YAY!!!

OK... it was a Family filled event last night!!  Oh MY Goodness man... there was so much Love lastnight!!  OK... yeah... & there was alota Ass Slapping, Ass Pinching, 3 People Freaking (I found myself sandwiched atleast 4 times lastnight), & I had this mondo freaking session w/ Angie Simpson as well!!  LoL

All in All in was a Dope Dope Dope night!!!  Oh MY GOsh man... I Love It!!  YAY... & I got a ride home from Eyore & Pen last night!!!  Love That Dude.... Love That Chica!

Thank U Code 4 a Mondo Groovy night!!!  Love U Code! <3  

I Love Friendster
--

Subject: [sfraves] Digital Mix: A Special BayFF Celebrating Illegal Art

* Digital Mix: A Special BayFF Celebrating Illegal Art

On July 25th the Electronic Frontier Foundation will host a night of music,
art, and conversation to celebrate digital culture.  Hosted at the Black
Box in downtown Oakland, this special BayFF will bring up-and-coming
artists of electronica, digital film, and illegal art together with leaders
from the cyber-rights movement.  Lawsuits and legislation have become the
weapons of choice for dealing with file-sharing and cultural recycling
("sampling"); come out and discover what all the hype is about. Between
laptop music, hip hop, and industrial performances, you will hear from
people who are fighting to protect new forms of expression and cultural
distribution from the attacks of the entertainment industry.  This is an
all-ages event.

Performers:
   ~ Kat5 <http://www.katfive.com>
   ~ Meanest Man Contest <http://www.weapon-shaped.com/mmc/>
   ~ Uprock <http://www.kelpandcircuits.com>
   ~ Mochipet <http://www.mochipet.com>
   ~ Freshblend <http://www.freshblend.com>

Speakers:
   ~ Fred von Lohmann (Electronic Frontier Foundation)
   ~ Glenn Otis Brown (Creative Commons)
   ~ Ray Beldner (Illegal Art)

Sponsored By:
   ~ XLR8R Magazine

Where:  Black Box at 1928 Telegraph Avenue
         Oakland, CA <http://blackboxoakland.com>
When:  Friday, July 25th, 8 p.m. - 2 a.m.
Cost: $5 suggested donation
All ages welcome
Easy BART access @ 19th St. Station in Oakland
Directions available here:
   <http://blackboxoakland.com/directions/directions.htm>
For more information please contact:
   katina@eff.org

technology which is pine. ;)

the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

Message-ID: <20030712034726.84450.qmail@web12303.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Fri, 11 Jul 2003 20:47:26 -0700 (PDT)
From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org, terry@saturn5.com, fable4our@hotmail.com
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] coolworld tacos [was: Re: [sfraves] paging dj seven

"Terry Estioko" wrote:

> Taco Bell analogy:

> C.I'm ordering 2 taco's: they come out butt-crappy. Abandon
> establishment, make own tacos.

Well, for thge most part, that's what I HAVE done wrt/ coolworld, though I
haven't sucessfully gotten so far as the "make own tacos" step.  I had my bad
experience...

(Yes, I DID, once, actually buy tickets to a coolworld party.  Hey, I was still
pretty new to town, didn't know that many ravers, and hadn't even first signed
on to SFRaves yet.  And I didn't, yet, know or heve experience with the
reputations of the crews that throw parties in the Bay Area.  So I never really
had the chance to be warned off about them at the time.  In fact, it was only
my second ever ATTEMPT at going to a rave in "the Bay Area".  I didn't actually
get to *GO* though.)

... and after getting fucked that once, I decided that they were a company that
would never see a penny from me again.  And this was WELL before I developed my
"small undergrounds over massives" preference.

The problem, though, is that I can't just abandon said establishment and
pretend they don't exist.  Because even *IF* I don't set foot in a coolworld
party ever again, their actions still affect me.

To continue your Taco Bell analogy:

Taco Bell not only serves crappy tacos; they serve notoriously and festeringly
bad tacos.  They don't take health precautions like refrigerateing their sour
cream, and washing and sanitizing their hands before handleing food.  They are
sloppy in handleing their poultry.  And they don't even allow their patrons to
inspect their food before eating it.  This leads to regular instances of food
poisoning at Taco Bell.  In some cases, said food poisoning has been fatal.

This leads the health department (Rightly or wrongly...  wrongly, IMO, but that
doesn't matter.) to conclude that not only Taco Bell tacos, but ALL tacos, and
indeed, all mexican food in general, is evil.  The health department therefore
recruits a pack of gun-toting thugs to rampage down Mission and Valencia
streets, and rough up and harrass the owners and patrons of the small and
independent taquerias where I *DO* get healthy and reliably good tacos all the
time.  This leads to some of these taquerias closeing down, and many of the
rest imposing tedious restrictions on the customers.  For instance, where I
could always bring candy bars as dessert before, to restraunts that didn't
include it on their menu, and I could bring my own hot sauce, to the ones that
didn't serve their food quite spicy enough; niether is allowed anymore.

Not only THAT, but the health department is doing their VERY best to prevent me
from making my own tacos as well...  To the point that, even though I was
planning to try a while back; Safeway, under pressure from the health
department's gun-toting thugs, has pulled taco shells off it's storeshelves,
forcing me to abort my attempt at making tacos of my own before I could even
get out of the store. 

So, despite the fact that I DID abandon Taco Bell, the fact that they serve
butt-crappy tacos (And sometimes send your order to another store, instead of
delivering it to you in the dining room where you ordered.) still AFFECTS me...
in multiple ways.

Now, I'm going to go downstairs, make myself some ramen noodles, and hide from
the bad-analogy police...  'Cuz I just took your ball, and ran with it, Forrest
Gump style, all the way out of the stadium.


cya,
john

protools, I know plenty of people who use it on a regular basis and would 
laugh hyserically if you asked them to show you their certification. most 
producers & engineers in the audio industry bearly have degrees it's not 
exactly an industry built on schooling.  a lot pick up more in a studio 
working then they do in school, and before you flame me. I did go to a 
school with a sound program, but they never made claims that you need 
certifcation to work and the teachers all still work in the industry.  a 
good school will teach you more then just protools.

From: Terry Estioko [mailto:terry@saturn5.com]

On Thu, 10 Jul 2003, John B. wrote:

> > Like Coolworld, its hard to hate them
>
> Eh... not really.  But...
>
>
> Yeah, I do gotta give them credit on that one.  Whoever they employ to
monitor
> and post to SFRaves is sure dedicated to his job.  > criticism, even in
threads that aren't specific to coolworld...  This guy's on the ball.

Read your own reply...Yep.

> ... it really does make me wonder if there *IS* an actual human being at
the
> other end, or not.

Yep, and Nope.

Depend's on what you're trying to do.

Taco Bell analogy:

A. I'm ordering 2 taco's: they come out butt-crappy.
 1. Complain to the cashier/drone, get an apology
 2. Complain to the manager/drone, get 2 replacement tacos

Result: Tacos are still crappy

B. I'm ordering 2 taco's: they come out butt-crappy.
 1. Complain to Customer Relations/drone, receive apology
 2. Also receive coupons for more crappy Taco Bell

Result: A few bucks richer, but tacos are still crappy

C.I'm ordering 2 taco's: they come out butt-crappy. Abandon
establishment, make own tacos.
 1. Figure out how to make good taco
 2. Make good taco, Invite friends
 3. Everyone experiences good taco (on a small scale)

Result: Good Tacos, Good Friends

The problem is...?

Granted, this is a simplistic solution, but <spin aside>, can you expect
massives to acknowledge and embrace harm-reduction with what's on their
public plate w/ current threatening legislation?

Tell 'em to take out Trans-fats while you're at it...or just work to
replace the tacos.

 -t

p.s. Sorry for the analogy, it's late, and I'm hungry =)

aka Kidloose (Shalion Productions), Rossi (Feel Good Entertainment),

http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D635
Northern CA Venue, 90 Min from SAC California, USA

Friday, July 11, 2003 ** LEFTLANE July 11TH, 2003 **

TWELVES AND LEFTLANE PRESENTS...Cherrywine Tour

Cherrywine (Butterfly of Digable Planets) - In the early '90's, Ishmael
"Butterfly" Butler was at the forefront of a new wave of urban music as
the founder and leader of Digable Planets. Along with fellow members Mary
Ann "Ladybug" Viera (aka Mecca) and Craig "Doodlebug" Irving (aka
Knowledge), they created music charged with classic jazz samples, hip hop
beats and politically greased lyrics. They released two definitive albums,
their platinum selling debut album Reachin' (a new refutation of time and
space) in 1993 and it's follow-up Blowout Comb in 1994, before disbanding
in 1996. They also won a Grammy in 1993 for best rap performance by a
group for their MTV-friendly single "Rebirth of Slick (Cool Like Dat')."
Plus special performances by: Larry's Lounge Lizards (Off the Wagon)
Addict Merchants feat. Orginal Headz and Storytellas. Located @ Elements
805 15th Street, SF.  $10-$12 21 + up 9pm-2am. LEFTLANE A Unique Urban
Experience Bring the soul of the underground to the stage,

http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar2/events/view?identifier=3D611
Sacramento California, USA

Friday, July 25, 2003 ** The Scrumfrom @ 1015 Folsom **

Euphoria Dreams and Spundae Presents: Origin @ 1015 Folsom Mainroom DJs:
The Scumfrog with opening set by Gianni (djgianni.com/spundae). Bassment
DJs: (TRANCE/HOUSE/NRG) Dead Dan (djdeaddan.com), Ehash
(euphoriadreams.com), and Teddy Rockspin (gruvindustries.com). Upstairs
VIP Lounge DJs: (HOUSE) DJ Elz (sister sf), Eladio (ddp/am), DJ Torque
(92.7 party), and Paul Hemming (zen city records). Frontroom DJ:
(HIP-HOP/R&B/CLUB FAVORITES) Rafael Fiero. The Scumfrog, an Amsterdam
native and New York City transplant, has evolved his sound by combining
the best from both sides of the Atlantic with a sophisticated blend of New
York dark and funky beats and sexy European sounds. His recent successes
include four no. 1 club hits; 2001's Ibiza anthem "We Love You",his remix
of George Michael's single "Freeek", the billboard dance smash "Love At
First Sight" by Kylie Minogue, and his re-conception of Dirty vegas' "Days
Go By".  His highlights have included collaboration with David Bowie on
Positiva, and DJ Gigs all over the world.

-------------------------------------------------
Administrative Notes
-------------------------------------------------

SFRaves serves the greater SF Bay Area, but reaches
beyond the local scene to all corners of the Terra Firma -
thanks to everyone whose support of and contribution to
the SFRAVES.org community - locally --> to both poles
---> to all points along the equator ---> as well as each
longitude and latitude perspective that makes this beautiful
place we know as Earth our home.

Please notify me regarding new events, event changes,
deprecated event information, or any other information
pertaining to events in the greater SF Bay Area and beyond.

I look forward to hearing from you @ karina@hyperreal.org

THE SFRaves.org Calendar is sent via email every week.

To subscribe to the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-subscribe@hyperreal.org

To remove your address from the list, send a message to:
sfraves-calendar-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org

Send mail to the following for info and FAQ for this list:
sfraves-calendar-info@hyperreal.org or
sfraves-calendar-faq@hyperreal.org

mancy), $
Faithfully yours,
-- Karina Powers
karina@hyperreal.org

---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] coolworld tacos [was: Re: [sfraves] paging dj seven

On Fri, 11 Jul 2003, John B. wrote:

> To continue your Taco Bell analogy:
>
> This leads the health department (Rightly or wrongly...  wrongly, IMO, but that
> doesn't matter.) to conclude that not only Taco Bell tacos, but ALL tacos, and
> indeed, all mexican food in general, is evil.

To place blame for the vilification of mexican food on a single promoter
is short-sighted. Clearly many of us on this list have been to a slew of
taquerias, and I'll bet many have seen lots of "jacked up shit" in many of
them thrown by the entire spectrum of promoters.

> The health department therefore
> recruits a pack of gun-toting thugs to rampage down Mission and Valencia
> streets, and rough up and harrass the owners and patrons of the small and
> independent taquerias where I *DO* get healthy and reliably good tacos all the
> time.  This leads to some of these taquerias closeing down, and many of the
> rest imposing tedious restrictions on the customers.  For instance, where I
> could always bring candy bars as dessert before, to restraunts that didn't
> include it on their menu, and I could bring my own hot sauce, to the ones that
> didn't serve their food quite spicy enough; niether is allowed anymore.

Not to bust your bubble or anything, but some of those, healthy and
reliable tacos are some of the most insane death traps I've ever seen.
The problems you are lamenting are not because the biggest, baddest, most
public taquerias are irresponsible fuck-ups, it's because they are the
most visible and easiest to blame.

I think your gun-toting and rampaging thugs retalition argument is
paranoic. Speaking for myself, I've pretty much been to a whole host of
very good, safe, and unbusted fiestas this year. IMHO, it has become
*easier* to throw a fiesta now than in the last few years. The scene is
considerably smaller, and segmented. The fiestas that I've seen that have
been getting the most heat are the ones which have been borderline public
nuisances and potentialy more dangerous than their massive counterparts.

> Not only THAT, but the health department is doing their VERY best to prevent me
> from making my own tacos as well...  To the point that, even though I was
> planning to try a while back; Safeway, under pressure from the health
> department's gun-toting thugs, has pulled taco shells off it's storeshelves,
> forcing me to abort my attempt at making tacos of my own before I could even
> get out of the store.

Safeway pulled what? No one's stopping you from making your own biggidy
baggidy bad-ass tacos. Taquerias are in full-effect in the bay area.

> Now, I'm going to go downstairs, make myself some ramen noodles, and hide from
> the bad-analogy police...  'Cuz I just took your ball, and ran with it, Forrest
> Gump style, all the way out of the stadium.

Run...Forrest....Run!

-terry

*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-
Cloud Factory Design Collective presents

                RE:FUSE

        July 12th, 2003

a fashion performance brought to you by the best underground designers...

*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-

Listless and lacklustered from a year of bulldozed war, unheard
protests, and insidious attacks on our freedoms?

Never fear!  The cfdc returns with a fashion performance fueled to
reinspire and refire the spirit.  Always ones to (b)uck the trends
and reject the status quo, re:fuse is our recommittment to live out
loud!  To re:fuse hopelessness, the 'security' of acquiescence, and
the tyranny of the normal ~ we raise our needles in the air!!!
Revel in the beauty of the underground, as the cfdc shakes your booty
and brain to pieces, re:fuses and revives you!

Be a part of the Burlesque renaissance! An old-school burly show with enough
for everyone, there is no other striptease production like the Original Fat
Bottom Revue anywhere in the world! Join Miss Demeanor and her big beautiful
dancers, including Mia More, Rudan Raunche, Pussy Flambe, Queen Justine, and
Suki Divine for a rocking good time. Tips are appreciated.
www.bigburlesque.com <http://www.bigburlesque.com/>

Doors open at 7:30pm

Music provided all night long (for you to shake your booty!)

Joe Rice (Circuit Breaker)
AudioEl (Cybrid)
DJ Enki (Future Primitive Sound)
Fred Funk (Brass Tax)
Stonie (Cloud Factory)

Fashion show starts at 8:00pm

Dancing and grooving until 2am

Presale tickets are $10 and available online at Ticketweb
http://ticketweb.com/user/?region=sfbay&query=detail&event=443347

http://www.cfdesign.net/

*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-*-

StudioZ
314 11th Street @ Folsom, San Francisco
415.252.7666 www.StudioZ.tv
21+ w/ID

>Taco Bell analogy:
>
>A. I'm ordering 2 taco's: they come out butt-crappy.
>  1. Complain to the cashier/drone, get an apology
>  2. Complain to the manager/drone, get 2 replacement tacos
>
>Result: Tacos are still crappy
>
>B. I'm ordering 2 taco's: they come out butt-crappy.
>  1. Complain to Customer Relations/drone, receive apology
>  2. Also receive coupons for more crappy Taco Bell
>
>Result: A few bucks richer, but tacos are still crappy
>
>C.I'm ordering 2 taco's: they come out butt-crappy. Abandon
>establishment, make own tacos.
>  1. Figure out how to make good taco
>  2. Make good taco, Invite friends
>  3. Everyone experiences good taco (on a small scale)
>
>Result: Good Tacos, Good Friends
>
>The problem is...?
>
>Granted, this is a simplistic solution, but <spin aside>, can you expect
>massives to acknowledge and embrace harm-reduction with what's on their
>public plate w/ current threatening legislation?
>
>Tell 'em to take out Trans-fats while you're at it...or just work to
>replace the tacos.

Warren aka SparcoTrip, why to you keep harassing both sfraves and sacraves with you nonsensical babling?
 
And why on earth would you call "scooter" a real 'hardcore' DJ?  If you are refering to scooter the producers from Hamburg, THEY make trance music, specifically a type of kiddy nu-nrg that was around back in the day made specifically to target young audiences and generate chart numbers.  There is nothing 'hardcore' about them whatsoever, they make cheese for children.  A number of other artists (ex: Hardfloor, Tom Wax, Michael Kohlbecker, Jam & Spoon aka Tokyo Ghetto Pussy, DJ Hooligan, etc) during the time did the same thing as a JOKE.  This repackaging of standard issue frankfurt nu nrg for children first took place back in 92 and by 94 the joke was over for everybody but scooter.  Why they have continued to do the same exact thing for the last 10 years is totally mind bogling and certainly shows they are worthy of the lamest act in EDM award.  
 
I guess the fact that there are still people out there that want to hear that crap, and even worse, don't even know the history of that crap or which genre their crap is, proves that while they certainly have no artistic integrity to speak of, they made the right decision for their wallets.  And I wont even get into how every record they ever made is a KLF ripoff in some way or another....
 
But my point being... scooter is trance...   so 1) please stop cross posting to sfraves and bugging them with your nonsense, and 2) if you are going to bug everybody with your nonsense, at least know what you are talking about before you do it....
 
[Don't] keep it wet & hard.... [you don't need to be breeding]
p a t

Subject: [sfraves] Re: (NRR) help elect a President who is against the Drug War

Speaking of labels and name calling, it might be helpful to consider
propaganda analysis when playing word games and throwing flames. By
defining people through various names, labels and stereotypes, the game
begins. It is interesting to observe the depth of opinions conveyed, and
the point in which manipulation of people's ideas, definitions of ideals
and people change through one's perception and bias. Presumption versus
fact can have a huge impact on how ideas are received and messages
are conveyed.  To note, this applies to many situations, whether it be
political or any other subject that is emotionally charged...see

propaganda: case study
Propaganda Techniques: Word Games
Name Calling

"...The name-calling technique links a person, or idea, to a negative
symbol. The propagandist who uses this technique hopes that the audience
will reject the person or the idea on the basis of the negative symbol,
instead of looking at the available evidence..."

-- Institute for Propaganda Analysis, 1938
http://carmen.artsci.washington.edu/propaganda/cites.htm#ipa

Psychological:

"...Name-Calling is a Disappointing Substitute for Real Criticism..."

-- Jensen, Arthur R. (2000) Name-Calling is a Disappointing Substitute for
Real Criticism, Psycoloquy: 11,#9 Intelligence G Factor (25)
http://psycprints.ecs.soton.ac.uk/archive/00000009/

Labels:

"...Think about the term "bitch", it used to be an insult toward women yet
today many women call themselves this name with pride. It was taken over
by the feminist movement almost a decade ago and redefined to mean "strong
woman who stands up for herself without apology..."

Political Propaganda:

"...List of Negative words and phrases that GOP candidates were told to
use when speaking about their opponents..."' -- cited from "Newt's
Name-Calling Words"

Historical:

Propaganda: Name-calling - Lesson Plan (University of Michigan)

redefined: (NASPCenter)

"...Unfortunately, many adults also engage in name-calling, having never
learned more appropriate means of expressing anger and displeasure; we
have only to view the evening news to see the consequences often violent
death...

...Name-calling is a means of expressing displeasure/disapproval of
others. Its aim is to hurt the other person, at least verbally, or
facilitate the other person's getting into trouble as he/she retaliates in
kind. This kind of retaliation firmly cements into place the reinforcing
consequences; thus, name-calling begets name-calling, resolves no
problems, and often leads to accelerated destructive behaviors..."

..In respects to the truth and reality:

The flaws of word games: Though this strategy of persuasion is effective,
it is flawed as a method for discovering or evaluating the truth; and it
is highly prejudicial and ripe for generating gross misrepresentation and
wrongful perceptions.

List of Flaws

* Oversimplification. Does the name capture the full essence of what the
person or idea represents?
* Overly broad classification and errant associations. The use of certain
labels tend to lump ideas together that have substantive differences.
* False classification. Not all labels are correctly applied. In fact,
negative labels, used in reference to various organizations by their
opponents, are particularly suspect--such is the case with the critics who
continue to use labels to communicate their point.
* Presumptive judgements. Not all labeling comes from generally accepted
sources
--particularly with regards to negative labeling. The questions may well
be asked, "who are the critics of the idea being criticized?" "Who are
they to decide who/what is [insert label here] and who/what is not? Who
are they to alter the dictionary definitions of certain terms, and stand
in judgement of another idea?"
* Mis-connotation. Because certain labels have diverse meanings, there is
the potential for the wrong meaning to be applied, and misinterpretations
to occur.


Paix,

Karina

******************>karina@hyperreal.org<**********************

much in despairing of life as in hoping for another life
& in eluding the implacable grandeur of this life.
-- Albert Camus -- *******************************************

On Mon, 7 Jul 2003, Sean Griffith wrote:

>
> I think you still missed -his- point entirely.
>
> 'Left' and 'Right' are artificial labels created by what has developed
> itself into a two-party system. Most of us with half a brain don't
> identify ourselves as 'lefties' or 'right-wingers'.
>
> It is this left/right, democrat/republican, liberal/conservative
> distinction that causes us so much trouble and determines why we have
> almost no choice at the ballot every year. It is why voting 'independent'
> seems so useless and pointless to people.
>
> We've come to group not just our politicians, but the entirety of our
> society, into two camps. Human beings are not so easily categorized. If we
> continue to categorize ourselves, however, we will fit more snugly into
> the moulds we create for ourselves. And that way leads a lack of
> individual initiative.
>
> Why develop your own opinions when they can be determined by whether your
> 'left' or 'right'?
>
> TRH
>

OK... I respect like girls who go w/ their DJ boyfriends 2 gigs & stuff yeah... but man... I dunno... be happy your bf is spinning or something!!!  There was this girl like bein this Mondo wall flower sitting behind the decks of standing in from of the speaker jus' i dunno... eating her fuckin' fingernails!!  I mean... unless that DJ was like  babysitting that girl or something... it's kind apathetic 2 watch your bf spin & not do nothing!!!

Anywaze... we went in2 the main room & there was this 2X4 goin' on w/ these DJs spining like Tech House & stuff!  It was interesting!!  I liked it!!  It was fun!

So like yeah... I went 2 the outdoor area & like right away.... I saw fuckin' Mr Breakbeats himself, CANTOS!!!  Oh MY Goodness man... it was So Awesome seeing him!!!  

I also ran in2 His Highness!!! Weeeeeeeeee... it was so Dope seeing him!!!  Oh My Goodness... it's like totally rare I get 2 C this CAt.. so we had alota stuff 2 talk about!!!  Grrrrrr... unfortunately... I won't be able 2 make it 2 his SunDance party This Sunday & man.. the line up looks fuckin' Awesome man!!!  But it was Dope kickin' it w/ Paul again!!! YAAAAAAY!!

So DFly & Amber got on the decks & man... their set was so trippy!!!  I mean... they like totally started out w/ this tribal house kinda stuff... I think I heard some Electro thrown in there.... then they totally went full on in2 som Breakbeats, Trance, Acid, a lil' Techno here & there, man... it was Fuckin' Sick!!!  LoL!!  I Loved it!!!  I was pretty much dancing the whole time during their 2X4 set!!!  It was so Awesome!!!

So the party itself was pretty ummmmmm.... intimate I guess U could say!!  It wasn't a full house 2 like what that venue coulda been, but it was a Groovy crowd!!

It was a really fun time!!!

> there... as soon as we walked in... we were in the
> Jungle Room already!!  This DJ was Groovy... but I
> dunno... his whole swet it seem like was mainly all
> like Raga Jungle & Tech Step & it was kinda hard 2
> get my Groove on... but he was good!!  BUt Ooooh My
> Goodness... OK... I respect like girls who go w/
> their DJ boyfriends 2 gigs & stuff yeah... but
> man... I dunno... be happy your bf is spinning or
> something!!!  There was this girl like bein this
> Mondo wall flower sitting behind the decks of
> standing in from of the speaker jus' i dunno...
> eating her fuckin' fingernails!!  I mean... unless
> that DJ was like  babysitting that girl or
> something... it's kind apathetic 2 watch your bf
> spin & not do nothing!!!
> 
> Anywaze... we went in2 the main room & there was
> this 2X4 goin' on w/ these DJs spining like Tech
> House & stuff!  It was interesting!!  I liked it!! 
> It was fun!
> 
> So like yeah... I went 2 the outdoor area & like
> right away.... I saw fuckin' Mr Breakbeats himself,
> CANTOS!!!  Oh MY Goodness man... it was So Awesome
> seeing him!!!  
> 
> I also ran in2 His Highness!!! Weeeeeeeeee... it was
> so Dope seeing him!!!  Oh My Goodness... it's like
> totally rare I get 2 C this CAt.. so we had alota
> stuff 2 talk about!!!  Grrrrrr... unfortunately... I
> won't be able 2 make it 2 his SunDance party This
> Sunday & man.. the line up looks fuckin' Awesome
> man!!!  But it was Dope kickin' it w/ Paul again!!!
> YAAAAAAY!!
> 
> So DFly & Amber got on the decks & man... their set
> was so trippy!!!  I mean... they like totally
> started out w/ this tribal house kinda stuff... I
> think I heard some Electro thrown in there.... then
> they totally went full on in2 som Breakbeats,
> Trance, Acid, a lil' Techno here & there, man... it
> was Fuckin' Sick!!!  LoL!!  I Loved it!!!  I was
> pretty much dancing the whole time during their 2X4
> set!!!  It was so Awesome!!!
> 
> So the party itself was pretty ummmmmm.... intimate
> I guess U could say!!  It wasn't a full house 2 like
> what that venue coulda been, but it was a Groovy
> crowd!!
> 
> It was a really fun time!!!  
> 
> Take Care,
> Peace-> O§bY {8O)

other such goodies.

and Cheesesteaks, these two fellas are gonna rock your droors to the floor
on four turntables.

also one of the most hardcore of DC Junglists. He brings ze danger with
lots of nasty breaks and, of course, ze dubs.

tonight. The one and only Nature will be rollin thru tonight to drop
choons, plus whomever else is around. boh!

follow the direct ones below:

On Mon, 14 Jul 2003 kdb@technolounge.org wrote:~
-&e->
-&e->DJ T-1000..   D-Jax, Pure Sonik, Tresor
-&e->
-&e->One of the forefathers of Detroit's techno scene his 1987 debut on
-&e->the "Fast Forward" radio program fueled the fledgling Detroit techno
-&e->scene. His pure minimal techno sound has won him international
-&e->acclaim and a place in Detroit's Historical Museum Exhibit, Techno:
-&e->Detroit's Gift to the World. We are very fortunate to have this
-&e->legend ignite our decks for you.

You forgot to mention that he's way more than just a DJ/producer.

Most of the comic book stuff here is his work:
http://www.djax.nl/
http://www.capsite.net/grafix/aoldham/aoldham.htm

Anyway, along with US label UR (undergroundresistance, detroit... who
brought a super minimal criminal activist vibe), t-1000 aka alan oldham
has brought a lot of techno's most creative visual imagery and concepts to
the world (countless comic style stuff for djax, the logo designs for
transmat and kms, list goes on).  AND he fuckin shreds as a dancefloor DJ,
producer of some of the genres banginest tracks and historically as a
radio DJ with a show going back to 1987.

Take this opportunity to see the man throw down.  Essential listening for
anybody interested in techno...

andyw

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 83605 invoked from network); 14 Jul 2003 20:24:54 -0000
Message-ID: <20030714202452.35580.qmail@web40507.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 14 Jul 2003 13:24:52 -0700 (PDT)
From: Geri Dahl <eeelips@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="0-1402221309-1058214292=:33881"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] movies nrr

--0-1402221309-1058214292=:33881
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

i saw a movie that i really wanted to see, but forgot about, and then all of a sudden, POOF!, there it was, and i went, "woah, i forgot about that one." and i thought i wouldn't be able to watch it, 
thought, "nevermind", but then i watched it, and it was really good. so, scratch that one off, huh? now what? sometimes, 
they are just too loud these days,(the movie houses, that is) and also, why sit still for a movie when there is so much to do and see? if you have a date, and then on your way to the date, you see 
someone else that you want to go on a date with, do you think you should just go home? i think in most cases, the answer to that question is probably, "yes". what does that have to do with films? well, 
you should always question yourself about why you want to go to that movie. i mean, one show i want to see, i was thinking i might just want to see the clothes, and couldn't i just pick up a magazine or, uh, 
do my laundry for once in my life? no. why should i wash my clothes when i can go see some clean clothes on screen, dump the other clothes, and pick up more later? see what i mean? there are just too many choices sometimes, but always, well, i was about to say,  always a good time 
to be had, but recently i heard on the radio that you can't plan a good time. good times just happen or don't. i guess that is why you aren't having fun sometimes. i mean, if you are planning on having fun, 
then you must have something in mind, and what happens is never an exact replica of what you have in mind. there is a big difference between internal thoughts and external thingies. if you draw a picture, you 
will know what i mean. there are some things that are kind of predictable though. like, maybe your drawing is really going to suck ass, and you knew it before you picked up the pen, however, you didn't really know how badly it would suck ass until you saw the finished product, and then, well, that was no fun at all, was it? :)

I'll third this comment.

Alan is a top notch dj, producer, artist, and overall great guy.

We had Alan come out to the first ever trust outdoor event in Wisconsin in
1994.  Due to some complications with our choice of speakers, and the
nighbor 4 miles away complaining about their walls viberating, we had to
drop the volume significantly to keep the event going.

Luckily Alan ramped up the energy even with the stacks at 1/4 volume, and
everyone went away happy.

Looking forward to seeing/hearing him again.

-e-

For some reason, the Taco Bell by my house makes really good tacos, other Taco Bells can suck, but this one is great! It's because of the nice ladies that work there.
 I guess I come from a different perspective, since I was a Detroit Club Kid long before I was a Raver, and the First and only Massive I have been to was Planet New Year 2003, and I was there as part of a friend's crew, but I had a good time, and so did another member of the crew who is so hard core he LIVES in an underground venue, (it was also his first massive) Anyway, this same friend is performing at Cyberfest, and it is a great opportunity for him, I just got off the phone with him discussing details, I am definately going to be on the crew again, Cyberfest is going to help him make a lot of headway into making a living from his art and 20,000 peole who might never see him perform  get to see him. So, I can't wholy diss massives myself. I also met my first honest to god English Trancer this weekend and was impressed, it seems raving is a lot more mainstream over there and has led to social change ... just something to consider. Not saying that fillet minjon isnt better, but
 hamburger has its place.  ( it's a metaphor, so don't get mad if your a veggie, ( I keep trying to go veggie myself ) I just couldn't think of a better one cause I am a little fried.)

the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

Message-Id: <5.2.1.1.2.20030714185229.02bb9a90@mail.speakeasy.net>
X-Sender: apollo@mail.speakeasy.net

Date: Mon, 14 Jul 2003 19:09:27 -0700

From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_3644384==.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Club Six and Doc Martin

--=====================_3644384==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

As many of you may know, Leslie Ayres, former moderator of this list and 
SFLNC activist, is back from Thailand -- permanently, this time.  So Joey 
and I took her out for a night of dancing at Club 6 last Saturday.

I pretty much tend to avoid clubs these days.  I've come to detest security 
pat downs and surveillance so I keep most of my dancing in the friendly 
underground -- with the exception of Club 6.

Club 6 is to my mind the closest thing to an underground party "above" 
ground.  The venue has the feel of a warehouse downstairs, sweat and 
all.  And we sweated Saturday night.  The place was packed for the Doc's 
4-hour set and we danced almost continuously.  When a DJ has four hours on 
the tables he/she can really reveal the musical soul, and Doc Martin's set 
was amazingly eclectic and beautifully complex.  He threw down some of his 
remixes, moved to banging, rockin' house, then there was some very trippy 
acid stuff, and even some soulful, disco-flavored house.  Reminded me of 
those early parties when Doc was based in San Francisco.

When we left around four we all looked like we had been in a torrential 
downpour -- just soaking wet.  And I noticed my pants were covered in 
dirt.  What one used to call raver dirt.  So satisfying, it was.  Down and 
dirty at Club 6.  Props to the owner of that venue -- hope they can 
maintain the freedom and the vibe.

They could, however, purchase a few more fans:)

Love,

Apollo

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie
