Subject: [sfraves] Paradigm Shift:  Major Props!!!

--=====================_19396615==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Abundant praise to Sean, Chel-c and all of the DEF crew for throwing a 
totally awesome rave last night -- yes, "rave" in the very best meaning of 
the term.  Paradigm Shift was characterized by unselfish respect and care 
for guests;  a loving and peaceful vibe;  and a the growing reemergence of 
unity I have been feeling in the new underground revival in the Bay.

Experience has shown me time and again that a party is the reflection of 
the souls of the party givers.  DEF is a collection of lovely souls and it 
showed at this event.  Hospitality was in full effect with free fruit, 
water, and excellent vegan food.  Much care was given to details (make or 
break a party).  The decorations were very creative and playful.  Loved the 
altar with the dancing Furby, I guess it was, on top.  At first I thought I 
was having some "flashback" when I saw what looked like a small creature 
moving about:)

Music was excellent with some moving techno 2X4s.  Loved Forest Green vs 
Andy W.  Andy, as usual, was inventive and entertaining with skillful 
surprises on the decks.

Most impressive to me, however, was the passion for music and dance that 
motivates parties like Paradigm Shift.   If there is a shift here, and I 
believe there is, it is a movement back to throwing raves for the love of 
it all.  One is lucky to break even these days doing an event with high 
production values coupled with generosity towards guests.  The risks 
financially and otherwise seem to grow.  Fortunately -- and we should all 
be thankful for this -- there are those good promoters willing to embrace 
these challenges and give back to the community.

It gives me great joy, therefore, to welcome DEF to the mix.  The DIY 
spirit is far from dead with fresh blood like Sean and his crew in our 
community.  There is rebirth, reinvention, and regeneration of our 
underground "scene" going down right now, and the DEF crew is certainly a 
part of this paradigm shift.

Much love,

Apollo

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U  
--=====================_19396615==.ALT--



From sfraves-return-104001-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Jul 21 02:06:37 2003

Subject: [sfraves] (3): A philosophical and theoretical framework of a scientific school
 or discipline within which theories, laws, and generalizations and the
 experiments performed in support of them are formulated 


Late Latin paradigma, from Greek paradeigma, from paradeiknynai to show
side by side, from para- + deiknynai to show.

Recognize. Those of you hay00g production krewes trying to capture that
'something' that you can never quite get to come through at your
parties... you should have been at Paradigm Shift taking notes.

To say the aboveground scene is missing something -- that's not quite
right. They're operating within the wrong paradigm, and it shows.

I've had the pleasure of attending a number of very good parties in the
last few months. I've been discovering psychedelic trance, grooving to
d&b, and ... well. We won't mention that brief stint of happycore. I'm
sure you all understand. Everyone has their embarrassing moments. ;)

It was nice to see that good ole techno could show me the way once again.

There's something about techno. I dunno what it is, but it seems like
every time I go to a party like this (the last one was Mindcontrol,
which also god mad props) I get this really great oldschool vibe -- a
feeling of energy in the air; something very positive and powerful you
just don't normally get, no matter how good the music is.

Massive props to all the DJs (including... was it Chris Jackson who was
just tearing it up at about 5-5:30 in the morning? And AndyW/Forest Green
just before that? Who got some people who were dancing all night to jump
right back to their feet and bust out all over again?), Sean and Chelc,
and everybody else who made that ... okay, I'll say it: /RAVE/ happen.

And now I'm going back to sleep.

"History is hard to know, because of all the hired bullshit, but even
without being sure of 'history' it seems entirely reasonable to think that
every now and then the energy of a whole generation comes to a head in a
long fine flash, for reasons that nobody really understands at the time --
and which never explain, in retrospect, what actually happened." - Dr. HST

Sean

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] "Friendster" for mp3s???

Sean --  I think we were talking about this the other month at that show
at the GGP Bandshell (i was on rollerblades).

<braindump>

Specifically, because of the betamax ruling being applied as case law
in other cases (or having the potential of being applied), it is basically
"ok" to share songs between friends. So for example the mixtape you make for
your friend(s) is ok as "fair use copying." Also similarly covered, I believe,
is educational and classroom fair-use copying. So the question is whether this
concept can be legally extended to degrees-of-separation networks like 
friendster where one is not broadcasting or sharing broadly, but rather,
sharing among "friends."

Of course, there have been legal decisions in the vicinity of this issue
which need to be watched closely, eg.:
http://news.com.com/2100-1025-1022462.html?part=dht&tag=ntop

Moving on to the tangibles of software: there already exists a project
called "Waste" which can easily form the basis of an encrypted, file sharing
network. Of course, I have a copy from before the time it got pulled. And
given its GPL status, I feel that I am legally within my rights to use and 
modify this software.

(For more info on "waste" and the surrounding controversy:
  http://news.com.com/2100-1032-1011585.html
  http://news.com.com/2100-1032-1012833.html
  http://news.com.com/2100-1032-1020206.html
)

One of the aspects of "waste" is that it is designed for small-scale sharing. 
It would be quite inefficient for large-scale sharing. But this could actually
be a benefit, since one could say "the engineers designed the code 
specifically for fair use copying, and not broadcasting." See it doesn't 
scale, just like friendster!

We should setup a "waste" network amongs us friends and start playing with it,
in our infinite spare time. In fact, some might say that this is what NPM is
working on nowadays. I wish I could find a paying job doing this though.

My main design issue right now is whether such a filesharing network would
"piggyback" as a separate but linked site along side friendster, versus
just being a standalone site with an attached encrypted filesharing backend.
(The foolioz at Frienster.com used to have port 3306 open for MYSQL access. 
That woulda been the easiest. No, I never tried to mysqldump their database, 
or at least I won't admit to hacking in public. My warning to you, though,
is be careful what you stick in frienster -- unless friendster has firmed up 
their shoddy security, I can't imagine a dedicated hacker not being able to
break into their site with ease in less than 24 hours of work.)

Another legal pondering: can the concept of "friendster file sharing" be 
extended to arbitrary "affinity networks"... that is, the group of "friends" 
comes together simply because they all listenend to the same song, or like the 
same group, or ... (an "unintentional community"). Imagine if Microsoft built
a friendster like network into windows media player, for example: you could 
get together and chat with whoever is currently listening to that same song,
or join in with people who like the same band, or ....

I'd imagine that legal challenges to "affinity file sharing" would equate
it to "broadcasting." The cool thing about a "friendster file sharing" network
is that you have demonstrated a specific intent-of-friendship with another 
user, at least at the level that one is willing to request/confirm/accept each 
"friend" like friendster does currently.

Babble babble babble.... this is a subject of some excitement for me.

PS: also relevant is the concept of "scale free networks"
http://www.computerworld.com/networkingtopics/networking/story/0%2c10801%2c75539%2c00.html
ponder this next time frienster.com is down -- it is theoretically impossible 
for frienster not to be down most of the time. A "frienster killer" would be 
quite easy to implement, IMHO. And it would have good uptime because it would 
use federated databases and/or reside in it's own failure-resistant, 
distributed, p2p network implementation.

</braindump>

Sean Casey wrote:
> So I was thinking it'd be kind of cool to have a secure peer-to-peer
> filesharing service for linking groups of friends together.
> 
> It'd need a layer of encryption on every bit of the service. To
> browse it, use it, eavesdrop on it, or even know what kind of
> service is throwing around the encrypted packets, one would require
> a key. That would be as simple as having a service admin, or perhaps
> even a voting majority (pgp can do this) create you an access key.
> One could even have an option of keeping the files encrypted on a
> drive, and using a decryption driver to make them available to mp3
> players on your box.
> 
> It'd be nice in many ways. People with similar interests would
> naturally be able to help each other out more. It'd make it pretty
> reasonable to advertise files without advertising them to the world.
> 
> It would utterly foil the RIAA.
> 
> Anyone know of anything like this? Or heard of it being developed?
> 
> Sean
> 
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
> 
>

From sfraves-return-104005-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Jul 21 07:21:51 2003

From: DeezzerRec@aol.com
Message-ID: <f.15d4ddd8.2c4cee87@aol.com>
Date: Mon, 21 Jul 2003 03:21:43 EDT
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="part1_f.15d4ddd8.2c4cee87_boundary"
X-Mailer: 8.0 for Windows sub 6011
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] What difference does it make? (Art of Live PA)

--part1_f.15d4ddd8.2c4cee87_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Ladies and gentlemen, I'm throwing my hat in to the electronic trance music.  
Seems no promoter is interested to support this bay area silicon valley 
producer. I've fought long and hard, the good lord (and you promoters) knows how 
much $ i've been spilling to try to make a difference..

all this time i've been trying to show people how live pa can be done without 
a dat or tape.  i've always believed our genre was headed to a death because 
there isn't an accurate representation of our music.  other genres bring out 
the gear that made the music, but electronic music brings out only djs. i wish 
someone would've at least check into what i was doing and give it a chance at 
their venue.  but they've all ignored it.. 

So now i will tell you how live pa can be done so that maybe some DJ out 
there thats in the circuit of getting booked can do it. it's simple, and will 
mesmerize your crowd.

I am publishing this over the net only to the sfraves list, because we are 
silicon valley, where innovation happens.

The Ideal Electronic Live PA...

All must devices must have midi
1. you must have a drum machine. I use the tr 909
program each pattern, to know where they are, memorize what makes the rolls, 
add lots of verity.
2. you must have a sampler. program your favorite samples
3 program a synth that has an internal sequencer such as the korg ea1
4. have a secondary drum machine for layered drum sounds such as another 
sampler or a tr808 with effects connected.
5. maybe have your laptop running cubase sx, or reason.
6. connect all devices making all timecode external except the main drum 
machine internal, changing appropriate midi channel
7. when you press "start" on your drum machine, all devices will sound off 
and should be in sync. 
8. all will play into the mixer. now you must control the mixer. and 
different elements of each device.
9. you have yourself a synth, this synth is your favorite synth, it's like 
your guitar synth, and you jam on this synth and show the crowd that you and 
this synth are one. and your crowd will love you.
10. your act is a combination of known patterns, knowing when to switch off 
devices or changing sequence within the devices, vocoders on and off connected 
to your favorite synth. (my favoirte synth i've been using is the nord lead)

for a sample of all of this in action, you must have broadband, click here:
<A HREF="http://www.reflectnow.com/media/Reflector_Agenda.wmv">http://www.reflectnow.com/media/Reflector_Agenda.wmv</A>


there you have it...this is as real as it gets, and if only more people was 
exposed to this maybe we could've started something, maybe we would've been 
more respected and represented for electronic music as supposed to being 
followers of europe. they look down on us for not having culture, yet they are all 
using our computers. yes we've not been around as long as europe, but fuck that 
we are the capital technology hub of the world, and innovators of the fucking 
tv, computer, radio, and everything that makes entertainment happen. YES 
SILICON VALLEY AND YOU ALL LIVE HERE!!!!! dont you ever forget it.  all of us are in 
this sprit of technology...
So good luck to the scene... It was fun...

Dominic Son aka Reflector
Reflect Records
<A HREF="www.reflectnow.com">www.reflectnow.com</A>

""The Sounds that come out of a synthesizer provokes my soul in inexplicable 
mysterious ways and for this reason I must devote a big part of my life to 
electronic music." 

Broadband Archieve Reflector Live PA Video & Audio Clips found here: <A HREF="http://www.reflectnow.com/audio/index.html">
http://www.reflectnow.com/audio/index.html</A>

"Don't start the party without us!" Visit eParty Unlimited's new site: <A HREF="http://www.epartyunlimited.com">
http://www.epartyunlimited.com</A>

--part1_f.15d4ddd8.2c4cee87_boundary--

Message-ID: <20030721085348.10461.qmail@web80606.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 21 Jul 2003 01:53:48 -0700 (PDT)
From: Giles Bowkett <giles_bowkett@yahoo.com>
To: DeezzerRec@aol.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <f.15d4ddd8.2c4cee87@aol.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] What difference does it make? (Art of Live PA)

--- DeezzerRec@aol.com wrote:
> i've always believed our genre was
> headed to a death because 
> there isn't an accurate representation of our music.
>  other genres bring out 
> the gear that made the music, but electronic music
> brings out only djs.

actually this is part disagreement part tangent.

ready?

my theory is this: electronic music inherits
traditions of composition and improvisation. producing
is all about composition. DJing is all about
improvisation. there's a core musicality required for
both roles, but being able to make the right choices
in a prepared way (composition) and in a spontaneous
way (improv) are totally different abilities.

live PAs have always seemed to me rather odd because
even tho I like the old-school jam session as much as
anyone the truth is that the technology involved in
making this music often tends to be persnickety and
particular. fine-tuning it in the midst of a sweaty
club or a full moon renegade often looks to me like
trying to crack a safe in the middle of an orgy --
there's a lot going on, and most of it detracts from
your ability to concentrate.

besides, even if you can get unique sounds that way,
doesn't it seem like the crowd deserves more of your
energy than that? after all, 303 fanatics aside, it's
not actually about the machinery...

[europe]
> they look down on us for not
> having culture, yet they are all 
> using our computers. yes we've not been around as
> long as europe, but fuck that 
> we are the capital technology hub of the world, and
> innovators of the fucking 
> tv, computer, radio, and everything that makes
> entertainment happen. YES 
> SILICON VALLEY AND YOU ALL LIVE HERE!!!!! dont you
> ever forget it.  all of us are in 
> this sprit of technology...

dude, chill. radio was invented in Italy.

and techno was invented in America.


Giles

-----Original Message-----
From: Apollo [mailto:apollo@speakeasy.org]
Sent: Sunday, July 20, 2003 6:33 PM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] Paradigm Shift: Major Props!!!


Abundant praise to Sean, Chel-c and all of the DEF crew for throwing a
totally awesome rave last night -- yes, "rave" in the very best meaning of
the term.  Paradigm Shift was characterized by unselfish respect and care
for guests;  a loving and peaceful vibe;  and a the growing reemergence of
unity I have been feeling in the new underground revival in the Bay.

Experience has shown me time and again that a party is the reflection of
the souls of the party givers.  DEF is a collection of lovely souls and it
showed at this event.  Hospitality was in full effect with free fruit,
water, and excellent vegan food.  Much care was given to details (make or
break a party).  The decorations were very creative and playful.  Loved the
altar with the dancing Furby, I guess it was, on top.  At first I thought I
was having some "flashback" when I saw what looked like a small creature
moving about:)

Music was excellent with some moving techno 2X4s.  Loved Forest Green vs
Andy W.  Andy, as usual, was inventive and entertaining with skillful
surprises on the decks.

Most impressive to me, however, was the passion for music and dance that
motivates parties like Paradigm Shift.   If there is a shift here, and I
believe there is, it is a movement back to throwing raves for the love of
it all.  One is lucky to break even these days doing an event with high
production values coupled with generosity towards guests.  The risks
financially and otherwise seem to grow.  Fortunately -- and we should all
be thankful for this -- there are those good promoters willing to embrace
these challenges and give back to the community.

It gives me great joy, therefore, to welcome DEF to the mix.  The DIY
spirit is far from dead with fresh blood like Sean and his crew in our
community.  There is rebirth, reinvention, and regeneration of our
underground "scene" going down right now, and the DEF crew is certainly a
part of this paradigm shift.

Much love,

Apollo

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U

Subject: [sfraves] How to DJ right

Yo, I picked up a pretty good book the other day 
"How to DJ right - the art and science of playing records".  
A good book I would recommend to the beginner or novice.  
It includes the basics and then into some technical aspects of mixing.  It also includes cute illustrations, quotes from your favorite DJs, well written, lots of details.  Its not a hard back, but sturdy construction, cost me 15 bucks.
Not a bad read , pick it up.

Jon

Date: Mon, 21 Jul 2003 10:40:39 -0700

Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <Law10-F61lrCv3wBzpk000257d3@hotmail.com>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] What difference does it make? (Art of Live PA)

i've been following your posts over the past several months.  i've even 
taken the time to check out your site and listen to your sounds clips and 
view your video clips.

its obvious that you are passionate about what you are doing.  i can also 
see that you want to get out and show your stuff.  and i think that's 
awesome.

i just think you need to start taking some new avenues in promoting yourself 
and producing your material.  continuing to post here whining for people to 
book you isn't going to help much.  have you tried shopping your stuff 
around as a demo cd?  do you have promotional materials that are better 
designed than your website (which i'm sorry, it looks really amateur).  have 
you tried to get your tracks pressed on vinyl?  if so, have you actively 
pushed that material?  have you taken active steps in getting involved with 
local crews and helped throw parties?  have you tried to throw your own 
party?  have you tried to team up with other local producers and 
collaborated so that you can combine your energies in promoting yourselves?

just a few ramblings from me.  i'm an aspiring dj and if all i did was sit 
here and send emails in hopes of getting a booking....then i'd be going 
nowhere.  hit the streets, make connections, and pimp yourself out like a 
cheap hooker.




-------------
< Brandon / DJ Bam >

DJ Bam - serving breaks and beats
http://www.invibe.com/bam

Download the new mix online!

>From: Chris Jackson <resourcemusic_usa@yahoo.com>

From: Giles Bowkett <giles_bowkett@yahoo.com>
To: Captain Scarlet <slipstream341@yahoo.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <000701c34faa$d4367840$683fa143@yahshipseki>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] How to DJ right

"how to dj right" is great, it's like one of those
classic late-90s Andy W rants that make you realize
playing records IS the meaning of life. if you've been
spinning a while you won't find any new information,
except perhaps in the turntablist section, but it's
still worth reading.

my favorite quote in there is the bit where fatboy
slim describes the key to finding good samples:

"I look for hair styles and beards on a band. If
they've got long hair and beards, they're likely to
make better records. Especially those big seventies
bands with eight of them in -- half white, half black,
and they look like they all take acid."

I might as well just nerd out like a muddafugga and
give you my second favorite quote, the definition of a
breakdown:

"This is where the song calms down and creates drama
by stripping away its elements until there's nothing
left (except perhaps a single string note, a German
woman having an orgasm, or the voice of God telling
you to take drugs)."

British people are funny. I think I'm gonna move to
England.


Giles

> 
> Yo, I picked up a pretty good book the other day 
> "How to DJ right - the art and science of playing
> records".  
> A good book I would recommend to the beginner or
> novice.  
> It includes the basics and then into some technical
> aspects of mixing.
> It also includes cute illustrations, quotes from
> your favorite DJs, well
> written, lots of details.  Its not a hard back, but
> sturdy construction,
> cost me 15 bucks.
> Not a bad read , pick it up.
>

** :CODE -> Help us celebrate TWO YEARS of :CODE!!!
          || http://code.dnalounge.com
          || http://www.dnalounge.com/flyers/2003/07/10-code.html
          || displaying :CODE sequence for 07.24.03:

** :CODE has been around for two years now, providing SF with some
   of the best in local and international electronic music talent.
   To help us celebrate our success, we've got a lot of neat stuff
   lined up for the line, including a performance by one of the
   Godfathers of techno:  DJ T-1000!

** "Detroit Techno's Renaissance Man" DJ T-1000 from Chicago comes
   to code for our 2-year Anniversary blowout.  Anyone who is 
   familiar with Detroit techno knows the name Alan Oldham. 
   Better known as DJ T-1000 with his own releases on Pure Sonik
   Records, Alan has been responsible for some of the Motor City's
   great tracks over the past several years.

THE MAIN ROOM:
+--------------------------------------------------------------
| T-1000                                [ Puke Sonik, Chicago ]
| Praxis --live PA               [ Omniscient Records / :CODE ]
| Shank                    [ :CODE / Epiphany / Cloud Factory ]
| Amber                                   [ :CODE / Sister SF ]
|   -vs-
| Dragn'fly                             [ Epiphany / Teknique ]
|    (2x4 -- on four turntables)


THE LOUNGE (hosted by Sleeveless, SF and judah. skateboards):
+--------------------------------------------------------------
| Aye-n vs. Ivry                                [ Compression ]
| UltraViolet             [ Sleeveless, Future Breaks, judah. ]
| Femmes Fetales          [ Sleeveless, Future Breaks, judah. ]
| Arson                          [ Urban Drums, Triple 5 Soul ]


Live webcasting with separate audio and video feeds
---+-----------------------------------------------------------
   | http://www.dnalounge.com/audio
   | http://www.dnalounge.com/cam


:code || techno. electro. drum-n-bass. breaks.
---+-----------------------------------------------------------
   | DNA LOUNGE . 375 11th Street . SF 
   | 9pm - after hours. 21+ with ID.
   | free before 10pm. $5 after.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] What difference does it make? (Art of Live PA)

I just watched Jay Walker and Jack Buser play live, each on their own rig,
with no, read that NO DAT, and all hardware based sequencing. Guess what?
They blew the mutha fucking roof off of POW! that night. That tiny place was
JAMMED with people that were dancing away. I've seen Praxis tear shit up
live on stage at the DNA regularly. He's got people stomping around and
again - all hardware based sequencing and NO DAT. I think where you fall
short is the need to produce trance. Sorry - trance is dead here. Those that
listen to it are few and far between with most live acts being of the
psy//goa realm.

LivePA is well loved in this area and happens all the time. It just hasn't
worked out well for you... =/

:: r y a n ::

----- Original Message ----- 
From: <DeezzerRec@aol.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, July 21, 2003 12:21 AM
Subject: [sfraves] What difference does it make? (Art of Live PA)


Ladies and gentlemen, I'm throwing my hat in to the electronic trance music.
Seems no promoter is interested to support this bay area silicon valley
producer. I've fought long and hard, the good lord (and you promoters) knows
how
much $ i've been spilling to try to make a difference..

all this time i've been trying to show people how live pa can be done
without
a dat or tape.  i've always believed our genre was headed to a death because
there isn't an accurate representation of our music.  other genres bring out
the gear that made the music, but electronic music brings out only djs. i
wish
someone would've at least check into what i was doing and give it a chance
at
their venue.  but they've all ignored it..

So now i will tell you how live pa can be done so that maybe some DJ out
there thats in the circuit of getting booked can do it. it's simple, and
will
mesmerize your crowd.

I am publishing this over the net only to the sfraves list, because we are
silicon valley, where innovation happens.

The Ideal Electronic Live PA...

All must devices must have midi
1. you must have a drum machine. I use the tr 909
program each pattern, to know where they are, memorize what makes the rolls,
add lots of verity.
2. you must have a sampler. program your favorite samples
3 program a synth that has an internal sequencer such as the korg ea1
4. have a secondary drum machine for layered drum sounds such as another
sampler or a tr808 with effects connected.
5. maybe have your laptop running cubase sx, or reason.
6. connect all devices making all timecode external except the main drum
machine internal, changing appropriate midi channel
7. when you press "start" on your drum machine, all devices will sound off
and should be in sync.
8. all will play into the mixer. now you must control the mixer. and
different elements of each device.
9. you have yourself a synth, this synth is your favorite synth, it's like
your guitar synth, and you jam on this synth and show the crowd that you and
this synth are one. and your crowd will love you.
10. your act is a combination of known patterns, knowing when to switch off
devices or changing sequence within the devices, vocoders on and off
connected
to your favorite synth. (my favoirte synth i've been using is the nord lead)

for a sample of all of this in action, you must have broadband, click here:
<A
HREF="http://www.reflectnow.com/media/Reflector_Agenda.wmv">http://www.refle
ctnow.com/media/Reflector_Agenda.wmv</A>


there you have it...this is as real as it gets, and if only more people was
exposed to this maybe we could've started something, maybe we would've been
more respected and represented for electronic music as supposed to being
followers of europe. they look down on us for not having culture, yet they
are all
using our computers. yes we've not been around as long as europe, but fuck
that
we are the capital technology hub of the world, and innovators of the
fucking
tv, computer, radio, and everything that makes entertainment happen. YES
SILICON VALLEY AND YOU ALL LIVE HERE!!!!! dont you ever forget it.  all of
us are in
this sprit of technology...
So good luck to the scene... It was fun...

Dominic Son aka Reflector
Reflect Records
<A HREF="www.reflectnow.com">www.reflectnow.com</A>

""The Sounds that come out of a synthesizer provokes my soul in inexplicable
mysterious ways and for this reason I must devote a big part of my life to
electronic music."

Broadband Archieve Reflector Live PA Video & Audio Clips found here: <A
HREF="http://www.reflectnow.com/audio/index.html">
http://www.reflectnow.com/audio/index.html</A>

"Don't start the party without us!" Visit eParty Unlimited's new site: <A
HREF="http://www.epartyunlimited.com">
http://www.epartyunlimited.com</A>

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

>>> SYSTEM UPDATE 07.18.03 <<<

Greetings carbon-based lifeforms!
As the 18th day of the seventh month of the 2003rd year draws to a close
and
the earth's gravitational pull brings us ever closer to the weekend, cast
your eyes below and behold the glory that is all-things System.

And remember, wipe all Klingons off Uranis!


------
>> JOSH WINK 'Profound Sounds v2' - OUT NOW! <<
http://www.systemrecordings.com/store/product_info.php?products_id=62

2xCD includes DJ mix CD + Bonus EP featuring some of Wink's biggest tracks!
+ View Wink tour dates at: http://www.systemrecordings.com/tourdates/
+ Enter to win a Final Scratch system: http://www.systemrecordings.com/

Critics are using words like "brilliant" and "revolutionary" to describe
'Profound Sounds v2'. But don't take our word for it, Here's what the
people
are saying...

+++++
"OMG!!!!! By far the best mix of the year! By far the best mix of the year!
It has been a very long time since I have bought a cd and loved every track
on it. Come to think of it the last cd I bought like that was PSv1. Josh
MAD
PROPS on an amazing cd you are such an inspiration!!"
+++++
"PSv2 is DA BOMB!!! AWESOME!!! I was just lucky enough to get my hands on a
copy of Profound Sounds v2, and it was WORTH THE WAIT!!! If ever a DJ stood
for quality over quantity its Wink. He doesn't just toss one off, he makes
it as good as he can."
+++++
"The perfection of this CD is that Wink gives you exactly what you need to
hear. You can attentively listen to it or simply let it slip into the
background of your life. It never attempts to exhaust the listener and
keeps
the music fresh throughout. The CD is a worthy buy; I can promise you it
can
be listened to for hours and never fail to leave some aspect unexplored."
+++++
"This mix is so smooth! The intensity builds very gradually but it always
remains interesting. This is a very effective way of capturing the
listener.
You can feel the tension starting to build. The mixes are sometimes rich
and
textured, and often smooth as a chocolate swirl. It depends on what Wink
wants you to feel. It's a beautiful thing."
+++++
All i can say is HELL YEAH... You've done it again Josh... Made my head bob
and my ears happy w/ the sounds of great music.. Id say keep up the good
work, but so far I haven't heard anything you've done that's bad work.."
+++++
To those who haven't heard PS v2, GET OFF YOUR BOOTY AND GO BUY IT, THEN
SHAKE YOUR BOOTY ALL THE WAY HOME TO THE SOUNDS OF A MASTER LIKE WINK..."
+++++

------
STREET TEAM:

System Recordings is looking to expand its current street team with your
help! This is a great way to get involved in the music industry and get a
few perks along the way - all the while enjoying the music that you love!
Street Team responsibilities include passing out flyers/stickers/magazines
etc and putting up posters at events, servicing local retail and lifestyle
locations (cafes, clothing stores, skate shops, record stores, college
campuses etc) with System materials, setting up listening parties and more!

We are asking for as much or as little time as you can commit, but the
perks
are certainly relative to your time! This is a great opportunity to get
involved with a fast-growing record label and help grow your resume at the
same time.

This is a NON-PAID position.

If you're interested, know someone who is, or have questions, write us at
teams@systemrecordings.com

At 12:21 AM 7/21/2003, DeezzerRec@aol.com wrote:

>Ladies and gentlemen, I'm throwing my hat in to the electronic trance music.
>Seems no promoter is interested to support this bay area silicon valley
>producer. I've fought long and hard, the good lord (and you promoters) 
>knows how
>much $ i've been spilling to try to make a difference..
>
>all this time i've been trying to show people how live pa can be done without
>a dat or tape.  i've always believed our genre was headed to a death because
>there isn't an accurate representation of our music.  other genres bring out
>the gear that made the music, but electronic music brings out only djs. i 
>wish
>someone would've at least check into what i was doing and give it a chance at
>their venue.  but they've all ignored it..
>
>So now i will tell you how live pa can be done so that maybe some DJ out
>there thats in the circuit of getting booked can do it. it's simple, and will
>mesmerize your crowd.
>
>I am publishing this over the net only to the sfraves list, because we are
>silicon valley, where innovation happens.
>
>The Ideal Electronic Live PA...
>
>All must devices must have midi
>1. you must have a drum machine. I use the tr 909
>program each pattern, to know where they are, memorize what makes the rolls,
>add lots of verity.
>2. you must have a sampler. program your favorite samples
>3 program a synth that has an internal sequencer such as the korg ea1
>4. have a secondary drum machine for layered drum sounds such as another
>sampler or a tr808 with effects connected.
>5. maybe have your laptop running cubase sx, or reason.
>6. connect all devices making all timecode external except the main drum
>machine internal, changing appropriate midi channel
>7. when you press "start" on your drum machine, all devices will sound off
>and should be in sync.
>8. all will play into the mixer. now you must control the mixer. and
>different elements of each device.
>9. you have yourself a synth, this synth is your favorite synth, it's like
>your guitar synth, and you jam on this synth and show the crowd that you and
>this synth are one. and your crowd will love you.
>10. your act is a combination of known patterns, knowing when to switch off
>devices or changing sequence within the devices, vocoders on and off 
>connected
>to your favorite synth. (my favoirte synth i've been using is the nord lead)
>
>for a sample of all of this in action, you must have broadband, click here:
><A 
>HREF="http://www.reflectnow.com/media/Reflector_Agenda.wmv">http://www.reflectnow.com/media/Reflector_Agenda.wmv</A>
>
>
>there you have it...this is as real as it gets, and if only more people was
>exposed to this maybe we could've started something, maybe we would've been
>more respected and represented for electronic music as supposed to being
>followers of europe. they look down on us for not having culture, yet they 
>are all
>using our computers. yes we've not been around as long as europe, but fuck 
>that
>we are the capital technology hub of the world, and innovators of the fucking
>tv, computer, radio, and everything that makes entertainment happen. YES
>SILICON VALLEY AND YOU ALL LIVE HERE!!!!! dont you ever forget it.  all of 
>us are in
>this sprit of technology...
>So good luck to the scene... It was fun...
>
>Dominic Son aka Reflector
>Reflect Records
><A HREF="www.reflectnow.com">www.reflectnow.com</A>
>
>""The Sounds that come out of a synthesizer provokes my soul in inexplicable
>mysterious ways and for this reason I must devote a big part of my life to
>electronic music."
>
>Broadband Archieve Reflector Live PA Video & Audio Clips found here: <A 
>HREF="http://www.reflectnow.com/audio/index.html">
>http://www.reflectnow.com/audio/index.html</A>
>
>"Don't start the party without us!" Visit eParty Unlimited's new site: <A 
>HREF="http://www.epartyunlimited.com">
>http://www.epartyunlimited.com</A>


--=======6A013451=======

Friday.August.8th.2003 
Xtort Proudly Presents: *PULSE* 
Xtort's proudly showcases *TWO ROOMS* of non-stop energy featuring over 13 performers along with one of the founding fathers of the Frequency-8 label as he kicks off his new DVD/Album nationwide tour...feel the pulse.

FEATURING: 
MARS (FREQUENCY 8, SF) 
TOM SLIK (SKILLS, SF)

SASCHA23 (XTORT)
MAJERE (ELEKTROSORCERY, SF)
SCEPTER (SHAOLIN)
DINGO and COORAW (KIDS AT PLAY, SF) 
DJ WARREN (XTORT) + EX-DJ RYAN (XTORT) +  RIGATONY (SAGITARIUN) ALL AGES WELCOME... 
*FANTASTIC VIDEO VISUALS* 
FREE posters/cds/stickers to the first 150 people courtesy of ASTRALWERKS, NETTWERK, and ADV Films along 
with METROPOLIS Records. 
Friendly and Professional Security 
Doors open: 8:30pm-4am

Subject: [sfraves] Dancing to Latin (in Oakland) was Re: [sfraves] NRR:  Celia Cruz

Ah, I discovered some Latin music last week in Oakland, at Noche De Vaqueros
(Latin Cowboy  night). For some reason, perhaps trying to stay happy (and
thin), I have been dancing a lot lately. Not partying too hard here, just
dancing hard all last week at:

Estuary on Monday night (at Masses, in Pleasanton)
Noche De Vaqueros (The Latin cowboy party, on Wed)
Reform Skool at The Stud (Thursday)
Fashion show & dance at the Noodle Factory (Friday)
Underwear party in Hayward at the Turf club (Saturday)
(P.S. it's fun to dance in sexy silk boxers)

Now I'm ready to start all over again at Masses.

Anyway, about that Latin music, I had SO much fun. I don't speak a lick of
Spanish, didn't understand the words to the songs, but boy was it good for
dancing.

I wore my Roper cowboy shirt, Stetson cowboy hat, and just got into the
spirit of things. I even had a large Latin cowboy try to dance with me. (by
the way, there were many cowgirls, too). I was shaking that booty all over
the floor, even moved to the middle of the action.

Wow, I stayed until closing (2 am). I am not familiar with the Latin genre,
but apparently on this night (Northern Cal's only Latin cowboy night), they
play Cumbia, Banda, Nortena, and Ranchero music. (whatever the heck that
stuff is).

I missed Naomi's drag show at 10 pm, but I came to dance, not watch the drag
queens.

I don't know my inspiration, but if might have been news reports about the
Queen of Salsa, may she rest in peace, because I think I understand her
spirit now (the essence of latin soul).

Greg VP


----- Original Message -----

I've had a lifelong affection for Latin music and, in particular,
salsa.  The "Queen of Salsa,"  Celia Cruz, passed last week.  A great loss
to anyone who loves music.

http://tinyurl.com/hj1s

Love,

Apollo

Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

Subject: [sfraves] short skirts...with or without built in shorts nrr

--0-628135594-1058841857=:90777
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

pluses and minuses of little school girl skirts....many styles to choose from these days, because they are classic and totally trendy:
classic style number one: school girl skirt...basic, thick fabric, pleats and plaid...multiple colors to choose from...
trendy style number one: closes with velcro, is short...comes in small, medium or large rather than number sizes...thin fabric, costs more than all of them except for one style i saw with a medium ranger price..mostly ill fitting, only good for a costume...highly unusable, but apparently are selling sometimes....
new age style number one: skirt with shorts..available in high quality fabric and design or in the cheapo, wear it once design too...so many options for the collector these days. :)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] What difference does it make? (Art of Live PA)

Tossing my shit in to the ring-

(but i comment only cause ive known about you for a
long time)

I dunno- I know you've tryed to focus on the "i'm
really live" aspect- but I think your song structure
is just kinda not there-

Like- just cause you're hand-playing that arrpeggio
cheese synth line doesnt make the song any more
palateable.

Not that I'm any master in this area, but certain
songs evoke emotion in me- songs a built from tension
and release.
Unfortunaely I've been "blessed" with the ADHD that
doesnt allow me to ever really complete anything; but
I'm guessing you must have some songs that do these
same things to you-
Listen to them- study them.
Break them down in to exactly what it is that makes
the hair on your back stand up when you hear them-
Im talking about the pure SQ-wave 303 1-bar breakdown
in Voodoo People-
The 3-bar drum-mixup progression at ~1:20 in the Chem
Bros remix of their own Music Response.

Those are just a couple sections that take me to a
differnt place; I don't think you've discovered yours
yet...

--- innocentchild <innocentchild@hotmail.com> wrote:
> I just watched Jay Walker and Jack Buser play live,
> each on their own rig,
> with no, read that NO DAT, and all hardware based
> sequencing. Guess what?
> They blew the mutha fucking roof off of POW! that
> night. That tiny place was
> JAMMED with people that were dancing away. I've seen
> Praxis tear shit up
> live on stage at the DNA regularly. He's got people
> stomping around and
> again - all hardware based sequencing and NO DAT. I
> think where you fall
> short is the need to produce trance. Sorry - trance
> is dead here. Those that
> listen to it are few and far between with most live
> acts being of the
> psy//goa realm.
> 
> LivePA is well loved in this area and happens all
> the time. It just hasn't
> worked out well for you... =/
> 
> :: r y a n ::
> 
> ----- Original Message ----- 
> From: <DeezzerRec@aol.com>
> To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
> Sent: Monday, July 21, 2003 12:21 AM
> Subject: [sfraves] What difference does it make?
> (Art of Live PA)
> 
> 
> Ladies and gentlemen, I'm throwing my hat in to the
> electronic trance music.
> Seems no promoter is interested to support this bay
> area silicon valley
> producer. I've fought long and hard, the good lord
> (and you promoters) knows
> how
> much $ i've been spilling to try to make a
> difference..
> 
> all this time i've been trying to show people how
> live pa can be done
> without
> a dat or tape.  i've always believed our genre was
> headed to a death because
> there isn't an accurate representation of our music.
>  other genres bring out
> the gear that made the music, but electronic music
> brings out only djs. i
> wish
> someone would've at least check into what i was
> doing and give it a chance
> at
> their venue.  but they've all ignored it..
> 
> So now i will tell you how live pa can be done so
> that maybe some DJ out
> there thats in the circuit of getting booked can do
> it. it's simple, and
> will
> mesmerize your crowd.
> 
> I am publishing this over the net only to the
> sfraves list, because we are
> silicon valley, where innovation happens.
> 
> The Ideal Electronic Live PA...
> 
> All must devices must have midi
> 1. you must have a drum machine. I use the tr 909
> program each pattern, to know where they are,
> memorize what makes the rolls,
> add lots of verity.
> 2. you must have a sampler. program your favorite
> samples
> 3 program a synth that has an internal sequencer
> such as the korg ea1
> 4. have a secondary drum machine for layered drum
> sounds such as another
> sampler or a tr808 with effects connected.
> 5. maybe have your laptop running cubase sx, or
> reason.
> 6. connect all devices making all timecode external
> except the main drum
> machine internal, changing appropriate midi channel
> 7. when you press "start" on your drum machine, all
> devices will sound off
> and should be in sync.
> 8. all will play into the mixer. now you must
> control the mixer. and
> different elements of each device.
> 9. you have yourself a synth, this synth is your
> favorite synth, it's like
> your guitar synth, and you jam on this synth and
> show the crowd that you and
> this synth are one. and your crowd will love you.
> 10. your act is a combination of known patterns,
> knowing when to switch off
> devices or changing sequence within the devices,
> vocoders on and off
> connected
> to your favorite synth. (my favoirte synth i've been
> using is the nord lead)
> 
> for a sample of all of this in action, you must have
> broadband, click here:
> <A
>
HREF="http://www.reflectnow.com/media/Reflector_Agenda.wmv">http://www.refle
> ctnow.com/media/Reflector_Agenda.wmv</A>
> 
> 
> there you have it...this is as real as it gets, and
> if only more people was
> exposed to this maybe we could've started something,
> maybe we would've been
> more respected and represented for electronic music
> as supposed to being
> followers of europe. they look down on us for not
> having culture, yet they
> are all
> using our computers. yes we've not been around as
> long as europe, but fuck
> that
> we are the capital technology hub of the world, and
> innovators of the
> fucking
> tv, computer, radio, and everything that makes
> entertainment happen. YES
> SILICON VALLEY AND YOU ALL LIVE HERE!!!!! dont you
> ever forget it.  all of
> us are in
> this sprit of technology...
> So good luck to the scene... It was fun...
> 
> Dominic Son aka Reflector
> Reflect Records
> <A HREF="www.reflectnow.com">www.reflectnow.com</A>
> 
> ""The Sounds that come out of a synthesizer provokes
> my soul in inexplicable
> mysterious ways and for this reason I must devote a
> big part of my life to
> electronic music."
> 
> Broadband Archieve Reflector Live PA Video & Audio
> Clips found here: <A
> HREF="http://www.reflectnow.com/audio/index.html">
> http://www.reflectnow.com/audio/index.html</A>
> 
> "Don't start the party without us!" Visit eParty
> Unlimited's new site: <A

> http://www.epartyunlimited.com</A>

  innocentchild <innocentchild@hotmail.com>, DeezzerRec@aol.com,
  sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20030722045852.74096.qmail@web13906.mail.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] What difference does it make? (Art of Live PA)

A couple of years ago, my live PA duo was having similar problems. 
We'd go to promoters, say, "Look, we're doing deep house, LIVE- don't
you want to see that?", and they'd go "Uh, we book dance music here,
you know, DJs?".  We'd come back saying, "Yeah, we know- we make dance
music, live, with electronics and live instruments together.", and
they'd still be saying, "Oh, maybe you don't get it- the music we book
here is dance music, you know, like house?"

So apart from a few brave promoters (mainly good friends), we were
largely ignored- until we turned our sights on production.  We put out
a single, it got a little press and some people got to hear it, and we
started getting booked a little more.  We've put out a second now, and
it's picking up steam, little by little.  We're not actively seeking
bookings for live stuff right now (focusing on the next single and the
album), but we still get offered the odd thing here and there, and feel
very lucky for that.

I would say, as a person who has tried to push the live PA thing for a
few years, the best thing you can do is have something to put in a
promoter's hands- a live demo, say, or a 12" of a killer track you've
produced.  If you can come to them with a bit of precedence set, that's
far better.  Just like a DJ needs a good mix CD and a 'lil bit of a
"resume" of events they've played to get better bookings, a live act
needs some "money" to put where their mouth is.  If your music is great
and there's a market for your style of music in a given area, you've
got a good shot.

Even still, support or no support, make music if it makes you happy. 
The more I've gotten my head wrapped up in the success or failure of my
music, the more weary and uninspired I've been.  When you can strip all
that away and get back to doing it for the reasons you did when you
started (i.e. love of music), the rest will come naturally.

GeorgeC aka Origami (from dj2)
www.djorigami.com

First of all Quitters don't lose, and Losers don't quit!
Second, This is a hard industry to be in. Times are tough for everyone. As a 
producer you should be focusing on pumping out as many tracks as possible. 
Shit I wish I had that ability. Get those tracks out to labels, Its up to you, 
but let me just say this, If your in the industry JUST for the money Yea get 
out, If you truly love dance music, Suck it up like everyone else and enjoy it. 
As an "artist" you now get to enjoy the Top Raman dinners that so many of us 
eat. LOL! Really, don't quit, Its a bad habit to start! Good luck, 


                             Gianni  ;0)      <-------Has been easing a lot

Mime-Version: 1.0

User-Agent: Mutt/1.3.28i

Subject: Re: [sfraves] What difference does it make? (Art of Live PA)



If you are doing live stuff, it really helps to have a niche.  I do a live
set with a friend, and we work well at chill rooms at psytrance parties...
I dunno, we just work well there.  We don't aspire to be in the main room,
and we don't aspire to make it big.  We just have fun with it.  And we
enjoy it.  And we get people's groove on in the chill room.  

Find your niche and go with it...

And it certinaly helps to be a part of the production crew... a part of
the scene.

-troy

On Tue, Jul 22, 2003 at 09:38:45AM -0700, georgeC wrote:
> A couple of years ago, my live PA duo was having similar problems. 
> We'd go to promoters, say, "Look, we're doing deep house, LIVE- don't
> you want to see that?", and they'd go "Uh, we book dance music here,
> you know, DJs?".  We'd come back saying, "Yeah, we know- we make dance
> music, live, with electronics and live instruments together.", and
> they'd still be saying, "Oh, maybe you don't get it- the music we book
> here is dance music, you know, like house?"
> 
> So apart from a few brave promoters (mainly good friends), we were
> largely ignored- until we turned our sights on production.  We put out
> a single, it got a little press and some people got to hear it, and we
> started getting booked a little more.  We've put out a second now, and
> it's picking up steam, little by little.  We're not actively seeking
> bookings for live stuff right now (focusing on the next single and the
> album), but we still get offered the odd thing here and there, and feel
> very lucky for that.
> 
> I would say, as a person who has tried to push the live PA thing for a
> few years, the best thing you can do is have something to put in a
> promoter's hands- a live demo, say, or a 12" of a killer track you've
> produced.  If you can come to them with a bit of precedence set, that's
> far better.  Just like a DJ needs a good mix CD and a 'lil bit of a
> "resume" of events they've played to get better bookings, a live act
> needs some "money" to put where their mouth is.  If your music is great
> and there's a market for your style of music in a given area, you've
> got a good shot.
> 
> Even still, support or no support, make music if it makes you happy. 
> The more I've gotten my head wrapped up in the success or failure of my
> music, the more weary and uninspired I've been.  When you can strip all
> that away and get back to doing it for the reasons you did when you
> started (i.e. love of music), the rest will come naturally.
> 
> GeorgeC aka Origami (from dj2)
> www.djorigami.com
> 
> > > ----- Original Message ----- 
> > > From: <DeezzerRec@aol.com>
> > > To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>

> > > (and you promoters) knows

deposit is workable

her email is jzubiate@sbcglobal.net
Peace,
Danny

to smacken-backen und fix de morkin, yøobetcha! "
-The Swedish Chef

Actually, ::jumping in on the speculation bandwagon::, I'm guessing that
Ron's in quite a pickle right now, I don't think he's gonna make anywhere
near a house off this party. I don't think he's gonna make much really. I
think he's just trying to not lose his ass on this party.

And, think about it, you have $100K or more invested into a party, and
ticket sales/ venue drama cast doubt on your party, are you gonna
introduce more doubt into the event by spilling the beans, or are you
gonna try to keep the event as rumordly positive as possible so ticket sales
don't go into the toilet.

Of course, I may be wrong, just trying to get into the head-space of a
massive promoter.

-terry

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 75164 invoked from network); 22 Jul 2003 20:15:44 -0000
Date: Tue, 22 Jul 2003 13:15:40 -0700 (PDT)
To: <DeezzerRec@aol.com>
Cc: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <20030722163845.1887.qmail@web80502.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.30.0307221257220.30246-100000@dragon.greengraphics.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
From: Ed Colmar <ed@greengraphics.net>
X-Delivery-Agent: TMDA/0.65 (Johnstown)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] What difference does it make? (Art of Live PA)


I'm in agreement with George on this.  Making tracks, getting demos out
there, and soliciting feedback from listeners is vital.  Not only to your
bookings, but to your quality as well.

The music industry is populated.  Every Dj, performer, band and live act,
is (in one way or another) in competition with each other.  Competition
for people's attention probably being number one.

I think we are lucky in the rave scene to have people involved that are
interested in working together and collaborating to achieve goals that
will help the group.

Another suggestion that tends to work really well in this scene is DIY.
If you think you've got it going on, put an event together and show it.
Get some other performers and dj's that you respect together and suddenly
you've got a venue to do whatever you want with.

Personally, I think it's great that we're seeing more and more live
performances popping up.

Good luck.

-e-

On Tue, 22 Jul 2003, georgeC wrote:

> I would say, as a person who has tried to push the live PA thing for a
> few years, the best thing you can do is have something to put in a
> promoter's hands- a live demo, say, or a 12" of a killer track you've
> produced.

www.siegerecords.com
www.edcolmar.com


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] short skirts...with or without built in shorts nrr

If I can remember from my private-school skirt chasing days, the only
green uniformed skirt is St. Lawrence Academy (I'm from SJ). the 2 main
schools down here were Blue (Presentation) and Grey (Notre Dame). Most
everything else was blue or red.

I thought it was funny how their parents would drop them off with their
skirts down to their kness, then when the boys would visit for lunch
they'd hike 'em up to their ass.

Good times, good times =)

-t

 =0D
Haha yeah it was the ever famous rolled skirt. As soon as you hit the
parking lot you'd roll them up. We had a nun at Notre Dame (in Salinas),
Sister Celine who was as old as the school itself. She used to come aroun=
d
and make us kneel on the concrete and see if our skirts hit the ground
kneeling. If not we'd have to unroll them. She'd also make us recite "thi=
s
is the day the lord has made...let us rejoice and be glad" We'd run when =
we
d see her coming.=0D
=0D
Now I see the ND girls and they might as well not even be wearing a skirt=
=2E
The skirt rolling gets to a point where it just looks silly and makes you
look like you have major love handles.=0D
=0D
Jennifer=0D

----- Original Message -----
From: "Giles Bowkett" <giles_bowkett@yahoo.com>
To: <DeezzerRec@aol.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Monday, July 21, 2003 1:53 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] What difference does it make? (Art of Live PA)


> --- DeezzerRec@aol.com wrote:
> > i've always believed our genre was
> > headed to a death because
> > there isn't an accurate representation of our music.
> >  other genres bring out
> > the gear that made the music, but electronic music
> > brings out only djs.
>
> actually this is part disagreement part tangent.
>
> ready?
>
> my theory is this: electronic music inherits
> traditions of composition and improvisation. producing
> is all about composition. DJing is all about
> improvisation. there's a core musicality required for
> both roles, but being able to make the right choices
> in a prepared way (composition) and in a spontaneous
> way (improv) are totally different abilities.
>
> live PAs have always seemed to me rather odd because
> even tho I like the old-school jam session as much as
> anyone the truth is that the technology involved in
> making this music often tends to be persnickety and
> particular. fine-tuning it in the midst of a sweaty
> club or a full moon renegade often looks to me like
> trying to crack a safe in the middle of an orgy --
> there's a lot going on, and most of it detracts from
> your ability to concentrate.
>
> besides, even if you can get unique sounds that way,
> doesn't it seem like the crowd deserves more of your
> energy than that? after all, 303 fanatics aside, it's
> not actually about the machinery...
>
> [europe]
> > they look down on us for not
> > having culture, yet they are all
> > using our computers. yes we've not been around as
> > long as europe, but fuck that
> > we are the capital technology hub of the world, and
> > innovators of the fucking
> > tv, computer, radio, and everything that makes
> > entertainment happen. YES
> > SILICON VALLEY AND YOU ALL LIVE HERE!!!!! dont you
> > ever forget it.  all of us are in
> > this sprit of technology...
>
> dude, chill. radio was invented in Italy.
>
> and techno was invented in America.
>
>
> Giles

How to get a marina.girl

Scan a $20 bill front and back. Have your friend at kinkos run them on a
Canon fiery on high cotton content paper. Make about $500 worth and print
them front and back (duplexed) and cut them out. Wrap a real $20 bill around
the fakes and conspiquously flash your money clip while buying drinks. Dress
like the uber scenester from Ruby Skye. They'll flock to you like flies to
shit. But who wants that?

All of my credit cards have less plastic than a single marina girl.

hey thanks Mystic.

it was actually William Hewlett and David Packard that were messin around in their garages and built the resistance-capacitance audio oscillator in their garages here in Palo Alto which gave ways to the radio...

By the way i'm going to give you guys the truth, if it's dealing with trance, people won't listen to you if you're not from Europe. I feel like i'm battling a war with a handicap - that i'm not in Europe.  Warner Brothers has shown interest, Columbia Records loves my tracks and think it's commercial and a hit, but i'm not from Europe.  so for those who say to write better songs, either you've not heard my new songs, or you are pre-judging without really knowing. 

Thanks for all your love..and your hate. You all make the world go round...

Dominic Son aka Reflector
Reflect Records
www.reflectnow.com

MIME-Version: 1.0

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] What difference does it make? (Art of Live PA)

On Tue, 22 Jul 2003, Giles Bowkett wrote:

> > it was actually William Hewlett and David Packard
> > that were messin around in their garages and built
> > the resistance-capacitance audio oscillator in their
> > garages here in Palo Alto which gave ways to the
> > radio...
> 
> my bad. I stand corrected.

not so fast .. hate to nitpick, but ..  
http://inventors.about.com/library/inventors/blradio.htm
"
Guglielmo Marconi, an Italian inventor, proved the feasibility of radio 
communication. He sent and received his first radio signal in Italy in 
1895. By 1899 he flashed the first wireless signal across the English 
Channel and two years later received the letter "S", telegraphed from 
England to Newfoundland. This was the first successful transatlantic 
radiotelegraph message in 1902.

(Note: Nikola Tesla is now credited with having inventing modern radio; 
the Supreme Court overturned Marconi's patent in 1943 in favor of Tesla.) 
"
"
The first time the human voice was transmitted by radio is debatable. 
Claims to that distinction range from the phase, "Hello Rainey" spoken by 
Natan B. Stubblefield to a test partner near Murray, Kentucky, in 1892, to 
an experimental program of talk and music by Reginald A. Fessenden, of 
Brant Rock, Massachusetts, in 1906, which was heard by radio-equipped 
ships within several hundred miles.

In 1915 speech was first transmitted across the continent from New York 
City to San Francisco and across the Atlantic Ocean from Naval radio 
station NAA at Arlington, Virginia, to the Eiffel Tower in Paris. There 
was some experimental military radiotelephony in World War I between 
ground and aircraft..
" 


Jeff

From sfraves-return-104096-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Jul 23 03:00:26 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-104096-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 23635 invoked by uid 1103); 23 Jul 2003 03:00:26 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

Received: (qmail 23621 invoked from network); 23 Jul 2003 03:00:25 -0000
From: "Tom Lee" <tomslee75@rcn.com>
To: "sfraves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Date: Tue, 22 Jul 2003 19:57:57 -0700
Message-ID: <GCENIKNKCMGIJALOGPAMKEGLDCAA.tomslee75@rcn.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook IMO, Build 9.0.2416 (9.0.2911.0)
Importance: Normal
In-Reply-To: <20021230223821.GB19662@alterior.net>
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2727.1300
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Review and future BSP: ESTUARY -- somewhat long, but very informative.

Hey all,

I'm not normally someone who posts on here, though I go out alot.  Whether
it's DNA, Sitio, NHC, Tenderloft, 550, Moksha parties, other parties, etc.,
rarely will I make a post.  I've always had fun at those places (most of the
time), so don't get me wrong.

However during this past Monday night, I had an AMAZING time at this
bar/club out in Pleasanton.  The night is called ESTUARY. OK, first I was
concerned that it was too far.  45 minutes to drive on a Monday can be a bit
rough, but it is SOOOO worth it.  I can't stress that enough.

Here are a list of things that make this place wonderful:
1) Security is really friendly and nice.
2) They serve dope and reasonably-priced food for a bar.
3) It is a LARGE space -- could easily fit 200 to 300 people.
4) There is FREE pool!!!!
5) There is a huge outside smoking area furnished with chairs and tables.
6) The people there are SOOOO cool.  I met all these new people who were
great: Happy, Damien, Michelle, Chris, Dave, Karen, KJ, Nate, Jacob, Greg,
Tom etc. etc. (plus my wonderful group of friends who happened to be there:
Graham, Jessica, Audra, Penny, Brandon, Monique, Teks, John and Marcine).
7) There are OPEN DECKS from 9 until 2AM!!!!  (with one hour set-aside for a
headliner)
8) Long Islands that should be called STRONG Islands and they cost ONLY $2!
9) It's FREE to get in.

I was in such awe when I got there.  I wasn't expecting much, but made about
some new friends, got to hangout with alot of people, got to throw down some
breaks, got to see some friends spin and also got to see Marcine play some
kickass D&B (she was the head-liner that night).

Another highlight of the night:  Kicking Brandon's (DJ Bam) butt in
foosball... 9-0.  :-)

If you guys have not checked out the place yet, set aside some time on this
upcoming Monday.  You won't regret it.  If you are a DJ, show up early and
try to get an Open Deck slot.  I warn you though, the slots go quick.

I just have to say thanks to the people who throw ESTUARY for really making
the place so welcoming and wonderful.  You guys have a goldmine out there.
They've been doing this for a month and are going pretty strong (for being
out in Pleasanton).  If things continue well, they'll move to Thursday
nights!

(Scroll down to see details for ESTUARY.)

Much love,

Tom Lee
ShezTek
www.evolvingspectrum.com
www.galanta.net <- check out 30 minutes of my latest mix
Moksha Tribe

--------------------
Below is the BSP for the night:

Estuary: Open Deck Weekly
Mondays 9:00 pm - 2:00 am
Masse's Nightclub : 21+ With ID, Free
6180 Stoneridge Mall Drive
Pleasanton, CA
(650)463-8181

Notes:
Estuary: (Noun) 1. Where the river blends with the sea. 2. A place
where all styles mix.

Every Monday from 9pm-11:30pm and 12:30am-2:00am we will have 1/2
hour open deck slots. Sign ups start at 8:30p, first come first
served. If you have no skills at all, but have some cool tracks that
you'd like to share, you are just as welcome as anyone else! Please
bring needles and headphones.

There will be a weekly special guest featured from 11:30pm-12:30pm.
(Monday 7/28 will be ShezTek)






---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org


From sfraves-return-104097-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Jul 23 04:40:51 2003

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 42908 invoked by uid 1103); 23 Jul 2003 04:40:50 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 42894 invoked from network); 23 Jul 2003 04:40:49 -0000
Message-ID: <003401c350d5$fd7eaf20$d60a030a@internal.village.net>
From: "n i c o" <nico@bassriot.org>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
References: <GCENIKNKCMGIJALOGPAMKEGLDCAA.tomslee75@rcn.com>
Date: Tue, 22 Jul 2003 21:50:21 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1158
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1165
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] review: Paradigm Shift

I don't like the Tenderloft.  *shrug*  I don't know why except that I feel
like it's missing something.

I loved the music at this party, start to finish.  Except I felt like our
scene wasn't paying enough respect when the promoter scheduled Chris Jackson
to play at 4am to close.  But it makes me happy that there's so much solid
talent in the slightly-above-underground that anyone would consider having
J-Bot and Clarity play the opening set.

Hell, even Deaks was playing at another party that night.  Choices,
decisions, random chance.  Deaks and Maya duo-handedly turned me on to
techno back in 1998 at a party another tekhead helped throw (sup Oracle).
God, I love SF.

...?  I'm still not sure why people in the area take for granted the talent
we have living in the bay simply because they live in the bay.  I've seen
horrible DJs get booked for good slots (like the most recent Overworld
party) when the grass is way greener in our front yard.

<3

n i c o

p.s. Anyone willing to sell me a used copy of Chris' tape "Lifeline"?  Mine
broke and I miss the tracks on that tape.



---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

 Position 3. - Locking Legs The woman raises her legs higher and locks them 
around her partner. The higher she can raise her legs, the deeper the 
penetration because access to the vagina is easier. If she has the flexibility to lock 
her legs around her partner then she can contribute to his leverage by 
squeezing him close to her or just hold him with her thighs. Many men find that the 
feel of their partner's legs around them to be a real turn on. One significant 
drawback of this position is that some men find it results in hurried orgasms. 
For this reason we might suggest that you leave this position towards the end 
of your lovemaking.

I have been to every night of Estuary so far, (since the premiere) and I
have really enjoyed it. I have a day job that requires getting up in the
morning but I just don't give a damn when it comes to some good dancing and
fellowship.

The work will get done and I can drink coffee.

Check it out, don't make any excuses, it's just sinful, too.

I mean, where else can you hang out with someone named "Devil?"

Greg

Subject: [sfraves] RE: cathloic school girl skirts [NRR]

--0-1490796807-1058944001=:8043
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Man, thank you all for writing me, I would write you all back individualy, but I am too drunk I had ONE drink, ONE! I always wanted to go to a private school myself, but damn, I was poor, I had uniform envy, like I was in girl scouts and my mom wouldn't buy me a uniform, EVEN WHEN WE SAW ONE AT A GARAGE SALE, I got a huge kick out of working at a movie theatre and actualy getting to wear a uniform. I loved the thing about the 80's shorts and the doubled up socks. Being poor was good though, my mom had the best line when I wanted some toy off TV, she would say "Why don't you make one?" so I would, and pretty soon my toys were way better than the "real" thing, and even at RISD, where it's supposed to be the most creative kids in the whole country, right? Kids would be all like "How do you do that? How do you know how to do all that stuff?" "I was "poor," baby, I can make anything out of anything!" I used to teach oil painting to rich kids in Cupertino, I felt kind of sorry for them,
 never getting to make their own toys. 


--
Sarah Schumm <sarah_schumm@yahoo.com>
Hypnobunny Creative Services - Posters, Logos, Ads and More

Do you Yahoo!?
Yahoo! SiteBuilder - Free, easy-to-use web site design software
--0-1490796807-1058944001=:8043--

DJ T-1000..   D-Jax, Pure Sonik, Tresor

One of the forefathers of Detroit's techno scene his 1987 debut on the "Fast 
Forward" radio program fueled the fledgling Detroit techno scene. His pure 
minimal techno sound has won him international acclaim and a place in Detroit's 
Historical Museum Exhibit, Techno: Detroit's Gift to the World. We are very 
fortunate to have this legend ignite our decks for you.

On Wednesday, July 23, 2003, at 09:15 AM, shawn allen wrote:

> quoth Coolworld:
>> ALREADY CONFIRMED
>>
>> Kraftwerk's Original Member Karl Bartos
>
> So, does this mean Kraftwerk *won't* be performing? Because Karl Bartos
> isn't even part of the group anymore. I'm not looking for a reason to
> rag on Coolworld here -- I just know a lot of people that bought 
> tickets
> exclusively because they thought Kraftwerk would be performing.

That's precisely what I thought when I saw the BSP and an announcement 
on another list that Kraftwerk's new album is finally out - Karl Bartos 
was the name noticeably absent from the Kraftwerk announcement. This is 
precisely the type of bullshit that kept me from buying an advance 
ticket, and despite what looks to be a good lineup, will prevent me 
from going at all. Not that I like massives much to begin with, but 
such marketing practices will NOT be supported by my pocketbook.

I'm sure Cyberfest will be a blast, even without Kraftwerk. Personally, 
it was hard for me to even imagine a bunch of kiddies getting down to 
"Autobahn" or whatnot, so I know that KW would've been the main 
attraction for a handful of us geezers anyhow. But this about seals the 
deal for me. I'm never believing promoters again. After getting burned 
on supposed appearances by Daft Punk, Groove Armada and others, I'm 
only going to rely on Pollstar to check booking accuracy for 
too-big-to-be-true acts from now on.

Coolworld Productions - here's a tip:  Next time, do the listing like 
this

	KARL BARTOS (Kraftwerk, Germany)

His name still carries enough weight with KW fans, and you'd get a 
helluva lot more respect from the bitchers and moaners (myself 
included) on this list and elsewhere.

  - omid

Subject: Re: [sfraves] CYBERFEST 2003

--0-1634777539-1058981234=:40158
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Just to clarify a couple of issues, I'm going to post Karl's Bio so that you can read for yourself. If you still feel mislead, we extend our apoligies. However, Karl is performing as Kraftwerk and will be with his new band / group of musicians performing ALL KRAFTWERK hits & New Material.
 
If you would like to go to his own web-site and check it out, here is the address;

www.karl-bartos.de

Karl Bartos Bio:

Hardly any other name in German popmusic is as much a synonym for electronic lifestyle as Karl Bartos. Not only his work as a member of Kraftwerk, but also his co-operation with local and international artists show him as an icon of a worldwide movement in music. Now, the pioneer of electronic music is back to be heard and seen live. 

As co-author of known Kraftwerk titles as "The Robots", "The Model", "Pocket Calculator" or "Tour de France", Karl Bartos set the foundation for the world-wide success of German Techno-Pop a la Kraftwerk. Countless bands such as Depeche Mode, OMD, The Human League, but also the complete Techno-Dance movement never seize to stress the importance of Kraftwerk's influence on their creative work. 

Bartos belongs to the rare German Pop-icons who enjoy the highest international recognition. His authenticity as one of the founders of a particular German genre makes him as hip as ever. 

As a classically trained drummer and keyboarder, Bartos' influence is evident on the music of Kraftwerk. The godfathers of US-HipHop such as Africa Bambaataa & The Soul Sonic Force, but also the protagonists of the early Detroit Housegrooves have picked up his typical electro beats. With the international success of German Dancemusic, the quality of electronic lifestyle from Germany (co-founded by Bartos) is confirmed until this day. 

His activities as author and producer lead him to world-wide successful co-operations with OMD (Andy McCluskey) and Electronic (Bernard Sumner / Johnny Marr), The Mobile Homes (Sweden), and Anthony Rother and Deine Lakaien from Germany, as well as records of his own project titled "Electric Music". 

A suprise-gig as electronic DJ in August 1999 at the "Kickzone"-Festival during the PopKomm in Cologne gained him excellent critics for Bartos the starting-signal for new live plans. 

Accompanied by a keyboarder Bartos' live-set is composed of newly arranged solo-titles and some premiers. Thus "Man Machine", "Metropolis", "Techno Pop" and "The Telephone Call" have never been performed live before further Kraftwerk songs have been digitally optimized for stage conditions. The previously unreleased track "15 Minutes of Fame" will be complemented with further new compositions, inspired by the atmosphere of a live audience and set to be captured on an upcoming album. 

Visually Bartos will be supported by the work of Cologne video artist Karsten Binar who created video loops, illustrating on big TV screens the classics of Electro-Pop bartos live. 

COOLWORLD

From: Omid Tavallai <otavallai@mac.com>

In-Reply-To: <20030723172714.40560.qmail@web40020.mail.yahoo.com>

X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.552)
