Subject: Re: [sfraves] CYBERFEST 2003


On Wednesday, July 23, 2003, at 10:27 AM, Coolworld wrote:

> Just to clarify a couple of issues, I'm going to post Karl's Bio so 
> that you can read for yourself. If you still feel mislead, we extend 
> our apoligies. However, Karl is performing as Kraftwerk and will be 
> with his new band / group of musicians performing ALL KRAFTWERK hits & 
> New Material.

Of course we still feel misled!  Your current BSP says "Kraftwerk's 
Original Member Karl Bartos" - but in the previous round of hype, it 
was listed simply as KRAFTWERK.

While he will surely play a great deal of Kraftwerk songs, he is not 
performing AS Kraftwerk, he is performing as Karl Bartos. Those of us 
who know Kraftwerk, Bartos, and his music are well aware that he was 
the brains and talent behind it all. (Listening to the lackluster new 
Tour de France 2003 is proof enough!) However, that doesn't mean you 
can advertise the headliner as "Kraftwerk," which you had done before 
the full lineup was officially announced.  Some of us actually WERE 
interested in the boring, robotic live official Kraftwerk experience.

Here's an example of proper promotion. Dave Gahan of Depeche Mode is 
currently touring. Half of his set is comprised of classic DM tunes. On 
no bill or marquee or poster or pre-sale email or festival lineup does 
it list "Depeche Mode" as the act. Why? Because it would be dishonest.

Another example: Trey Anastasio of Phish is recording and touring as... 
Trey Anastasio!  How novel is that? We all know he'll play a lot of 
Phish tunes, the audience is mostly Phish phans, but guess what? It's 
not Phish!

> If you would like to go to his own web-site and check it out, here is 
> the address;
>
> www.karl-bartos.de

Nice site. And if you click on the "LIVE" portion of the site, there's 
a small facsimile of the poster for his London gig, which clearly says 
"KARL BARTOS" across the top.

I understand CWP's position and the talking-up it requires to be a 
successful promoter. I'm in marketing, have done a fair bit of 
promotional work myself, and know how brutal the market is out there, 
especially now with people spending less on events than they used to. 
But there's no rationalization for lying to the people whose money you 
rely on, especially when you have recurring events and hope to keep 
bringing us back.

  - omid

>From: Coolworld <cwpsf@yahoo.com>
>To: Omid Tavallai <otavallai@mac.com>
>CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] CYBERFEST 2003
>Date: Wed, 23 Jul 2003 10:27:14 -0700 (PDT)
>
>Just to clarify a couple of issues, I'm going to post Karl's Bio so that 
>you can read for yourself. If you still feel mislead, we extend our 
>apoligies. However, Karl is performing as Kraftwerk and will be with his 
>new band / group of musicians performing ALL KRAFTWERK hits & New Material.
>
>If you would like to go to his own web-site and check it out, here is the 
>address;
>
>www.karl-bartos.de
>
>Karl Bartos Bio:
>
>Hardly any other name in German popmusic is as much a synonym for 
>electronic lifestyle as Karl Bartos. Not only his work as a member of 
>Kraftwerk, but also his co-operation with local and international artists 
>show him as an icon of a worldwide movement in music. Now, the pioneer of 
>electronic music is back to be heard and seen live.
>
>As co-author of known Kraftwerk titles as "The Robots", "The Model", 
>"Pocket Calculator" or "Tour de France", Karl Bartos set the foundation for 
>the world-wide success of German Techno-Pop a la Kraftwerk. Countless bands 
>such as Depeche Mode, OMD, The Human League, but also the complete 
>Techno-Dance movement never seize to stress the importance of Kraftwerk's 
>influence on their creative work.
>
>Bartos belongs to the rare German Pop-icons who enjoy the highest 
>international recognition. His authenticity as one of the founders of a 
>particular German genre makes him as hip as ever.
>
>As a classically trained drummer and keyboarder, Bartos' influence is 
>evident on the music of Kraftwerk. The godfathers of US-HipHop such as 
>Africa Bambaataa & The Soul Sonic Force, but also the protagonists of the 
>early Detroit Housegrooves have picked up his typical electro beats. With 
>the international success of German Dancemusic, the quality of electronic 
>lifestyle from Germany (co-founded by Bartos) is confirmed until this day.
>
>His activities as author and producer lead him to world-wide successful 
>co-operations with OMD (Andy McCluskey) and Electronic (Bernard Sumner / 
>Johnny Marr), The Mobile Homes (Sweden), and Anthony Rother and Deine 
>Lakaien from Germany, as well as records of his own project titled 
>"Electric Music".
>
>A suprise-gig as electronic DJ in August 1999 at the "Kickzone"-Festival 
>during the PopKomm in Cologne gained him excellent critics for Bartos the 
>starting-signal for new live plans.
>
>Accompanied by a keyboarder Bartos' live-set is composed of newly arranged 
>solo-titles and some premiers. Thus "Man Machine", "Metropolis", "Techno 
>Pop" and "The Telephone Call" have never been performed live before further 
>Kraftwerk songs have been digitally optimized for stage conditions. The 
>previously unreleased track "15 Minutes of Fame" will be complemented with 
>further new compositions, inspired by the atmosphere of a live audience and 
>set to be captured on an upcoming album.
>
>Visually Bartos will be supported by the work of Cologne video artist 
>Karsten Binar who created video loops, illustrating on big TV screens the 
>classics of Electro-Pop bartos live.
>
>COOLWORLD
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>

Omid, no one is trying to falsely market you. I'm sorry that you feel that way. We are producing a show, Karl Bartos is performing as Kraftwerk with his new band.
 
It's not that far fetch since he's doing the same thing in other markets.
 
Coolworld isn't trying to make you believe something that isn't happening, thus were completely upfront with you on this list and on our advertisements.
 
The first initial emails you read were not meant to mis-lead you, hence we've been very forthcoming and have billed the artist and group appropriately.
 
In addition, lets not jump to conclusions on intentions, as i know nothing has been marketing with malice or ill intent.
 
If you would like to discuss this off list, i would be happy to answer any questions.
 
Thanks for your time...
 
COOLWORLD

>To: Omid Tavallai 
>CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] CYBERFEST 2003
>Date: Wed, 23 Jul 2003 10:27:14 -0700 (PDT)
>
>Just to clarify a couple of issues, I'm going to post Karl's Bio so that 
>you can read for yourself. If you still feel mislead, we extend our 
>apoligies. However, Karl is performing as Kraftwerk and will be with his 
>new band / group of musicians performing ALL KRAFTWERK hits & New Material.
>
>If you would like to go to his own web-site and check it out, here is the 
>address;
>
>www.karl-bartos.de
>
>Karl Bartos Bio:
>
>Hardly any other name in German popmusic is as much a synonym for 
>electronic lifestyle as Karl Bartos. Not only his work as a member of 
>Kraftwerk, but also his co-operation with local and international artists 
>show him as an icon of a worldwide movement in music. Now, the pioneer of 
>electronic music is back to be heard and seen live.
>
>As co-author of known Kraftwerk titles as "The Robots", "The Model", 
>"Pocket Calculator" or "Tour de France", Karl Bartos set the foundation for 
>the world-wide success of German Techno-Pop a la Kraftwerk. Countless bands 
>such as Depeche Mode, OMD, The Human League, but also the complete 
>Techno-Dance movement never seize to stress the importance of Kraftwerk's 
>influence on their creative work.
>
>Bartos belongs to the rare German Pop-icons who enjoy the highest 
>international recognition. His authenticity as one of the founders of a 
>particular German genre makes him as hip as ever.
>
>As a classically trained drummer and keyboarder, Bartos' influence is 
>evident on the music of Kraftwerk. The godfathers of US-HipHop such as 
>Africa Bambaataa & The Soul Sonic Force, but also the protagonists of the 
>early Detroit Housegrooves have picked up his typical electro beats. With 
>the international success of German Dancemusic, the quality of electronic 
>lifestyle from Germany (co-founded by Bartos) is confirmed until this day.
>
>His activities as author and producer lead him to world-wide successful 
>co-operations with OMD (Andy McCluskey) and Electronic (Bernard Sumner / 
>Johnny Marr), The Mobile Homes (Sweden), and Anthony Rother and Deine 
>Lakaien from Germany, as well as records of his own project titled 
>"Electric Music".
>
>A suprise-gig as electronic DJ in August 1999 at the "Kickzone"-Festival 
>during the PopKomm in Cologne gained him excellent critics for Bartos the 
>starting-signal for new live plans.
>
>Accompanied by a keyboarder Bartos' live-set is composed of newly arranged 
>solo-titles and some premiers. Thus "Man Machine", "Metropolis", "Techno 
>Pop" and "The Telephone Call" have never been performed live before further 
>Kraftwerk songs have been digitally optimized for stage conditions. The 
>previously unreleased track "15 Minutes of Fame" will be complemented with 
>further new compositions, inspired by the atmosphere of a live audience and 
>set to be captured on an upcoming album.
>
>Visually Bartos will be supported by the work of Cologne video artist 
>Karsten Binar who created video loops, illustrating on big TV screens the 
>classics of Electro-Pop bartos live.
>
>COOLWORLD
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>
>Omid Tavallai wrote:
>
>On Wednesday, July 23, 2003, at 09:15 AM, shawn allen wrote:
>
> > quoth Coolworld:
> >> ALREADY CONFIRMED
> >>
> >> Kraftwerk's Original Member Karl Bartos
> >
> > So, does this mean Kraftwerk *won't* be performing? Because Karl Bartos
> > isn't even part of the group anymore. I'm not looking for a reason to
> > rag on Coolworld here -- I just know a lot of people that bought
> > tickets
> > exclusively because they thought Kraftwerk would be performing.
>
>That's precisely what I thought when I saw the BSP and an announcement
>on another list that Kraftwerk's new album is finally out - Karl Bartos
>was the name noticeably absent from the Kraftwerk announcement. This is
>precisely the type of bullshit that kept me from buying an advance
>ticket, and despite what looks to be a good lineup, will prevent me
>from going at all. Not that I like massives much to begin with, but
>such marketing practices will NOT be supported by my pocketbook.
>
>I'm sure Cyberfest will be a blast, even without Kraftwerk. Personally,
>it was hard for me to even imagine a bunch of kiddies getting down to
>"Autobahn" or whatnot, so I know that KW would've been the main
>attraction for a handful of us geezers anyhow. But this about seals the
>deal for me. I'm never believing promoters again. After getting burned
>on supposed appearances by Daft Punk, Groove Armada and others, I'm
>only going to rely on Pollstar to check booking accuracy for
>too-big-to-be-true acts from now on.
>
>Coolworld Productions - here's a tip: Next time, do the listing like
>this
>
>KARL BARTOS (Kraftwerk, Germany)
>
>His name still carries enough weight with KW fans, and you'd get a
>helluva lot more respect from the bitchers and moaners (myself
>included) on this list and elsewhere.
>
>- omid

From: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

In-Reply-To: <20030723172714.40560.qmail@web40020.mail.yahoo.com>
User-Agent: Mutt/1.4i
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] CYBERFEST 2003

quoth Coolworld:
> Just to clarify a couple of issues, I'm going to post Karl's Bio so
> that you can read for yourself. If you still feel mislead, we extend
> our apoligies. However, Karl is performing as Kraftwerk and will be
> with his new band / group of musicians performing ALL KRAFTWERK hits &
> New Material.

No doubt Karl Bartos is an awesome musician. Not only did he do some
incredible work with Hutter, Schneider and Flur as Kraftwerk, but he's
also done some really interesting collaborations with members of New
Order and The Smiths. And some of his newer stuff is being distributed
by Kompakt, one of my favorite german "tech-pop" labels.

HOWEVER, Karl has not -- to my knowledge -- had anything to do with (or
performed as) Kraftwerk for over 11 years. I find it really hard to
believe that the remaining (and founding) members would give the rights
to the band name to him for the purpose of performance... Otherwise you
wouldn't be saying "Kraftwerk's Original Member Karl Bartos" -- you'd
just be saying "Kraftwerk".

Furthermore, Karl is *not* an original member of the band; in fact he
was the *last* of the four to join the ever-fluctuating roster before
the '74-'86 string of hits that put them on the map. I'm not trying to
downplay his significant contributions to the band, but saying he's an
"original member" is just factually inaccurate.

Sorry to split hairs here, but I really think your use of Karl's name
and that of Kraftwerk so interchangably is very misleading. I would
appreciate it if you changed the BSP. Omid's suggestion of "Karl Bartos
(Kraftwerk, Germany)" is much more appropriate, IMO.

Thanks,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Subject: [sfraves] paradigm shift review...

so... i probably should have stayed home cuz i needed
the rest, and i'd cut my foot swimming and was limping
around :(  but... i needed to dance and i need my
techno fix so i went to check this out.  was it worth
it?  well, i really enjoyed forest and andy w
tag-teaming.  got to dance for a while, and it was
great because they actually played some detroit and
were mixing different styles together.  but the rest
of the time?  i found the music rather boring -
straight-ahead techno, all pretty similar.  don't get
me wrong - i LOVE techno, but i guess i've just got
different techno tastes than most of sf, alas.  

granted, i did miss clarity/j-bot and yap, all of whom
i'd wanted to check out.  don't know if they played
any differently.  

i did appreciate the effort that went into the party -
the food, coffee bar (!!!!!!), etc, tho' $15 still
seemed rather steep.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] CYBERFEST 2003

I was writing up my own reply but Shawn summed it up perfectly.  It's 
all pretty much semantics from here on out, and all I simply ask for is 
  accuracy in promoting. When good information is available, it's wrong 
not to use it.

In terms of CWP's repeated requests to take further inquiries off-list 
- I appreciate the effort to reduce list "noise" and squabbling, but I 
personally think that the integrity of BSPs are of interest to the 
community at large, no matter who they come from.

This thread is not about any sort of public mudslinging. As I've said, 
I'm sure this Cyberfest will be as good a time as 'fests of the past. 
However, I think the public discourse on what I (and others) feel is a 
misleading practice will only serve everyone.

You listening, other promoters? This isn't just about CWP, and I hope 
you don't feel singled out.  ;)

  - omid

> I was writing up my own reply but Shawn summed it up perfectly.  It's 
> all pretty much semantics from here on out, and all I simply ask for 
> is  accuracy in promoting. When good information is available, it's 
> wrong not to use it.
>
> In terms of CWP's repeated requests to take further inquiries off-list 
> - I appreciate the effort to reduce list "noise" and squabbling, but I 
> personally think that the integrity of BSPs are of interest to the 
> community at large, no matter who they come from.
>
> This thread is not about any sort of public mudslinging. As I've said, 
> I'm sure this Cyberfest will be as good a time as 'fests of the past. 
> However, I think the public discourse on what I (and others) feel is a 
> misleading practice will only serve everyone.
>
> You listening, other promoters? This isn't just about CWP, and I hope 
> you don't feel singled out.  ;)
>
>  - omid

Subject: Re: [sfraves] more on pangea...

Monika,

Nothing in the BSP made any mention of gender; both men and women can 
dress as porn stars, can they not?  Furthermore, no one is being forced 
or compelled to dress as a pornstar.  Given this, I fail to see any 
exploitation occurring in this instance.  In fact, it seems to me that 
Sintaxxx is actually interrogating traditional notions of gender, 
sexuality, and pornography with this event by de- and 
re-contextualizing pornographic imagery and icons in the context of an 
electronic music event.

Exploitation would be telling people that a certain act was performing, 
only to later reveal that in fact only a portion of the act would 
actually be in attendance.

-- Jonathan

Date: Wed, 23 Jul 2003 15:26:46 EDT
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: "Intelect" House Documentary

--part1_2b.44aa06ca.2c503b76_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I just picked up this DVD called Intelect and It must be fairly new because I 
hadn't heard of it until I saw it the other day at Suncoast video. It a 
techno/progressive house documentary. They Interview like 60 house & techno DJ's 
about different people's opinion on what DJing is about and the what's all goes 
on behind the scenes in the industry. 
It's funny to see how pretentious and arrogant some DJ's are compared to 
other DJ's who are modest and are willing to explain exactly what it is that they 
do and how easy it really is. I mean they also tell you how hard it can be and 
certain situations that can happen that will be frustrating, which is 
understandable. 
There's this one guy who says he prefers to do his live set in another room 
or from the basement because all he does is twiddle around with knobs and 
program sounds on his laptop, and he doesn't understand why people always insist to 
see him play live lol hahahahah. See now that's modesty that guy is the shit! 
He spins from the fucking basement lol hahahaha while people dance on the 
upper floor. Actually I think he spins IDM music so they probably don't even 
dance but oh well I think that concept is hilarious. 
Then there's another disc which is a full hands on DJ instructional video 
with Nigel Richards and he is great. I mean he doesn't assume that you know 
anything about DJing at all, he explains even the most tinyest details about it 
that you probably already know but maybe someone else doesn't know. I it's like 
two hours full of every trick in the book about DJing from hooking up the 
equipment to beat matching and pitch control. At one point it seems like he is 
subtley making a reference to this little compartment on a tecnics turntable where 
you can keep an E pill... Is that true? 
Anyway I think this is the best yet rave related documentary, there's a 
really good interview with Mars as well as Dyloot where they even talk about the 
whole candy trance scene and It's hilarious to watch but they are really sincere 
people tho you can tell, I don't know why people talk so much shit about 
those guys. The movie start out a lil dry and boring but if you just let it keep 
going and keep watching it, it just keeps getting more interesting... and all 
the SF scene stuff is at the end of it. I don't think any other documentary has 
touched on the SF scene like this one yet. So check it out yo.

--part1_2b.44aa06ca.2c503b76_boundary--

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
From: max phillips <teknobuddha@juno.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] What difference does it make? (Art of Live PA): ATTITUDE MAKES THE DIFFERENCE!!!

   "Gianni  ;0)      <-------Has been easing 
a lot 
of Top Raman"


 Top Ramen, Mauchan, it's a, who ever has them 10 for a buck, kind of
economy. Not good for the bowels, but it streaches the $5 you have to get
through the week!



 "Ladies and gentlemen, I'm throwing my hat in to the
 electronic trance music.
 Seems no promoter is interested to support this bay
 area silicon valley
 producer. I've fought long and hard, the good lord
 (and you promoters) knows
 how
 much $ i've been spilling to try to make a
 difference.."


 If every starving artist had this kind of attitude, would we have art
today? Our art galleries would be empty, the book shelves in book stores
would have no books, and radio stations would be all right wing talk
shows!

 I know what it means to be discouraged, but there is something in me
that tell's me not to give up, even if it's a Top Ramen Noodle kind of
day.
 
 If you fail, is it you who failed, or are you blaming others? Here's the
cosmic deal. When you get up in the morning, you have two choices: face
the day with an attitude of fear and say you won't make it, or face the
day with an attitude of somehow, someway, I'll get through. I've made it
this far haven't I? Your personal reality is in your mind. Everything has
karmic consequences. If I choose to live in the attitude of fear, then I
will attract people and situations that will confirm my attitude. If I
choose to live in the attitude of faith, then I will attract people and
situations that will confirm my faith. I'm not talking about this phoney
"name it and claim it" faith, but real faith that recognizes life will
work out if we let go and let life happen in life's own time and own way.
I may not get every thing I want, but I know I'll get what I need. Maybe
what I need now may not be recognition or instant fame, but It may be
other things that pertain to the soul or what's going on inside me and
what's in my mind.
 
A famous prophet once said, "seek first the kingdom of god ( who ever
"god" is to you) and his/her rightousness, and all these things
(electronic music career) will be added to you.
 The electronic music scene is full of big $$$ rock stars and super stars
and people inspiring to be big $$$ rock/super stars, that, in my opinion
is one of the major reasons for the down fall or the rave scene and the
infusion of cheezy, mass produced electronic music. We have too many
D.J.'s inspiring to be big $$$ rock stars and very few in it for the love
of the scene and the people. Again, that cosmic law of the universe,
karma. If you go into this with an attitude to be famous and rich, then
you choose to be in that reality whose karma is competitive, cut throat
and the odds are against you. If you go in this with an attitude to give
my talents to the world and particularly the rave scene as an offering of
love and healing (boy do we need love and healers in these days!), then
you choose to be in that reality whose karma may not get famous and rich,
but will give you happiness and satisfaction, which all the money and
fame can never give you, and in time all these things "will be added to
you". If you get fortune and fame, you won't become an ass-hole about it,
which means if you are an ass-hole, you are not happy.
 
Maybe you need to stop fighting and start living. Just do it for the
love. You don't even know what doors will open for you if you do it
life's way! Karma, karma, karma!!!!

 Right now as I'm writing this, I have no job, the job market is tuff and
I have 2 months of unemployment left and the little money I get barely
pays the rent and I have a lot more 10 for a buck meals. Hopefully, EDD
will accept my schooling application which means I can go to school and
collect unemployment until April of next year. I may not get accepted,
but I try not to start my day in fear over this and my employment issues
because if I do, I will set in motion the karma consequences of fear and
I'll be like someone with a tire stuck in the mud,  spinning my wheels
out or frustration and anger, and in the end, having flat tires and no
gas (depression) and have gone no where. If I get rejected, I know life
has another way of taking care of me. Faith allows me to let go and give
life an opportunity to provide rocks, sticks, what ever I need to get out
of the hole.

 So, if you give up, that is your choice. Like Gianni sayz... "suck it
up!" We all have our problems and we don't get all we want, but we don't
give up. I can "suck it up" with Gianni because eventually it does work
out. May not be what we like or want, but things work out. Accepting that
is real faith. 

 I love to spin records, but I haven't bought records in 2 years! I have
a cheezy $75 shredder mixer and a turn table with a bad arm. When I moved
here from Arizona 3 years ago, my "D.J. career" came to an abrupt end. I
know people who recently bought nice $1,000 mixers, new 1200's and can
keep up their record collections. Am I depressed? Some times. But, thanks
to unemployment, I've had the time to ponder the mysteries of life, and
part of my spiritual awakenings is the realization that I know this is
happening for a reason. If I'm meant to have a "D.J. career", it will
happen when it's supost to happen and let it go. Faith is understanding
there is a reason for this to happen, and when I learn my lessons, it
will all come together for me again. I choose by my attitude what reality
I will have and the karma that it brings. If I come up again as a D.J.,
attitude will bring the karma for that to happen. Find your own
righteousness, and all these things will be added to you!

 Peace, Bodhi ^_^

Omid Tavallai <otavallai@mac.com> wrote:
I was writing up my own reply but Shawn summed it up perfectly. It's 
all pretty much semantics from here on out, and all I simply ask for is 
accuracy in promoting. When good information is available, it's wrong 
not to use it.

In terms of CWP's repeated requests to take further inquiries off-list 
- I appreciate the effort to reduce list "noise" and squabbling, but I 
personally think that the integrity of BSPs are of interest to the 
community at large, no matter who they come from.

This thread is not about any sort of public mudslinging. As I've said, 
I'm sure this Cyberfest will be as good a time as 'fests of the past. 
However, I think the public discourse on what I (and others) feel is a 
misleading practice will only serve everyone.

You listening, other promoters? This isn't just about CWP, and I hope 
you don't feel singled out. ;)

- omid

Subject: Re: [sfraves] What difference does it make? (Art of Live PA): ATTITUDE MAKES THE DIFFERENCE!!!

I WISH PROMOTORS WOULD JUST DROP THEIR "I'M TOO BUSY ATTITUDE" AND PAY ATTENTION TO THOSE WHO ARE TRYING TO COME UP IN THE BAY...INSTEAD OF BOOKING SOMEONE LIKE KRAFTWERK WHO'S LIKE 80 YEARS OLD, WHO HAVE A NITCHED MARKET, AND KIDS THAT GO TO COOLWORLD EVENTS DON'T CARE, THEY GO BECAUSE THEY KNOW IT'S GONNA BE A BIG FESTIVAL... AS IF ANYONE REALLY CARES ABOUT ME, OR THAT OTHER LIVE PA DOOD ON HERE I WANT TO CONTACT, BUT DAMN GIVE US SOME LOVE!!! STOP THE HATE, MOTIVATE!!!

Dominic Son aka Reflector
Reflect Records
www.reflectnow.com


>>"Ladies and gentlemen, I'm throwing my hat in to the
electronic trance music.
Seems no promoter is interested to support this bay
area silicon valley
producer. I've fought long and hard, the good lord
(and you promoters) knows
how
much $ i've been spilling to try to make a
difference.."

>
If every starving artist had this kind of attitude, would we have art
today? Our art galleries would be empty, the book shelves in book stores
would have no books, and radio stations would be all right wing talk
shows!

I know what it means to be discouraged, but there is something in me
that tell's me not to give up, even if it's a Top Ramen Noodle kind of
day.

If you fail, is it you who failed, or are you blaming others? Here's the
cosmic deal. When you get up in the morning, you have two choices: face
the day with an attitude of fear and say you won't make it, or face the
day with an attitude of somehow, someway, I'll get through. I've made it
this far haven't I? Your personal reality is in your mind. Everything has
karmic consequences. If I choose to live in the attitude of fear, then I
will attract people and situations that will confirm my attitude. If I
choose to live in the attitude of faith, then I will attract people and
situations that will confirm my faith. I'm not talking about this phoney
"name it and claim it" faith, but real faith that recognizes life will
work out if we let go and let life happen in life's own time and own way.
I may not get every thing I want, but I know I'll get what I need. Maybe
what I need now may not be recognition or instant fame, but It may be
other things that pertain to the soul or what's going on inside me and
what's in my mind.

A famous prophet once said, "seek first the kingdom of god ( who ever
"god" is to you) and his/her rightousness, and all these things
(electronic music career) will be added to you.
The electronic music scene is full of big $$$ rock stars and super stars
and people inspiring to be big $$$ rock/super stars, that, in my opinion
is one of the major reasons for the down fall or the rave scene and the
infusion of cheezy, mass produced electronic music. We have too many
D.J.'s inspiring to be big $$$ rock stars and very few in it for the love
of the scene and the people. Again, that cosmic law of the universe,
karma. If you go into this with an attitude to be famous and rich, then
you choose to be in that reality whose karma is competitive, cut throat
and the odds are against you. If you go in this with an attitude to give
my talents to the world and particularly the rave scene as an offering of
love and healing (boy do we need love and healers in these days!), then
you choose to be in that reality whose karma may not get famous and rich,
but will give you happiness and satisfaction, which all the money and
fame can never give you, and in time all these things "will be added to
you". If you get fortune and fame, you won't become an ass-hole about it,
which means if you are an ass-hole, you are not happy.

Maybe you need to stop fighting and start living. Just do it for the
love. You don't even know what doors will open for you if you do it
life's way! Karma, karma, karma!!!!

Right now as I'm writing this, I have no job, the job market is tuff and
I have 2 months of unemployment left and the little money I get barely
pays the rent and I have a lot more 10 for a buck meals. Hopefully, EDD
will accept my schooling application which means I can go to school and
collect unemployment until April of next year. I may not get accepted,
but I try not to start my day in fear over this and my employment issues
because if I do, I will set in motion the karma consequences of fear and
I'll be like someone with a tire stuck in the mud,  spinning my wheels
out or frustration and anger, and in the end, having flat tires and no
gas (depression) and have gone no where. If I get rejected, I know life
has another way of taking care of me. Faith allows me to let go and give
life an opportunity to provide rocks, sticks, what ever I need to get out
of the hole.

So, if you give up, that is your choice. Like Gianni sayz... "suck it
up!" We all have our problems and we don't get all we want, but we don't
give up. I can "suck it up" with Gianni because eventually it does work
out. May not be what we like or want, but things work out. Accepting that
is real faith. 

I love to spin records, but I haven't bought records in 2 years! I have
a cheezy $75 shredder mixer and a turn table with a bad arm. When I moved
here from Arizona 3 years ago, my "D.J. career" came to an abrupt end. I
know people who recently bought nice $1,000 mixers, new 1200's and can
keep up their record collections. Am I depressed? Some times. But, thanks
to unemployment, I've had the time to ponder the mysteries of life, and
part of my spiritual awakenings is the realization that I know this is
happening for a reason. If I'm meant to have a "D.J. career", it will
happen when it's supost to happen and let it go. Faith is understanding
there is a reason for this to happen, and when I learn my lessons, it
will all come together for me again. I choose by my attitude what reality
I will have and the karma that it brings. If I come up again as a D.J.,
attitude will bring the karma for that to happen. Find your own
righteousness, and all these things will be added to you!

Peace, Bodhi ^_^

One guy who would *NEVER* go to a rave, was all like "I want to see Kraftwerk!" ( I mostly go to ug's since scope closed and I think Coolworld Parties are fun, so sue me! ) And as a graphic designer, I don't know if I personaly would have chosen to phrase it EXACTLY the way it is on the flyer, but I have seen more misleading things from people bigger than coolworld, and I have also seen band members do EVEN MORE misleading things to the promoters, that have resultied in trashed press runs and recalled flyers for legal reasons ( NOT BY ME! This is why I am willing to explin to my client 300 times that we can't use SOMEBODY ELSE'S image. ) ! ( this is why I would have phrased it differently, see?) But you know, bands break up,  and there are disputes over names, it is just a fact of life.

Karma, karma, karma!!!


On Wed, 23 Jul 2003 16:58:40 -0400 DeezzerRec@aol.com writes:
>I WISH PROMOTORS WOULD JUST DROP THEIR "I'M TOO BUSY ATTITUDE" AND PAY 
>ATTENTION TO THOSE WHO ARE TRYING TO COME UP IN THE BAY...INSTEAD OF 
>BOOKING SOMEONE LIKE KRAFTWERK WHO'S LIKE 80 YEARS OLD, WHO HAVE A 
>NITCHED MARKET, AND KIDS THAT GO TO COOLWORLD EVENTS DON'T CARE, THEY 
>GO BECAUSE THEY KNOW IT'S GONNA BE A BIG FESTIVAL... AS IF ANYONE 
>REALLY CARES ABOUT ME, OR THAT OTHER LIVE PA DOOD ON HERE I WANT TO 
>CONTACT, BUT DAMN GIVE US SOME LOVE!!! STOP THE HATE, MOTIVATE!!!
>
>All I've been tryin to say...is we must have more pride here. We have 
>the right to be heard, our beloved bay...
>
>Dominic Son aka Reflector
>Reflect Records
>www.reflectnow.com
>
>
>>>"Ladies and gentlemen, I'm throwing my hat in to the
>electronic trance music.
>Seems no promoter is interested to support this bay
>area silicon valley
>producer. I've fought long and hard, the good lord
>(and you promoters) knows
>how
>much $ i've been spilling to try to make a
>difference.."
>
>>
>If every starving artist had this kind of attitude, would we have art
>today? Our art galleries would be empty, the book shelves in book 
>stores
>would have no books, and radio stations would be all right wing talk
>shows!
>
>I know what it means to be discouraged, but there is something in me
>that tell's me not to give up, even if it's a Top Ramen Noodle kind of
>day.
>
>If you fail, is it you who failed, or are you blaming others? Here's 
>the
>cosmic deal. When you get up in the morning, you have two choices: 
>face
>the day with an attitude of fear and say you won't make it, or face 
>the
>day with an attitude of somehow, someway, I'll get through. I've made 
>it
>this far haven't I? Your personal reality is in your mind. Everything 
>has
>karmic consequences. If I choose to live in the attitude of fear, then 
>I
>will attract people and situations that will confirm my attitude. If I
>choose to live in the attitude of faith, then I will attract people 
>and
>situations that will confirm my faith. I'm not talking about this 
>phoney
>"name it and claim it" faith, but real faith that recognizes life will
>work out if we let go and let life happen in life's own time and own 
>way.
>I may not get every thing I want, but I know I'll get what I need. 
>Maybe
>what I need now may not be recognition or instant fame, but It may be
>other things that pertain to the soul or what's going on inside me and
>what's in my mind.
>
>A famous prophet once said, "seek first the kingdom of god ( who ever
>"god" is to you) and his/her rightousness, and all these things
>(electronic music career) will be added to you.
>The electronic music scene is full of big $$$ rock stars and super 
>stars
>and people inspiring to be big $$$ rock/super stars, that, in my 
>opinion
>is one of the major reasons for the down fall or the rave scene and 
>the
>infusion of cheezy, mass produced electronic music. We have too many
>D.J.'s inspiring to be big $$$ rock stars and very few in it for the 
>love
>of the scene and the people. Again, that cosmic law of the universe,
>karma. If you go into this with an attitude to be famous and rich, 
>then
>you choose to be in that reality whose karma is competitive, cut 
>throat
>and the odds are against you. If you go in this with an attitude to 
>give
>my talents to the world and particularly the rave scene as an offering 
>of
>love and healing (boy do we need love and healers in these days!), 
>then
>you choose to be in that reality whose karma may not get famous and 
>rich,
>but will give you happiness and satisfaction, which all the money and
>fame can never give you, and in time all these things "will be added 
>to
>you". If you get fortune and fame, you won't become an ass-hole about 
>it,
>which means if you are an ass-hole, you are not happy.
>
>Maybe you need to stop fighting and start living. Just do it for the
>love. You don't even know what doors will open for you if you do it
>life's way! Karma, karma, karma!!!!
>
>Right now as I'm writing this, I have no job, the job market is tuff 
>and
>I have 2 months of unemployment left and the little money I get barely
>pays the rent and I have a lot more 10 for a buck meals. Hopefully, 
>EDD
>will accept my schooling application which means I can go to school 
>and
>collect unemployment until April of next year. I may not get accepted,
>but I try not to start my day in fear over this and my employment 
>issues
>because if I do, I will set in motion the karma consequences of fear 
>and
>I'll be like someone with a tire stuck in the mud,  spinning my wheels
>out or frustration and anger, and in the end, having flat tires and no
>gas (depression) and have gone no where. If I get rejected, I know 
>life
>has another way of taking care of me. Faith allows me to let go and 
>give
>life an opportunity to provide rocks, sticks, what ever I need to get 
>out
>of the hole.
>
>So, if you give up, that is your choice. Like Gianni sayz... "suck it
>up!" We all have our problems and we don't get all we want, but we 
>don't
>give up. I can "suck it up" with Gianni because eventually it does 
>work
>out. May not be what we like or want, but things work out. Accepting 
>that
>is real faith. 
>
>I love to spin records, but I haven't bought records in 2 years! I 
>have
>a cheezy $75 shredder mixer and a turn table with a bad arm. When I 
>moved
>here from Arizona 3 years ago, my "D.J. career" came to an abrupt end. 
>I
>know people who recently bought nice $1,000 mixers, new 1200's and can
>keep up their record collections. Am I depressed? Some times. But, 
>thanks
>to unemployment, I've had the time to ponder the mysteries of life, 
>and
>part of my spiritual awakenings is the realization that I know this is
>happening for a reason. If I'm meant to have a "D.J. career", it will
>happen when it's supost to happen and let it go. Faith is 
>understanding
>there is a reason for this to happen, and when I learn my lessons, it
>will all come together for me again. I choose by my attitude what 
>reality
>I will have and the karma that it brings. If I come up again as a 
>D.J.,
>attitude will bring the karma for that to happen. Find your own
>righteousness, and all these things will be added to you!
>
>Peace, Bodhi ^_^
>
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------
>To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>
>

good points..someone else mentioned inner eye parties...how about all the silver pearl stuff too? or rather most of it..not all of it...quest...why can't we just discontinue the gross parts and keep the good? if things 
remain completely underground, it keeps things special, but also, if things are too hidden, then people 
can't thrive, and then things get shut down. there's a lot of good things going on these days. there are a lot of single event kind of things going on, and clubs galore are opening up too. it's kind of like a candy store. also too, just for the record, my taste in clothing has absolutely nothing to do with religion or anyone else's fetish of the moment.  :)
Monique Wolfe <mdwolfe19@hotmail.com> wrote:
not only is 4 or 5 years a long time,.. but also, the music itself has this 
incredible ability to change so much over a short period of time. Trance 
alone has definitely come a longgggggg way. Even though a lot of it is oober 
cheesy nowadays, every now and then comes out a pretty descent track that 
eventually becomes a classic. Gotta love the music :)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] cyberfest/kraftwerk

quoth Giles Bowkett:
> it sounds like the kraftwerk thing might have more to do with band
> breakup drama than anything coolworld was responsible for. like he's
> the only KW member there, and the other guys are doing work without
> him, yet they say it's all Kraftwerk material and the set will be
> recorded for a live album? will it be a Kraftwerk live album?

Not quite. Karl Bartos left (along with Wolfgang Flur) around '92.
Granted, Kraftwerk as a band hasn't put out anything worth listening to
since then (celebrity remixes of Expo 2000 nonwithstanding), but that
shit's old news. Breakup drama doesn't usually last 11 years, right?

But you're right in some respects, this is starting to sound like a
legal issue. Did Karl get booked as Kraftwerk (with the band's
permission), or is Coolworld just using his involvement with the group
to sell tickets?

Regardless, the man was one of the most influential members of the group
during their most prolific period. He had a hand in most of the tracks
that originally defined techno as a musical genre, ideology, and
cultural movement. So, if you're really interested in seeing your
favorite Kraftwerk tracks performed live by one of the "godfathers of
techno", you should still at least consider going. ;)

Just trying to be diplomatic,
-- 
shawn allen
  mailto://shawn@alterior.net
  phone://+1.415.577.3961
  http://alterior.net
  aim://shawnpallen

Date: Wed, 23 Jul 2003 18:17:42 -0700
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII; format=flowed
Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v552)
From: jonathan.dawgbuddha <jonathan@dawgbuddha.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
In-Reply-To: <20030723200756.41718.qmail@web40014.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-Id: <9FBDB6BC-BD74-11D7-BE3E-000A9589F740@dawgbuddha.net>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.552)
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Coolworld LIES! 


On Wednesday, July 23, 2003, at 01:07  PM, Coolworld wrote:

> Actually omid, no ones trying to sweep anything under the rug here, 
> simply trying not to over sensationalize something that is in a 
> difference in opinion, both professionally and personally.
>

Hmm... that's an interesting way to characterize it.  "A difference of 
opinion?"  A difference of opinion is whether or not you like chocolate 
or not; a difference of opinion is whether you vote Democrat or 
Republican (or Green, or what have you).  A difference of opinion is 
NOT the difference between the band, Kraftwerk, and one of its members. 
  That is a difference of fact.  Either all the current members of the 
band known as Kraftwerk will be at the Cow Palace on September 20th, or 
they won't.  If indeed Coolworld Productions knew that on September 
20th only Karl Bartos and not the other members of Kraftwerk would be 
performing and nevertheless advertised that Kraftwerk would be in 
attendance, that's LYING.  When corporate entities engage in this sort 
of behavior in television, radio, or print ads, it's known as false 
advertising.  In those media, there are laws and regulations 
prohibiting that sort of behavior.  Furthermore, if Coolworld 
Productions allowed tickets to be sold to people who believed they were 
seeing Kraftwerk when in fact CWP knew that only Karl Bartos would be 
attending, that's FRAUD.


> I admire your persistence and need to make sure Coolworld presents an 
> honest depiction of it's event, so i simply asked you to take it on a 
> private level.

In other words, Coolworld is aware that their behavior is bordering on 
illegal and doesn't want anyone to know about it.

> I don't think thats too much to ask?

Actually, it IS too much to ask.  It's not as if Coolworld has made any 
sort of apology for their blatant deception or in any way owned up to 
their behavior; their responses to this thread have been further 
obfuscation.  Note their reply which says that Karl Bartos will be 
performing "as Kraftwerk."  Even after their Blatantly Scurrilous 
Perjury has been exposed, they continue to attempt to perpetuate it!  
Look at Monique's post about how she was unable to find any of the 
supposed $25 tickets, and then look at the post from Coolworld that was 
just sent to the list, wherein Coolworld maintains that $25 tickets are 
still available!   It's not as if these greedy corporate entities learn 
from their mistakes.  Not even a day has gone by since they were caught 
in a lie, and they're already fabricating another one.  Too much to 
ask?  TOO MUCH TO ASK?  Is it too much to ask that if you're going to 
make money from OUR community and OUR music, that you at least do it 
honestly?  Is it too much to ask that if you're going to appropriate 
our ideology and imagery for your mega-corporate carnivals that you at 
least treat us with a modicum of respect?

If Coolworld was really serious about putting this embarrassing episode 
behind them, they would offer, PUBLICLY, refunds for anyone who bought 
tickets thinking they were going to see Kraftwerk.  Somehow, though, I 
don't think that's going to happen.

-- Jonathan

On Wed, 23 Jul 2003, Coolworld wrote:
-&e->Actually omid, no ones trying to sweep anything under the rug here,
-&e->simply trying not to over sensationalize something that is in a
-&e->difference in opinion, both professionally and personally.

You guys are being upfront well before the show, so that's cool in my
book.

-&e-> I think 10 threads is pretty sufficient?

Whatever it takes.  The larger your promotion and party... the larger the
discussion.  The more you promise the world, the more a natural increase
in skepticism.  You guys signed up for the big time, not me.  I could get
mad (about the fact that my last car's window derailed from how hard one
of your flyer peeps shoved your foldout into my window jam but I'm over it
now even thought I wasn't even parked anywhere near a club or party at the
time).

-&e-> I admire your persistence and need to make sure Coolworld presents
-&e->an honest depiction of it's event, so i simply asked you to take it
-&e->on a private level.

Asking questions publicly to the benefit of the public as a response to a
public advertisment is totally fair game.  this is not an advertisement
list, it's a discussion list, so expect a little discussion in return for
the free promotion opportunity.

And it's a great topic this Kraftwerk thing... I mean, just WHO is the
operator of my pocket calculator?

peace,
andyw

p.s. You haven't gotten back to me about booking me for your party, which
lands on my birthday (what a coincendence, the premier West Coast Massive
and my being shot forth into the world by my loving mum... is that cool or
what!?!?!).. so I'll remind you of my special needs on my special day.
They are as follows: I need three decks, and a good mixer (I reserve the
right to adjust the turntables to span a bigger bpm range, but I'll set
them back when I'm done so it's shouldn't be a problem).  I'd like to play
on the loudest sound system there (I love it when the bass rattles my
nuts, it feels like a friendly musical hand).  Furthermore, if I could
play after some big name DJ and wipe the floor with their over-marketed
ass, that would be great... maybe Christopher Lawrence, last time I played
after him was super fun (few years back at one of the Innercense
parties... right after his wedding actually, suffice to say his hair
looked great!  I'd love to figure out who his stylist is, I've got some
problems managing my locks if you know what I mean).  I'd also like a cold
six pack of Coors Light or Lucky Lager, a blunt and some nice people to
pass it around with (this has to be _before_ my set, it helps me unwind
and feel *the vibe*), and if possible an armed escort so I can get back to
my bike safely with all the grip I'm gonna make for the set I'm playing
for you guys.  If you guys wanna really set me up, I like those almond
m&m's... don't worry about hiring any dancing girls or anything, my beats
take care of that right quick (the honeys like a friendly musical hand too
*wink wink*).  You don't need to worry about a hotel (I'm local baby!),
and I know of at least three people that aren't planning on going that
would totally go if you booked me (so that's like a third of what you'd
need to pay me right there!).  So it's like a win/win situation!  Act now!
I know I play techno and you might have your doubts, but seriously, it's
the shinny (and well, Carl Cox and Jeff Mills are techno Djs too,
right?!)!  Plus, I'm sorta considered underground, imagine the value add
of all the 'street cred' I pack in this ass...  it's like you could
promote your party as a *Genuine* Underground Event[tm] like Vlad used to
when he'd book me for those 5am chill room slots.  In fact, it's okay if
you want to use my name to help sell it... like maybe CYBERFEST featuring
ANDYW (please note capitalization... all text should appear in like
fontface and size although dropping the point on the "featuring" is
acceptable if called for by formatting constraints).  If you wanna drop
the Kraftwerk guy, I could dress up kinda nerdy and open up my set with
Tour de France as well (you 'd save a ton of money, I could totally pass
for a German electronic music pioneer, and I won't tell if you won't ;).
Please get back to me when you have a chance, it's getting kinda tough to
keep this date open (the Canadian Government narrowly voted against adding
AndyW Day to their holiday calendar last session, but apparently
detractors of the measure felt they had to repeal Bastille Day first...
and I don't want to sit in some silly car cruising at 3 kilometers per
hour in some parade in Quebec anyways, casue you know... I don't even
speak French!).  In any case, I'm really looking foward to it!  Peace
dudes!

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

       first off to nico and others who had a differing opinion, i hated the 
timeslot decisions but i feel they were necessary to keep people at the party. 
i think it's really tough throwing parties where the whole mass concensus 
agrees that just jetting at 3 am is the standard. nobody's hardcore anymore. it 
gets to the point where someone like yours truly has to get people to come 
because of gimmicks like putting the headliner on last and serving breakfast. and 
those of you who left w/o seeing chris jackson, REALLY missed out.
       it's as if the whole techno scene was just way too used to SF Bar life 
and gotten past the desire and excitement of the RAVE (shout it proud). just 
look at people in the SF techno scene, is anyone younger than 19? i personally 
feel that we should embrace and educate the next generation of people to 
bring some fresh new sounds into techno. because isn't that what it's about? 
-techno being a close synonym for the future and all?
please feel free to read the comments below if you made it this far. `;)

> > on the loudest sound system there (I love it when the bass rattles my
> > nuts, it feels like a friendly musical hand).  Furthermore, if I could
> > play after some big name DJ and wipe the floor with their over-marketed
> > ass, that would be great... maybe Christopher Lawrence, last time I played
> > after him was super fun (few years back at one of the Innercense
> > parties... right after his wedding actually, suffice to say his hair
> > looked great!  I'd love to figure out who his stylist is, I've got some
> > problems managing my locks if you know what I mean).  I'd also like a cold
> > six pack of Coors Light or Lucky Lager, a blunt and some nice people to
> > pass it around with (this has to be _before_ my set, it helps me unwind
> > and feel *the vibe*), and if possible an armed escort so I can get back to
> > my bike safely with all the grip I'm gonna make for the set I'm playing
> > for you guys.  If you guys wanna really set me up, I like those almond
> > m&m's... don't worry about hiring any dancing girls or anything, my beats
> > take care of that right quick (the honeys like a friendly musical hand too
> > *wink wink*).  You don't need to worry about a hotel (I'm local baby!),
> > and I know of at least three people that aren't planning on going that
> > would totally go if you booked me (so that's like a third of what you'd
> > need to pay me right there!).  So it's like a win/win situation!  Act now!
> > I know I play techno and you might have your doubts, but seriously, it's
> > the shinny (and well, Carl Cox and Jeff Mills are techno Djs too,
> > right?!)!  Plus, I'm sorta considered underground, imagine the value add
> > of all the 'street cred' I pack in this ass...  it's like you could
> > promote your party as a *Genuine* Underground Event[tm] like Vlad used to
> > when he'd book me for those 5am chill room slots.  In fact, it's okay if
> > you want to use my name to help sell it... like maybe CYBERFEST featuring
> > ANDYW (please note capitalization... all text should appear in like
> > fontface and size although dropping the point on the "featuring" is
> > acceptable if called for by formatting constraints).  If you wanna drop
> > the Kraftwerk guy, I could dress up kinda nerdy and open up my set with
> > Tour de France as well (you 'd save a ton of money, I could totally pass
> > for a German electronic music pioneer, and I won't tell if you won't ;).
> > Please get back to me when you have a chance, it's getting kinda tough to
> > keep this date open (the Canadian Government narrowly voted against adding
> > AndyW Day to their holiday calendar last session, but apparently
> > detractors of the measure felt they had to repeal Bastille Day first...
> > and I don't want to sit in some silly car cruising at 3 kilometers per
> > hour in some parade in Quebec anyways, casue you know... I don't even
> > speak French!).  In any case, I'm really looking foward to it!  Peace
> > dudes!

At 01:58 PM 7/23/2003, DeezzerRec@aol.com wrote:

>I WISH PROMOTORS WOULD JUST DROP THEIR "I'M TOO BUSY ATTITUDE" AND PAY 
>ATTENTION TO THOSE WHO ARE TRYING TO COME UP IN THE BAY...INSTEAD OF 
>BOOKING SOMEONE LIKE KRAFTWERK WHO'S LIKE 80 YEARS OLD, WHO HAVE A NITCHED 
>MARKET, AND KIDS THAT GO TO COOLWORLD EVENTS DON'T CARE, THEY GO BECAUSE 
>THEY KNOW IT'S GONNA BE A BIG FESTIVAL... AS IF ANYONE REALLY CARES ABOUT 
>ME, OR THAT OTHER LIVE PA DOOD ON HERE I WANT TO CONTACT, BUT DAMN GIVE US 
>SOME LOVE!!! STOP THE HATE, MOTIVATE!!!
>
>All I've been tryin to say...is we must have more pride here. We have the 
>right to be heard, our beloved bay...
>
>Dominic Son aka Reflector
>Reflect Records
>www.reflectnow.com
>
>
> >>"Ladies and gentlemen, I'm throwing my hat in to the
>electronic trance music.
>Seems no promoter is interested to support this bay
>area silicon valley
>producer. I've fought long and hard, the good lord
>(and you promoters) knows
>how
>much $ i've been spilling to try to make a
>difference.."
>
> >
>If every starving artist had this kind of attitude, would we have art
>today? Our art galleries would be empty, the book shelves in book stores
>would have no books, and radio stations would be all right wing talk
>shows!
>
>I know what it means to be discouraged, but there is something in me
>that tell's me not to give up, even if it's a Top Ramen Noodle kind of
>day.
>
>If you fail, is it you who failed, or are you blaming others? Here's the
>cosmic deal. When you get up in the morning, you have two choices: face
>the day with an attitude of fear and say you won't make it, or face the
>day with an attitude of somehow, someway, I'll get through. I've made it
>this far haven't I? Your personal reality is in your mind. Everything has
>karmic consequences. If I choose to live in the attitude of fear, then I
>will attract people and situations that will confirm my attitude. If I
>choose to live in the attitude of faith, then I will attract people and
>situations that will confirm my faith. I'm not talking about this phoney
>"name it and claim it" faith, but real faith that recognizes life will
>work out if we let go and let life happen in life's own time and own way.
>I may not get every thing I want, but I know I'll get what I need. Maybe
>what I need now may not be recognition or instant fame, but It may be
>other things that pertain to the soul or what's going on inside me and
>what's in my mind.
>
>A famous prophet once said, "seek first the kingdom of god ( who ever
>"god" is to you) and his/her rightousness, and all these things
>(electronic music career) will be added to you.
>The electronic music scene is full of big $$$ rock stars and super stars
>and people inspiring to be big $$$ rock/super stars, that, in my opinion
>is one of the major reasons for the down fall or the rave scene and the
>infusion of cheezy, mass produced electronic music. We have too many
>D.J.'s inspiring to be big $$$ rock stars and very few in it for the love
>of the scene and the people. Again, that cosmic law of the universe,
>karma. If you go into this with an attitude to be famous and rich, then
>you choose to be in that reality whose karma is competitive, cut throat
>and the odds are against you. If you go in this with an attitude to give
>my talents to the world and particularly the rave scene as an offering of
>love and healing (boy do we need love and healers in these days!), then
>you choose to be in that reality whose karma may not get famous and rich,
>but will give you happiness and satisfaction, which all the money and
>fame can never give you, and in time all these things "will be added to
>you". If you get fortune and fame, you won't become an ass-hole about it,
>which means if you are an ass-hole, you are not happy.
>
>Maybe you need to stop fighting and start living. Just do it for the
>love. You don't even know what doors will open for you if you do it
>life's way! Karma, karma, karma!!!!
>
>Right now as I'm writing this, I have no job, the job market is tuff and
>I have 2 months of unemployment left and the little money I get barely
>pays the rent and I have a lot more 10 for a buck meals. Hopefully, EDD
>will accept my schooling application which means I can go to school and
>collect unemployment until April of next year. I may not get accepted,
>but I try not to start my day in fear over this and my employment issues
>because if I do, I will set in motion the karma consequences of fear and
>I'll be like someone with a tire stuck in the mud,  spinning my wheels
>out or frustration and anger, and in the end, having flat tires and no
>gas (depression) and have gone no where. If I get rejected, I know life
>has another way of taking care of me. Faith allows me to let go and give
>life an opportunity to provide rocks, sticks, what ever I need to get out
>of the hole.
>
>So, if you give up, that is your choice. Like Gianni sayz... "suck it
>up!" We all have our problems and we don't get all we want, but we don't
>give up. I can "suck it up" with Gianni because eventually it does work
>out. May not be what we like or want, but things work out. Accepting that
>is real faith.
>
>I love to spin records, but I haven't bought records in 2 years! I have
>a cheezy $75 shredder mixer and a turn table with a bad arm. When I moved
>here from Arizona 3 years ago, my "D.J. career" came to an abrupt end. I
>know people who recently bought nice $1,000 mixers, new 1200's and can
>keep up their record collections. Am I depressed? Some times. But, thanks
>to unemployment, I've had the time to ponder the mysteries of life, and
>part of my spiritual awakenings is the realization that I know this is
>happening for a reason. If I'm meant to have a "D.J. career", it will
>happen when it's supost to happen and let it go. Faith is understanding
>there is a reason for this to happen, and when I learn my lessons, it
>will all come together for me again. I choose by my attitude what reality
>I will have and the karma that it brings. If I come up again as a D.J.,
>attitude will bring the karma for that to happen. Find your own
>righteousness, and all these things will be added to you!
>
>Peace, Bodhi ^_^
>
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------

>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Marco Mancia 
Certified MacTweek;-0 
tekno revolucion!!!!

Date: Wed, 23 Jul 2003 23:16:38 -0700 (PDT)
From: Giles Bowkett <giles_bowkett@yahoo.com>
To: shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20030723235324.GC25630@pion.local>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] cyberfest/kraftwerk

--- shawn allen <shawn@alterior.net> wrote:
> Breakup drama doesn't usually last
> 11 years, right?

I sure hope not...

> But you're right in some respects, this is starting
> to sound like a
> legal issue. Did Karl get booked as Kraftwerk (with
> the band's
> permission), or is Coolworld just using his
> involvement with the group
> to sell tickets?

story...

my favorite band in high school was Sisters of Mercy.
Sisters of Mercy got involved in litigation pretty
regularly -- basically, any time the main guy (Andrew
Eldritch) disagreed with anyone else in the band, he
kicked them out, sued them, and (in extreme cases)
made records bragging about the amount of money they
had to pay him to settle the lawsuits.

as you could imagine he had a different guitarist
every album. he also had a different bassist every
album. in fact the only member of the band to stick
thru it the whole time besides Eldritch himself was
Doktor Avalanche, his trusty drum machine.

Eldritch/SOM recently toured the states playing a ton
of unreleased material which was not available
anywhere else. he hadn't put out a new album for
several years, because he was busy suing his record
label over the terms of its recording and release.

anyway, during the few years I was all into this goth
stuff, I learnt the history of the band, and this sort
of thing is **exactly** what used to happen right
before Eldritch sued somebody.

however, Andrew Eldritch is definitely eccentric.

hopefully the guys from Kraftwerk are a little more
laid back.

> Regardless, the man was one of the most influential
> members of the group
> during their most prolific period. He had a hand in
> most of the tracks
> that originally defined techno as a musical genre,
> ideology, and
> cultural movement. So, if you're really interested
> in seeing your
> favorite Kraftwerk tracks performed live by one of
> the "godfathers of
> techno", you should still at least consider going.
> ;)

altho in all fairness Kraftwerk more inspired techno
than defined it...you know what would be cool? a mix
CD which combined Kraftwerk, Africa Bambatta, World
Class Wrecking Cru, Juan Atkins, etc., and sort of put
them all in historical context -- so you could hear
how the ideas flowed from track to track. put in early
house, too, kz all the Detroit guys were driving to
Chicago to buy records.

man that would be cool to hear.

which reminds me, I gotta get that Tenaglia mix
"Classics."

blah, blah... :-)


Giles

Subject: [sfraves] 28 or more injured at police raid against ravers in France

--=====================_13666345==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit

 From another list:


This is a translation of the indymedia / Paris report - pics below!

it will also appear on http://widerstand.org and other sites and
mailinglists!

  -------
  28 or more injured at police raid against ravers in France
  --

  Everything began when members of CGT (the biggest labour syndicate)
sent a message on raver's infoline network telling that the Teknival will be
thrown in "Vieilles Charrues" festival's spot in support to its
artistic/technical workers (people working in art industry in france have a 
special status
  that is actually changed by the governement, to explain it quickly:
people like Depardieu or Johnny Halliday are "indemized" by social services in
addition to their already huge rewarding, and goverenement changed it
making it harder to have this status, so they took the money to people who
already are in difficulty....! so actually there's a big social movement about
it).
But the CGT told it wasn't them who did that. This point is quite
obscure.

 > The party was forbidden by the use of a prefectorial decrete, a
thousand policemen were mobilized.
 >
 > Then on thursday, a hide & seek game began with the authorities that
finished in Plouray during a big part of the night and day.
 >
 > About ten partypeople's vehicles took part on friday in a blocking
operation at about ten kilometres of Rostrenen (Côtes d'Armor) on the
road to Carhaix where the official festival took place.
 >
 > On friday night, party people went to a cul-de-sac "St Barbe's vault"
located in Faouet, a 2/3 kilometers road surrounded by fields ending on
two large ones.
 >
 > At about 9pm policemen seeing upcoming difficulties, the continuous
flood of cars arriving from everywhere and partypeople doing a sit-in
blocking the only way to t! he fields, began to get a little more irritated.
 >
 > At this time, everything was very peacefull, slogans were "Give our
sound back!" or "Let us party!" and such... it lasted quite a while.
 >
 >
 > Faouet's war
 > ------------------------------------
 >
 > Surrounded by policemen, some began to throw stones. The Morbihan's
prefect, Elisabeth Allaire, having reaffirmed that it was "out of
question to grant ravers an exeption", gave order to assault and to use all
means necessary to disperse the ravers. Quickly a rain of tear gas grenades
fell on the sitting partypeople.
 >
 > Partypeople answered by "stoning" police's vehicles (and policemen
obviously), that were about ten at this time.
 >
 > More and more partypeople were arriving to defend the road's entry,
attracted by the noise of grenades, always throwing stones. Policemen
feeling in inferiority and in danger didn't hesitate to ! use great
means:
these so called OFFENSIVE GRENADES !
 > (info: http://www.ssi-media.com/pigbrother/Report2003Part2.htm#8)
 >
 > That's when everything began to get really nasty, all the partypeople
agree saying that one would have believed oneself in war, "a true blood
bath" "a butchery" "a carnage"...
 >
 > First wounded raver received an offensive grenade on his thorax (he's
been very lucky), 4 broken "thorax bones" and multiple open wounds on all
the body, everybody thought he was dead. The problem was that policemen
were still firing offensive grenades (about 70 grenades were thrown ! ). No
way to
 > get (him) out of it, firemen couldn't come in, partypeople couldn't
come out ! Another one had a hand bursted by a grenade that exploded at few
centimeters away of him in the air...
 >
 > In fact, 25 wounded people have bee! n sent to the hospital or have
been healed by firemen's emergency services, but uncounted wounded people's
number is huge. 7 people were hospitalized.
 >
 > An old woman that has been saved by partypeople has been interviewed
on TV (only on 1pm news, it's strange that that infomation disapeared on 8pm
news - to broadcast only the part when she shows her wasted house).
partypeople took her to a safe place while policemen were firing
grenades everywhere, including houses of the residents (many broken 
windows), and present residents.
 >
 > The residents asked the cops to let ravers pass as they were already
many there anyways, but no way for them to be heard. Residents understood
the partypeople's distress, obliged to defend against cop's violent attack.
 >
 > Burning barricades have been set almost everywhere on the road and
the bridge leading to the place where a few sound-systems managed to take
place (2, 3 or 5 accor! ding to the testimonys)
 >
 > Another testimony: "12 CRS (crowd control police unit) with support
of the army, motorbikes and trucks... the hill was on fire with many burning
barricades and a few wooden gates"
 >
 > Everything lasted about 6 hours ! 6 hours of war to take the right to
throw a TAZ (Temporary Autonomous Zone)
 >
 > Some partypeople were in quite critical state and spent two days in
the hospital.
 >
 > The cops were firing grenades, partypeople were moving back a few
meters then assault with stones, breeze blocks and such. Prefect tells about
molotov cocktails but this is not confirmed by any witness.
 >
 > It ended when partypeople decided to stop fleeing the cops assaults
and began to all stand in front of the cops and their grenades, getting
closer and closer to them without moving back.
 >
 > Fortunately the cops stopped their butchery and all went away,
freeing the spot's! access. A "victory" but at which price ?...
 >
 >
 > The rave passes on
 > ------------------------------------------------
 >
 > Morbihan's prefect justified public force use, including using
offensive grenades, telling that "It wasn't a youth gathering but a real 
riot".
She also told that it wasn't a rave "as there were no sound-systems
present",that is an obvious bullshit, every sound-system being seized by
policemen.
 >
 > AFP: "The 1000 policemen spread in all central britany proceeded
since friday to 27 sound-systems seizures..."
 >
 > After the fight the policemen just completely went away, without any
will to "securize" the place. Not even an emergency call number was
available. Lastly it seems municipality was almost absent, Saturday 
afternoon, the
residents only received a simple phone call from the mayor. No visit on
the spot. For some of them, even victims, the fault is to the authoriti! es
that tried stopping things too late and ill-advised, as many ravers were
arrived in the city, they shouldn't have take the risk of the confrontation.
 >
 > 58 people were challenged for narcotic detention. The next day, two
of them were sent to prison for a year (No reason supplied).
 >
 > AFP: "Many ravers joined those already installed on St Barbe's
vault's spot during the night, taking the number of present people to about
10000 -according to police"
 >
 > On sunday morning about 8 000 young people were still in
Faouet,concentrated on a hill at the end of a road located just near
the borought.
 >
 > Saturday to Sunday's night have been quiet. Prefecture maintened
filtering the roads around Faouet to prevent sound-systems from getting to St
Barbe. It couldn't avoid that a small part arrived at destination, dismounted
in separate elements for more conceability.
 >
 > Ravers ended by pr! oceeding to the spot's cleaning (seen on TV).
Everybody participated, with trash bags distributed by firemen. Testimony: "At
the end the spot was really clean, trash bags were all grouped along the road,
even capsules and cigarettes ends have been took away in some places"
 >
 >
 > Whose fault?
 > ------------------------------------------------------
 >
 > The wrongs are shared.
 >
 > To the "organizers" that apparently didn't organize much, and are
surely not the ones that paid the full price for this night of hell. But if
these people have a part o responsibility, it surely wasn't to the ravers
"mass" to undergo the consequences for them. Even less, it was the resident's.
The Tekno comunity see the people responsible for this waste with evil
eyes.
 >
 > The fact that there has been a minority of rioters and breakers in
the partypeople crowd is very probable. But police's reaction was
appare! ntly (voluntarily?) disproportionned. Partypeople's image has been 
more
degraded -
that is a good deal for the governement.
 >
 > Lastly, and mostly, prefect and public forces didn't hesitate to
knowingly create a confrontation situation, pertinently knowing that with or
without authorization, thousands of young people would converge toward 
Carhaix.
The State once more led to a foreseeable confrontation, to make tekno
 > movement's reputation worse, in spite of the structuring attempts of
associations such as Le Silence Tue, Sound-systems collective... These
efforts towards a dialog are highly in question, that could lead to
others serious tensions and/or confrontations, in continuity of the
systematically repressive logic of the government...
 >
 > -+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-
 > Text translated by Signal² / Paris/France - text taken from:
 > http://paris.indymedia.org/article.php3?id_article=5588
 > -+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-



Moksha Tribe:  www.mokshatribe.net

House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U  
--=====================_13666345==.ALT--

--- AndyW <andy@saturn5.com> wrote:
> 
> On Wed, 23 Jul 2003, Coolworld wrote:
> -&e->Actually omid, no ones trying to sweep anything under
> the rug here,
> -&e->simply trying not to over sensationalize something that
> is in a
> -&e->difference in opinion, both professionally and
> personally.
> 
> You guys are being upfront well before the show, so that's
> cool in my
> book.
> 
> -&e-> I think 10 threads is pretty sufficient?
> 
> Whatever it takes.  The larger your promotion and party...
> the larger the
> discussion.  The more you promise the world, the more a
> natural increase
> in skepticism.  You guys signed up for the big time, not me. 
> I could get
> mad (about the fact that my last car's window derailed from
> how hard one
> of your flyer peeps shoved your foldout into my window jam
> but I'm over it
> now even thought I wasn't even parked anywhere near a club or
> party at the
> time).
> 
> -&e-> I admire your persistence and need to make sure
> Coolworld presents
> -&e->an honest depiction of it's event, so i simply asked you
> to take it
> -&e->on a private level.
> 
> Asking questions publicly to the benefit of the public as a
> response to a
> public advertisment is totally fair game.  this is not an
> advertisement
> list, it's a discussion list, so expect a little discussion
> in return for
> the free promotion opportunity.
> 
> And it's a great topic this Kraftwerk thing... I mean, just
> WHO is the
> operator of my pocket calculator?
> 
> peace,
> andyw
> 
> p.s. You haven't gotten back to me about booking me for your
> party, which
> lands on my birthday (what a coincendence, the premier West
> Coast Massive
> and my being shot forth into the world by my loving mum... is
> that cool or
> what!?!?!).. so I'll remind you of my special needs on my
> special day.
> They are as follows: I need three decks, and a good mixer (I
> reserve the
> right to adjust the turntables to span a bigger bpm range,
> but I'll set
> them back when I'm done so it's shouldn't be a problem).  I'd
> like to play
> on the loudest sound system there (I love it when the bass
> rattles my
> nuts, it feels like a friendly musical hand).  Furthermore,
> if I could
> play after some big name DJ and wipe the floor with their
> over-marketed
> ass, that would be great... maybe Christopher Lawrence, last
> time I played
> after him was super fun (few years back at one of the
> Innercense
> parties... right after his wedding actually, suffice to say
> his hair
> looked great!  I'd love to figure out who his stylist is,
> I've got some
> problems managing my locks if you know what I mean).  I'd
> also like a cold
> six pack of Coors Light or Lucky Lager, a blunt and some nice
> people to
> pass it around with (this has to be _before_ my set, it helps
> me unwind
> and feel *the vibe*), and if possible an armed escort so I
> can get back to
> my bike safely with all the grip I'm gonna make for the set
> I'm playing
> for you guys.  If you guys wanna really set me up, I like
> those almond
> m&m's... don't worry about hiring any dancing girls or
> anything, my beats
> take care of that right quick (the honeys like a friendly
> musical hand too
> *wink wink*).  You don't need to worry about a hotel (I'm
> local baby!),
> and I know of at least three people that aren't planning on
> going that
> would totally go if you booked me (so that's like a third of
> what you'd
> need to pay me right there!).  So it's like a win/win
> situation!  Act now!
> I know I play techno and you might have your doubts, but
> seriously, it's
> the shinny (and well, Carl Cox and Jeff Mills are techno Djs
> too,
> right?!)!  Plus, I'm sorta considered underground, imagine
> the value add
> of all the 'street cred' I pack in this ass...  it's like you
> could
> promote your party as a *Genuine* Underground Event[tm] like
> Vlad used to
> when he'd book me for those 5am chill room slots.  In fact,
> it's okay if
> you want to use my name to help sell it... like maybe
> CYBERFEST featuring
> ANDYW (please note capitalization... all text should appear
> in like
> fontface and size although dropping the point on the
> "featuring" is
> acceptable if called for by formatting constraints).  If you
> wanna drop
> the Kraftwerk guy, I could dress up kinda nerdy and open up
> my set with
> Tour de France as well (you 'd save a ton of money, I could
> totally pass
> for a German electronic music pioneer, and I won't tell if
> you won't ;).
> Please get back to me when you have a chance, it's getting
> kinda tough to
> keep this date open (the Canadian Government narrowly voted
> against adding
> AndyW Day to their holiday calendar last session, but
> apparently
> detractors of the measure felt they had to repeal Bastille
> Day first...
> and I don't want to sit in some silly car cruising at 3
> kilometers per
> hour in some parade in Quebec anyways, casue you know... I
> don't even
> speak French!).  In any case, I'm really looking foward to
> it!  Peace
> dudes!
> 
> 
>
