Subject: RE: [sfraves] [NRR] Lies, Damn Lies, and Statistics

More statistics.. for those of you too lazy to do your own research
about what the media whores are spewing about our economy.  

http://www.econopundit.com/2003_07_01_econopundit_archive.html#105958266
017030566

More than 3.8 million people now draw unemployment benefits, the highest
in 20 years. The number looking for jobs has passed 9 million for the
first time in 10 years. The unemployment rate has climbed to a nine-year
high of 6.4 percent. The economy has lost over 300,000 jobs this year,
and unemployment claims are still up around 425,000 a week.

Okay, now unglaze your eyes for a second and you'll notice something.
First he says bla bla, the highest in 20 years. Then he says bleah,
blea, highest in 10 years. Then it's yadda, yadda, climbed to a nine
year high. And finally yackda, yacdka this year and this week.

Why doesn't he keep the time under consideration constant? The answer
is, it might weaken his argument!

Here are plots of new and continued claims for unemployment insurance
since 1967. I've made no adjustments for the growth in the population
and labor force, so you can plainly see what we're going thru is a very
mild jobs recession. By standards of the early 1990's (when 6% was about
as low as we thought we could go) we are not far from full employment.

(if you want to see the graph click the above link)

From sfraves-return-104459-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Jul 31 02:13:57 2003

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

From: JBlaze112@aol.com
Message-ID: <a6.3afbcc3b.2c59d559@aol.com>
Date: Wed, 30 Jul 2003 22:13:45 EDT
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="part1_a6.3afbcc3b.2c59d559_boundary"
X-Mailer: Thunderbird - Mac OS X sub 24
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: KABOOM!!!! @%^@#%^@$%&%@&  (Let me get something straight)

--part1_a6.3afbcc3b.2c59d559_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

Let me get something staight...

     When I say there is a "Square Root" problem/equation in America, and 
that there are two sides we must chose from, I'm not trying to neatly put 
everyone into little groups that they don't fit in, nor am I trying to use labels 
that we should all wear on our left or right breast pocket... 
     What I am saying, is that there is one epitime-type problem in America 
that people seem to never, ever, ever talk about: Should we, the U.S., have 
Nuclear weapons? I'm sure I know the reason why people don't talk about this 
issue... because we think the answer is obvious. Too obvious of an aswer to even 
ask the question, I mean what a STUPID question, people would look at you in 
disgust. "Of course the U.S. should have nuclear weapons! Fucking dumbass!"   
"If we didn't, all the Hitler type people would blow us the fuck up and take 
over the world." 
     And there you have it, you've been silenced, you never mention it 
again... but then you start to think what about John Lennon? How would he have 
answered that question? What about Bob Marley? What did Einstien mean when he said 
"You cannot similtaneously prevent and prepare for war." Was Einstien just 
being brash? Did he not think it all the way through? I mean if we don't use his 
thereoys in politics then why use his thereos in math? Maybe he's a madman. On 
that note lets just stop listening to the Beatles and the Wailers too. :p
     I know what you're all thinking now "It's not that simple, you can't 
just chose to have Nuclear weapons or not" "It's a touchy decision, that none of 
us are ready to make yet" and in the meantime I dunno when we last checked but 
I'm pretty sure we DO have NUCLEAR WEAPONS as of NOW. So to avoid the subject 
is the same thing as agreeing it's ok   to have them. Because we do have 
them. In fact we have the MOST of them of any other nation. And since by in large 
Nuclear Weapons are the most hated, wretched items in the world.... and we 
have the MOST of them... then wouldn't it be logical for us to be the most hated 
nation as well? We metaphorically hover these apocolipse capable bombs over 
our enimies heads practically stating "Well we could kill you if we wanted to 
but we're not going to because we're nice... so be goddamned thankful and don't 
start any shit, got it?"
     So anyway, when I say there are two sides to this issue it's because 
there ARE two sides and there can ONLY be two sides. You can either OWN nuclear 
weapons or you can NOT own them. You can't be inbetween. 
     I do empathize with those who say we need them for self defesnse... 
knowing that they believe other nuclear powers to be "madmen" who would kill us 
all if not for our current militant supiourity over them. ... but this thereoy 
somehow always reminds of the Rage Against the Machine song/quote "Fear is your 
only God"
     But I want to make it clear that, contrary to popular belief the 
"hippie" types who protest and call for peace are NOT wimps but are rather very much 
more couragous because:
 #1 they are swimming against the tide, (not out of spite, mind you, but out 
of personal, moral integrity)   
 #2 they entrust in other countries to have compassion equally as much as our 
own, (instead of attaching themselves to what's familiar and safe). 
 #3 Because they know that there is a chance they could be wrong and naive, 
and if that turns out to be the case, we could all die in our lack of 
self-defence militia, while being attacked and killed, in our efforts to serve the 
envirornment and the community... (just like soldiers die serving the military). 
     I don't think it's any different and therefor you can't use courage as 
the insult, nor can you use inteligence or integrity. When it boils down to 
it... it's a battle of faith. You can either die FIGHTING with a pretty good 
chance of wining and surviving (since you are very fortunate to be on the stronger 
side)
... or you can die Believing, in other people and in other nations than ours. 
Knowing that if your faith is wrong or naive you may catch a one way nuclear 
ticket to the cosmos. (at least then you have your honor, and you know you 
were a part of what could have been... something of the Utopia) And then again 
perhaps this way really works afterall? Who knows...

--part1_a6.3afbcc3b.2c59d559_boundary--

That's a good question.  There could be a case made that the US doesn't
need them because we are the single most powerful military on the
planet.  But that can change and china is doing their damnedest to catch
us. =20

1.  we must keep our nukes until everyone that has them agrees to
destroy all of theirs at the same time.  You may not know this but china
has a "nuke first" strategy to deal our military a crushing blow in case
they go to war with us.  China is very opposed to our missile defense
system for this reason.

2.  the UN has to get a set of nuts and enforce their existing
agreements with all the signatories on the nuclear proliferation
agreements that all the countries signed and the India/Pakistan violated
with no actions and that iran and north korea are currently violating. =20


But I want to make it clear that, contrary to popular belief the=20
"hippie" types who protest and call for peace are NOT wimps but are
rather very much more couragous because:
 #1 they are swimming against the tide, (not out of spite, mind you, but
out=20
of personal, moral integrity

what moral integrity lead protestors to protest the ouster of a man that
would have his sons throw live people into wood chipper machines?  You
think it is moral to oppose war when the end result is to allow human
rights violations on a scale beyond the most heinous acts?  The end
result of the na=EFve protests would have been more death and =
humiliation
for the Iraqi people.  I would not claim to have any sort of grasp of
what morality is if you actually protested against the liberation of
iraq.=20

Let me get something staight...

     When I say there is a "Square Root" problem/equation in America,
and=20
that there are two sides we must chose from, I'm not trying to neatly
put=20
everyone into little groups that they don't fit in, nor am I trying to
use labels=20
that we should all wear on our left or right breast pocket...=20
     What I am saying, is that there is one epitime-type problem in
America=20
that people seem to never, ever, ever talk about: Should we, the U.S.,
have=20
Nuclear weapons? I'm sure I know the reason why people don't talk about
this=20
issue... because we think the answer is obvious. Too obvious of an aswer
to even=20
ask the question, I mean what a STUPID question, people would look at
you in=20
disgust. "Of course the U.S. should have nuclear weapons! Fucking
dumbass!"  =20
"If we didn't, all the Hitler type people would blow us the fuck up and
take=20
over the world."=20
     And there you have it, you've been silenced, you never mention it=20
again... but then you start to think what about John Lennon? How would
he have=20
answered that question? What about Bob Marley? What did Einstien mean
when he said=20
"You cannot similtaneously prevent and prepare for war." Was Einstien
just=20
being brash? Did he not think it all the way through? I mean if we don't
use his=20
thereoys in politics then why use his thereos in math? Maybe he's a
madman. On=20
that note lets just stop listening to the Beatles and the Wailers too.
:p
     I know what you're all thinking now "It's not that simple, you
can't=20
just chose to have Nuclear weapons or not" "It's a touchy decision, that
none of=20
us are ready to make yet" and in the meantime I dunno when we last
checked but=20
I'm pretty sure we DO have NUCLEAR WEAPONS as of NOW. So to avoid the
subject=20
is the same thing as agreeing it's ok   to have them. Because we do have

them. In fact we have the MOST of them of any other nation. And since by
in large=20
Nuclear Weapons are the most hated, wretched items in the world.... and
we=20
have the MOST of them... then wouldn't it be logical for us to be the
most hated=20
nation as well? We metaphorically hover these apocolipse capable bombs
over=20
our enimies heads practically stating "Well we could kill you if we
wanted to=20
but we're not going to because we're nice... so be goddamned thankful
and don't=20
start any shit, got it?"
     So anyway, when I say there are two sides to this issue it's
because=20
there ARE two sides and there can ONLY be two sides. You can either OWN
nuclear=20
weapons or you can NOT own them. You can't be inbetween.=20
     I do empathize with those who say we need them for self defesnse...

knowing that they believe other nuclear powers to be "madmen" who would
kill us=20
all if not for our current militant supiourity over them. ... but this
thereoy=20
somehow always reminds of the Rage Against the Machine song/quote "Fear
is your=20
only God"
     But I want to make it clear that, contrary to popular belief the=20
"hippie" types who protest and call for peace are NOT wimps but are
rather very much=20
more couragous because:
 #1 they are swimming against the tide, (not out of spite, mind you, but
out=20
of personal, moral integrity)  =20
 #2 they entrust in other countries to have compassion equally as much
as our=20
own, (instead of attaching themselves to what's familiar and safe).=20
 #3 Because they know that there is a chance they could be wrong and
naive,=20
and if that turns out to be the case, we could all die in our lack of=20
self-defence militia, while being attacked and killed, in our efforts to
serve the=20
envirornment and the community... (just like soldiers die serving the
military).=20
     I don't think it's any different and therefor you can't use courage
as=20
the insult, nor can you use inteligence or integrity. When it boils down
to=20
it... it's a battle of faith. You can either die FIGHTING with a pretty
good=20
chance of wining and surviving (since you are very fortunate to be on
the stronger=20
side)
... or you can die Believing, in other people and in other nations than
ours.=20
Knowing that if your faith is wrong or naive you may catch a one way
nuclear=20
ticket to the cosmos. (at least then you have your honor, and you know
you=20
were a part of what could have been... something of the Utopia) And then
again=20
perhaps this way really works afterall? Who knows...

Btw... I've had a little time to digest why this email makes me sick and
I'd like to share it with you all.

http://www.viewfromiran.blogspot.com/2003_07_01_viewfromiran_archive.htm
l#105950623389319043

the above link is a blog that is written by a man and a woman currently
living in iran.  They detail their life and experience quite well.
There are hundreds if not thousand of these blogs if you go and look for
them.  The mad mullahs of iran are trying desperately to shut them down
because they are informing the world about what is happening in iran.

What pains me about this email is my little friend has demonstrated to
me that he is a moral coward, someone that believes in noble ideals but
would never sacrifice for them.  Screw all the people that are living in
iran, it is much better to let them suffer under the mad mullahs (and
suffer they do) than to take action.  No one knows how many people might
die in a real uprising with guns and bullets but if the end result was
that the mullahs were captured and dealt with and democracy returned to
iran then the pain would be worth it.  Using judas' logic, the US would
still be a british colony.  

I am tied by family to the country of south korea.  My wife and daughter
currently live in seoul.  The little bastard to the north has promised
to turn seoul into a sea of fire and if he does you can bet I'll be on
the next plane there to kill him with my bare hands (and anyone that
gets in the way).  You have no idea how much I fret over what is going
on in korea now but you can believe that if something happens I'll
support our government in its' actions.  I personally think there will
be a war there within a year and I am hoping that it doesn't happen
while my family is there.  But if it does, I'll join the fight, not the
protest. 

If the end result is the freedom of other families to have what I have,
it is worth it.

     I think you missed the point compleately. The reason we shouldn't have=20
nuclear weapons isn't because we can defend ourselves without them. The reas=
on=20
we shouldn't have them is, since we're supposedly a peace making nation, and=
=20
we're asking other nations to disarm, we should then make an honorable examp=
le=20
by disarming first. If then China or any other nation uses our own kindness=20
against us, and proceeds to "kick us while we're down" so to speak, then=20
president Bush's axis of evil thereoy will be truely proven, there truely wi=
ll be a=20
great evil preying on our true inocence, and we'll have to die hedious death=
s=20
because of our naiveness. And when we're all dead you can all blame naive=20
people like me throughout the afterlife...
     BUT if you have any damn faith in mankind at all, one would like to=20
believe that even a nation like China has this little thing called "honor".=20=
Can=20
you imagine, if the U.S. disarmed nuclear power as a peace gesture, as an=20
example for North Korea and the rest of the world to follow, can you imagine=
 then=20
China turning around and saying "They've disarmed nuclear power! lets bomb t=
hem=20
mhuahahahhaha!!" No because China, like all other countries has honor. The=20
reason China has strategies against us is because they don't trust us. We do=
n't=20
give them any reason to trust us. We ask other nations like Iraq and North=20
Korea to dis-arm while we hold on to our own nuclear weapons, we ignore insp=
ection=20
requests from the UN and we call that fair. We expect and assume trust from=20
all other nations because we just assume all of our intentions are just and=20
fair. But we only play by our own rules, compleately ignoring the UN.=20
     If you ask me I think it's a goddamn miricle that there even is a UN.=20
It's a miricle that it even exists and It's just about the only entity that=20=
can=20
make peace in the world and do it fair, without causeing spite and humiliati=
on=20
on the losing side. To disrespect it or ignore it in any way is just not=20
forgivable. I think the U.S. truely does have good intentions but we just ex=
pect=20
other countries to trust us and if they don't, too bad. This is no way to ru=
n a=20
country. Yes it can be done, yes we have the power to do it if we want to, n=
o=20
we're not technically doing anyting downright "evil". We do have good=20
intentions, but it's just retarded to expect other nations to trust us, just=
 because=20
we say so.=20

From: <JBlaze112@aol.com>

     I think you missed the point compleately. The reason we shouldn't have
nuclear weapons isn't because we can defend ourselves without them. The
reason
we shouldn't have them is, since we're supposedly a peace making nation, and
we're asking other nations to disarm, we should then make an honorable
example
by disarming first. If then China or any other nation uses our own kindness
against us, and proceeds to "kick us while we're down" so to speak, then
president Bush's axis of evil thereoy will be truely proven, there truely
will be a
great evil preying on our true inocence, and we'll have to die hedious
deaths
because of our naiveness. And when we're all dead you can all blame naive
people like me throughout the afterlife...
     BUT if you have any damn faith in mankind at all, one would like to
believe that even a nation like China has this little thing called "honor".
Can
you imagine, if the U.S. disarmed nuclear power as a peace gesture, as an
example for North Korea and the rest of the world to follow, can you imagine
then
China turning around and saying "They've disarmed nuclear power! lets bomb
them
mhuahahahhaha!!" No because China, like all other countries has honor. The
reason China has strategies against us is because they don't trust us. We
don't
give them any reason to trust us. We ask other nations like Iraq and North
Korea to dis-arm while we hold on to our own nuclear weapons, we ignore
inspection
requests from the UN and we call that fair. We expect and assume trust from
all other nations because we just assume all of our intentions are just and
fair. But we only play by our own rules, compleately ignoring the UN.
     If you ask me I think it's a goddamn miricle that there even is a UN.
It's a miricle that it even exists and It's just about the only entity that
can
make peace in the world and do it fair, without causeing spite and
humiliation
on the losing side. To disrespect it or ignore it in any way is just not
forgivable. I think the U.S. truely does have good intentions but we just
expect
other countries to trust us and if they don't, too bad. This is no way to
run a
country. Yes it can be done, yes we have the power to do it if we want to,
no
we're not technically doing anyting downright "evil". We do have good
intentions, but it's just retarded to expect other nations to trust us, just
because
we say so.

I was going to type out a long rebuttal to this but I don=92t think it =
is
worth it.  Anyone that thinks the UN has any credibility after all the
stark and utter failures that they have lined up the past decade is
beyond debate.  (Genocide in Rwanda, genocide in Kosovo/bosnia, genocide
in Africa, genocide in north korea, complete failure to enforce their

formed

that promises hong kong 50 years of democracy under a =931 china, 2

don=92t

have nuclear weapons isn't because we can defend ourselves without them.
The reason we shouldn't have them is, since we're supposedly a peace
making nation, and we're asking other nations to disarm, we should then
make an honorable example by disarming first. If then China or any other
nation uses our own kindness against us, and proceeds to "kick us while
we're down" so to speak, then president Bush's axis of evil thereoy will
be truely proven, there truely will be a great evil preying on our true
inocence, and we'll have to die hedious deaths because of our naiveness.

throughout the afterlife...

"honor". Can you imagine, if the U.S. disarmed nuclear power as a peace

disarmed nuclear power! lets bomb them mhuahahahhaha!!" No because
China, like all other countries has honor. The reason China has
strategies against us is because they don't trust us. We don't give them
any reason to trust us. We ask other nations like Iraq and North Korea
to dis-arm while we hold on to our own nuclear weapons, we ignore
inspection requests from the UN and we call that fair. We expect and
assume trust from all other nations because we just assume all of our
intentions are just and fair. But we only play by our own rules,
compleately ignoring the UN.=20

UN. It's a miricle that it even exists and It's just about the only
entity that can make peace in the world and do it fair, without causeing
spite and humiliation on the losing side. To disrespect it or ignore it
in any way is just not forgivable. I think the U.S. truely does have
good intentions but we just expect other countries to trust us and if
they don't, too bad. This is no way to run a country. Yes it can be
done, yes we have the power to do it if we want to, no we're not
technically doing anyting downright "evil". We do have good intentions,
but it's just retarded to expect other nations to trust us, just because
we say so.=20

:CODE at DNA Lounge wins Best of the Bay award!
http://bestofthebay.com/2003/e_ent.html
http://code.dnalounge.com
----------------------------------------------------------------
Best Place to See an Electronic Duo Score 'My Dinner with Andre' 
----------------------------------------------------------------
As far as SoMa spaces go, the DNA Lounge has definitely stepped to the
plate in the post-1015-relevance era. Resident DJs Shane and Amber have
been putting on :CODE there every other Thursday since the club's
impressive renovation two years ago, spinning a consistently good mix of
acid techno, ghetto breaks, glitch, and drum 'n' bass as well as
showcasing live acts when they can. :CODE's a good party, and the night
we saw experimental duo Idiom Creak perform was no exception. What was
exceptional was watching kids get down to their bizarro breaks while the
two scored epochal indie film My Dinner with Andre on the fly. Kids who
didn't exist when the film came out in '82 were shakin' it beneath the
projected image of Wallace Shawn waxing philosophical as Idiom Creak
trickled dialogue into the mix along with their spastic beats. DNA
Lounge, 375 11th St., S.F. (415) 626-1409, www.dnalounge.com/0xC0DE/.

................................................
who----------------|Shane Knapp
contact------------|donut-at-bayarea.net
:CODE+DNA Lounge---|http://code.dnalounge.com
music+DJ mixes-----|http://www.nuclearferret.com

the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no

adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

From: Sarah Schumm <sarah_schumm@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: multipart/alternative; boundary="0-1741680130-1059677082=:43761"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] [nrr] Driving DOES suck

--0-1741680130-1059677082=:43761
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

"I'll have you know I was online registering my disgust on the internet within minutes"
>comic book guy<
 
Remeber a while back when people were talking on here about racing cars and I made some sarcastic remark about how cars were some evil capitalist plot or something, and then a flame war started and I apologised...Well I take My apology back: CARS DO SUCK! If you want to drive em go ahead, but yesterday I had to drive and IT SUCKED! I LOVE BART! I LOVE MY BIKE! How can you people who drive stand it?!
So Here's what happened: I had this big commisiion right, and the art was done, but I needed blacklights, batteries and frames, all of which I ordered on line to be delivered by UPS, the Blacklights came while I was back East , so I had to go to to Sunnyvale and Pick them up, the Frames were backordered so I had to buy them retail, and the only place that had enough in stock was in Sunnyvale too! My husband, who does drive, works in Palo Alto, You would think this would be easy to coordinate, but I had to go to Sunnyvale and Palo Alto Twice because one frame was broken, and the UPS thing took me an Hour to find even though I used to live in Sunnyvale the UPS place is like in some alternate dimention or something, and there is this big body of water in the way between Fremont and Sunnyvale! Plus the guy at the frame place did not understand that 10 $6 frames does not add up to $85. his Exact words " I don't know, that's what the cash register says, if you want to add it up on the side
 while I ring these other people up go ahead." OK, I am not a math genius or anything but 10x6=60, tax is 8% so 60x8=480 just estimating you get $65, not $85. Even with cash register hypnosis, that is easy to figure out. I have had cash register hypnosis, it takes exactly 3 times as long to do basic math when you have it it, so it should have taken him about 30 seconds! IT TOOK AN HOUR AND A HALF! Anyway, by the time I got that straightened out, I had to pick up my husband in PA, and there are all these other people in other cars, that you cant go around because you are in a car, and these red lights you have to stop at, even when they turn green because all the cars are in the way, and these big orange cones you have to drive around, all of which is really easy on a bike but is a pain in a stupid car. So then I have to go over the big body of water to get home, but everybody else wants to go home at the same time, so there are all these cars in each others way! Then, after I frame
 all the work I have to deliver the art to San Francisco, but there are still cars all trying to go the same place at once! Even at 9:00 at night! Where are they going? And then I have to go across this big bridge, because that lake or whatever is in the way AGAIN! And they want $2 to get across it, so I have to go to this shady place in oakland to get cash. And I have to drive all over the place and the signs are all different sizes and hard to see, you can't just get back on the freeway where you got off, no, you have to drive to some other place. And then when you get on the bridge it is broken, and only one lane works! Then when you want to go back they close off all the places to get on with those little yellow cone thingies, I think they do this to keep all the people trapped in San Francisco so they can charge more for rent!  I gave up and took 280 to 101 to 84 to 880 home because 280 was the only freeway I could find that was open. Anyway, I got home and Kissed my BART pass
 (not literaly, eww) and Hugged my Bicycle. DRIVING SUCKS! 




---------------------------------

	boundary="----=_NextPart_000_0155_01C35760.5518C730"
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2800.1158
X-MIMEOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2800.1165
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Another Anti Rave/Ecstasy Bill Introduced

------=_NextPart_000_0155_01C35760.5518C730
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

link:
http://thomas.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c108:H.R.2962:

text:
July 25, 2003
Mr. PASCRELL (for himself, Mr. TERRY, Mr. PALLONE, Mr.
ETHERIDGE, and Mr. CAPUANO) introduced the following
bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and
Commerce, and in addition to the Committees on the
Judiciary, and Education and the Workforce, for a
period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in
each case for consideration of such provisions as fall
within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned=20



-------------------------------------------------------------------------=
-------


A BILL
To prevent the abuse of the illegal drug commonly
called ecstasy.=20


Be it enacted by the Senate and House of
Representatives of the United States of America in
Congress assembled,

SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE.

This Act may be cited as the `Ecstasy Awareness Act of
2003'.

SEC. 2. PROFITING FROM RAVES.

Section 416 of the Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C.
856) is amended by adding at the end the following:

`(c) Whoever profits monetarily from a rave or similar
electronic dance event, knowing or having reason to
know that the unlawful use or distribution of a
controlled substance occurs at the rave or similar
event, shall be fined not more than $500,000 or
imprisoned not more than 20 years, or both. If the
defendant is an organization, the fine imposable for
the offense is not more than $2,000,000.'.

SEC. 3. GRANTS FOR PROSECUTION OF ECSTASY OFFENSES.

In addition to any other amounts authorized to be
appropriated for such purpose, there are authorized to
be appropriated to the Attorney General $10,000,000 for
fiscal year 2004 to make grants to provide training to
State and local prosecutors and law enforcement agents
for prosecution of ecstasy offenses.

SEC. 4. GRANTS FOR EDUCATIONAL ACTIVITIES TO PREVENT OR
REDUCE THE USE OF ECSTASY.

Section 4115(b)(1) of the Elementary and Secondary
Education Act of 1965 (20 U.S.C. 7115(b)(1)) is
amended--

(1) in subparagraph (C), by striking `and' at the end;

(2) in subparagraph (D), by striking the period at the
end and inserting `; and'; and

(3) by adding at the end the following:

`(E) include activities to prevent or reduce the use of
the illegal drug commonly called ecstasy.'.



Bryan Oley
Board President
Acting Executive Director
DanceSafe
bryan@dancesafe.org

"Because what you don't know CAN hurt you"

"Everyone is out trying to add years to life...but no one is ever trying =
to add life to years." - unknown
------=_NextPart_000_0155_01C35760.5518C730--

From sfraves-return-104500-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Jul 31 19:45:19 2003
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-104500-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Date: Thu, 31 Jul 2003 12:45:16 -0700 (PDT)
From: AndyW <andy@saturn5.com>
X-X-Sender: andy@atari
To: Jack Triumph <jacktriumph@hotmail.com>
cc: Joeandus@aol.com, SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <BAY8-DAV30BoH9tiSnB000147d9@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0307311146420.20615-100000@atari>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR - Re: [sfraves] Question


Just a couple facts in response...

On Thu, 31 Jul 2003, Jack Triumph wrote:
-&e->Are you kidding me? Obviously we know where your loyalties lie. You are
-&e->comparing a greedy son a bitch governor who spent your money and mine and
-&e->put us in danger of junk bond status to a president who whole-heartedly is
-&e->doing the best job he can (which is an opinionated statement) ?

Honestly?  Both.

-&e->Hello, class...anyone tell me what state *used* to have the 5th largest
-&e->economy? You see the other states in the same shape we are? You think bush
-&e->is responsible for the economy? 8 years of trickle down politics, open
-&e->borders, failed social programs, focusing on bj's instead of work, and
-&e->overall bleeding heart liberalism got us in this spot folks; Bush didn't
-&e->create this, he inherited it.

"Trickle down" was a term coined by the Reagan cabinet to describe how
giving tax breaks and other fiscal advantage to the rich and corporations
made society benefit as a whole (detractors referred to this practice as
voodoo economics).  Time has proven that this is horribly incorrect by the
way... it does stimulate cash flow in certain sectors, but at the expense
of middle class solvency.  It creates more money in the banking system
available for lending at cheaper rates, but has middle and long term
effects of foreclosures and bankrupcies.  See Bush's recent tax package,
which offers low income families not a fucking thing, kicks a couple
hundred bucks to middle class and dual income families, and reduces taxes
for well off individuals and corporations substantially.

Many other states *are* in the same shape we are in.  Two things happened
to make California eat shit.  One, a temporary economic growth that seemed
like it would be a permanent fixture... and two, the expense of bailouts
that were a direct result of the deregulation of utilities.  The first was
the result of bipartisan economic shortsightedness, the second a strong
libertarian/republican push to privatize the energy market during Wilson's
term.  Make no mistake, rolling blackouts, a couple hundred bucks of your
money in extra bills, the enron debacle and the lobbying that allowed this
all all very linked.

Regarding open borders, NAFTA was bipartisan.  The China free trade
agreement had it's roots in Nixon's visits there in the 70s and 80s.
Most of the resistance to NAFTA stemmed from unions, usually a
democraticaly aligned concern.  The republicans were strongly behind
NAFTA, the version that passed was an edited version that Democrats were
convinced did enough to protect American jobs.

Your choice of words ("inherited") in the last sentence of this is
especially funny.  Some of the most questionable practices in federal
economics were established during the reagan/bush era, where defense
contracts went unchecked and often without adequate oversight... resulting
in the infamously expensive toilets seats and other overpriced materials
at taxpayer expense, as well as whole departments in the areas of
national security and intelligence that have almost zero accountabiity
and cost hundreds of millions.  Of course, for each of those there's a HUD
or similar democratic party darling, but I still thought it a funny word
choice.

-&e->Only a dem can spend money that fast: aka, see Red Davis' spending spree in
-&e->the first 7 months of re-election. I feel nauseous from your lack of
-&e->backbone.

This statement is a tad emotional don't you think?  Can we talk about the
world we live in without you threatening to barf or accusing those with
dissenting opinions of being invertebrates?

Looking at budgets, both major parties are horribly irresponsible with
money. At the national level, the budget shortfall winners are Reagan and
Bush Jr.  Greed, stupidity, and corruption are hardly something that
should be discussed along party lines... for each "blo job" or "bleeding
heart liberalism" I could spout a "watergate" or "iran contra" or
"senseless invasion of sovreign nation without internationally accepted
provocation" but the whole discussion sucks when it ends in inflammatory
slogans best left to inbred radio show hosts that cater to the quick to
judge and slow to understand.

I'd like to politely request that all the armchair politicians acknowledge
that this type of hardline crap would lock up the political process
altogether... politics is about compromise and finding middle ground (and
taking bribes and doing big lines of coke off hookers at the no-tell
hotel).  It's not too fun to see on a rave list, especially without an
"NRR" in the subject line.

If you're going to discuss politics, let's talk about what we could do
better without it descending into sandbox namecalling.  Suffice to say,
both parties have made major moves against many of the freedoms I was
raised to appreciate only a few decades ago.  Both parties are wickedly
self serving, and often work at 180 degrees to what they publically state
(for example, both major parties accuse the other of being "in bed" with
corporations at the expense of the people... when what we really need is
MAJOR lobbying, campaign and government employee compensation reform).

andyw


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR - Re: [sfraves] Question

"and two, the expense of bailouts that were a direct result of the
deregulation of utilities. the second a strong
libertarian/republican push to privatize the energy market during Wilson's
term.  Make no mistake, rolling blackouts,
a couple hundred bucks of your money in extra bills, the enron debacle and
the lobbying that allowed this
all all very linked."

---You are wrong on a few points *just* on the above.  The utilities were
*not* deregulated, that's the problem.
They were half-way deregulated, and anyone with a brain and knowledge of
economics would tell you that you
either regulate, or don't.  Period.  This is how we got into the energy
mess.  Yet you go further and make a second
error and suggest it was Wilson's fault alone for deregulation; deregulation
never happened, hello.  The democratic
controlled assembly forced Wilson to compromise with them and as I said do a
half-way deregulation, that's what
screwed us.

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <npm@mail.netwiz.net>
Reply-To: npm@netwiz.net
Organization: 5214-F Diamond Heights Blvd #635, San Francisco, CA 94131
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-US; rv:1.2.1) Gecko/20030225

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] seb fontaine at sno drift last night

Seb Fontaine played an amazing set last night at Sno Drift. Totally unlike
what I expected to hear him play. The vibe was, well, usual for Sno Drift. 
Nothing worth writing about. Fortunately, every once in a while they get a DJ
that really knows how to work it. Last night, IMHO, was such a night.

I expected trancier pop mainstreamy stuff with some good crowd-working
going on, inna UK style. But instead he played some pretty heady, groovy,
dubby tribal stuff that was still hard as nails. It was cool. You could
bug-out to it. It was less dark than, say, a Danny Tenaglia set, but kinda in
the same vein of being deeply embedded in a humid, sexy jungle of beats, with
occasional wafts of cool dub-fog to help  that last little bead of sweat on 
your forehead to not eruct all over the dancefloor.

Anybody got the proper term for the style he was playing last night? Was
it just "i'm going to play a bunch of underground shit for all the heads
in SF?"

Anybody got a DAT or some MP3s online of his set??


this is re:
|Please join us for a very special event with DJ SEB FONTAINE (Perfecto, 
|Thrive, Radio 1 / London, UK), one of the best DJs in the world, at Sno-Drift 
|tonight, July 30th. Seb Fontaine is touring in support of his new Perfecto CD 
|available now on Thrive Records and will perform an exclusive 3 hour set in 
|celebration of Mason from Thump Radio's birthday!

--

Subject: [sfraves] video artist needed

Greetings all, I am looking for a video artist for an
upcoming party to do single-screen projections.  This
is a paying gig.  You don't need to supply the
projector or screen.  Any interested parties please
send me an email off-list with 1. a brief description
on your work, 2. a list of recent gigs/references if
any and 3. a quote for your services for the night. 
The length of the set is flexible, 6 hours at the
absolute most.  Demo reels or references to online
samples would be great and we can take it from there. 
I'm mostly interested in material with a dark, gritty,
abstract, techy feel but I'm open to anything.

thanks, Dave

=====
Dave Marwick | DJ M
Tenderloft / Faultline / Freebeats
San Francisco

MIME-Version: 1.0

Subject: [sfraves] Dancers Break Record in 51 Hour Marathon....

--0-707173502-1059688805=:61328
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Dancers Break Record in 51-Hour Marathon 
46 minutes ago

By KRISTEN GELINEAU, Associated Press Writer 
CLEVELAND - Kool & the Gang's "Celebration" played early in the morning at the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, marking what 41 marathon dancers hope is a new record for the longest dance party. 

AP Photo 
 
It will be a few weeks before the Guinness Book of World Records confirms whether the record was broken, event spokesman Peter Collins said Thursday. 

"We wait for evidence to come in for it and if it fits — which I think it probably would — they'd be looking at getting the new record," Kate White, press officer for Guinness in London, said. 

"I'm relieved that it's over and exhilarated that we broke the record," said Dick Hurwitz, the oldest dancer to make it to the end. "I'm 58 years old and I'm not sore a bit." 

Hurwitz and others started dancing at 5:10 a.m. Tuesday and reached 51 hours — one hour past the 1999 record of 50 hours — at 8:10 a.m. Thursday. 

"It was rough this morning and people were hurting but everyone was determined," said Valerie Salstrom, co-owner of "Get Hep Swing," a swing dance instruction company based in Cleveland. 

Dancers were allowed to take 10-minute breaks every hour for food, trips to the bathroom and short naps. They also could stop moving between songs for up to 30 seconds, but otherwise had to at least be shifting their weight while on the dance floor. 

Guinness' current mark for longest dance party was set in November 1999 by 56 participants in an event sponsored by MTV India. 

Ben Rich, 26, got ready for the marathon with a little training. Rich, who lives in Washington, D.C., ran 4 miles one day and then stood for 12 straight hours — including during dinner at a Mediterranean restaurant. 

"The waitress was hysterical," Rich recalled with a laugh. 

The dancers originally had planned to dance for 81 hours, but they cleared the floor Thursday morning after 52 hours and three minutes, organizers said. The 81-hour goal was in recognition of the 81st anniversary of their sponsor, St. Joseph Aspirin's 81 milligram aspirin tablet. 

Salstrom and fellow instructor Marty Klempner helped recruit the dancers, who they know from their teaching trips around the United States and Canada. Unfortunately for Klempner, despite his training, painfully swollen knees forced him to bow out Tuesday night — the first casualty of the event. 

As the clock on the deejay platform hit 30 hours, the crowd cheered. 

"Seattle is in the house!" cried a bleary-eyed but grinning Jen Holland, known in the Seattle swing community as "Hep Jen." 

Most dancers brought several pairs of shoes to change when one pair got too sweaty or hot. Weary dancers soaked their feet, grabbed snacks and rested on air mattresses when they took their breaks. Some played card games from the dance floor, spreading the cards on the deejay's platform and breaking away every so often to twirl around. Others read books and ate while swaying. 

Salstrom said she and Klempner had to catch a plane to Los Angeles after the contest. 

"We're going to a swing workshop weekend," Salstrom said. "We start dancing tonight." 
 


___ 
On the Net: 
Guinness World Records: http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/ 
Rock and Roll Hall of Fame: http://www.rockhall.com/

Do not worry about anything, but in everything by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving let your requests be made known to God. And the peace of God, which surpasses all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.    Philippians 4:4-7

Starting this Monday, August 4th, we are changing the way we do the open =
deck signups.=20

In the back room, we will continue to have "first come first served" =
open deck slots.=20

In the main room, however, signups will be for the following week. At =
10pm you can put your name on the list of djs who want to spin the =
following week and we will set the lineup. This allows for several =
things:=20

1) We can group the genres together, which is more pleasing for the =
audience than radically changing styles every 1/2 hour.

2) Starting the signups at 10pm gives you more time to get there, =
especially for those coming from places like San Francisco and Marin =
County.

3) You will have a whole week to tell your friends exactly what time you =
will be spinning, so that they can come and support you.

Monday, August 4th, 2003

9:00 Gavin=20

9:30 Summer K

10:00 Jacob B

10:30 Jagged Mettal O

11:00 Teks

*11:30 Dragn'fly *

12:30 Marcine

1:00 Phaedrus

1:30 Lewt

This week we start off with some trance and breaks, then have 3 Hard =
House and Techno djs before we get to Dragn'nfly. After her set (which =
you know will be SICK!) We finish the night with 3 jungle djs.

8:30p Open Deck sign ups, first come first served

10:00p Sign ups for next week in the main room

Bring needles and headphones

$2 STRONG Islands
FREE pool tables
Outdoor smoking patio
NO COVER CHARGE!!!
21+ up w/ ID, please

Masse's Nightclub
6180 Stoneridge Mall Drive=20
Pleasanton, CA=20
(650) 463-8181

www.happycandykid.com/estuary=20

Subject: [sfraves] rumor nrr

--0-700398546-1059696641=:89535
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

i heard a rumor recently that the president wants to ban all gay marriages. i don't know if that is true or not, but it got me thinking about how it is still the way of the world to place value on marriages of convenience, as opposed to marriages based on love. also, i think that if this rumor 
is true that it has more of a basis in protecting economic interests as they currently are in the world, rather than protecting the moral standing of men and women. if all gay marriages were to just suddenly be validated, for example, then there would be a great cost to the military. army buddies 
would stop dating privately, and would openly marry and cost the government big bucks they aren't prepared to spill out, especially given the current world climate. everyone in the states would want 
to divorce their current spouses and go to be with the ones they truly love, and taxes would surely increase in the months ensuing. so think about it. you could also be stuck in a figure head position with your figure head spouse, or you could just go on living and loving and getting great tax breaks and acknowledgement from people who really do care. :)

Subject: [sfraves] BSP- SAFE @ The Top- Straight from London!

It's going to be a big night @ Safe this week. Kode 9 is truly on the
forefront of the new breed of UK Garage- deep and funky beats coined
DubStep. I'm really looking forward to it!

check out a couple tracks here:

http://www.dubplate.net/tunes/babylon.asx
http://www.hyperdub.com/kolony/tempa/007a.asx

and a mix here:

http://www.hyperdub.com/speedometer/ukgarage/bass.asx

bsp below...

-Science

> 
> Raul Endymion in association with True Intent Sonic Enterprises
> presents a
> new party dedicated to exploring the innovative, bassbin-rumbling,
> ultra-funky sounds of 2-Step/UK Garage, Broken Beat & Future Jazz:
> 
> SAFE
> 
> Every Saturday night @ The Top!
> 
> THIS WEEK'S SPECIAL GUESTS:
> 
> KODE 9 (TEMPA, HYPERDUB, LONDON UK)
> (bio below)
> 
> MOONSTARR (PUBLIC TRANSIT, COMPOST, TORONTO CA)
> (bio below)
> 
> plus resident selector:
> SUBTEK (DUBLIMINAL, GET LOW, SAFE)
> 
> Arrive early for an intimate Happy Hour from 7pm to 10pm with your
> hosts:
> 
> DOM SOME (STEP, FORWARD-THOUGHT)
> DJ SEA (TRUE INTENT, FUTURE BREAKS FM)
> ENZYME (STEP)
> FICTION (PACIFIC STANDARD)
> 
> this Saturday, 8/2
> @ The Top, 424 Haight St
> 10pm-2am
> FREE BEFORE 10PM
> LADIES FREE BEFORE 11PM
> $5 cover
> 21+, ID ESSENTIAL
> 
> don't forget to listen to Future Breaks FM on KUSF 90.3 Saturday
> afternoons
> from 4-6pm to hear the freshest sounds from the breakbeat continuum,
> get
> connected with the local breaks community and win tickets to SF's
> most
> boundary-pushing clubs!
> 
> 
> **more info on Kode 9**
> 
> Kode9 has followed the freshest wave of the hyperdub virus into the
> 21st
> century, a mutating sound, as much influenced by Jamaican dub and
> dancehall,
> German dub techno/microhouse as London's jungle and drum'n'bass
> scenes. He
> is currently pushing a distinctly South London sound, playing a
> mixture of
> dancehall influenced bass heavy garage, variously known as dubstep,
> sublow,
> grime and garage rap. In 2000-2001, kode9 promoted the Hyperdub
> sessions at
> the Bug Bar in Brixton, South London, the first night in the capital
> to push
> the dubstep vibe, featuring guests like Horsepower's Benny ill.
> With appearances at the Notting hill Carnival and early dark garage
> nights
> such as Corrosion, kode9 is now a resident at the pace setting
> underground
> night Forward>>, alongside the likes of Zed Bias, Oris Jay, J 'Da'
> Flex,
> Hatcha and the Slaughter Mob etc. He is known for his deep, moody
> selection
> and prolonged twisted mixes. Kode9 hosts the Forward>> show weekly
> (Thursdays 7-9pm) on the London underground's most respected pirate
> radio
> station, Rinse FM 100.3.(Also home to shows by the likes of Dizzee
> Rascal &
> Wiley's Roll Deep Crew, Oris Jay & Mark One's Virus Syndicate,
> Plasticman,
> DJ Hatcha and Crazy D)
> With the Forward>> crew, kode9 has played several times at the True
> Playaz
> nights at London's Fabric and at Andy Weatherall's Haywire sessions.
> Kode9
> also hosted the Hyperdub Transmission sessions on award winning
> internet
> radio station www.groovetech.com from 2001 to 2003, welcoming guests
> such as
> El-B, Horsepower, Zed Bias and the SLT Mob. In the last couple of
> years,
> Kode9 has done much to take the South London sound to an
> international
> audience, DJing in Toronto (Canada), Nantes & Lille (France), Berlin
> (Germany), Oslo (Norway), Tel Aviv (Israel), Glasgow (Scotland).
> 
> Producer
> Kode9 has been producing, and working on video soundtracks since the
> mid-1990s although most of his productions remain unreleased. Those
> that
> have surfaced include the distorted drum'n'bass monster 'Katak'
> released on
> the label Katasonix in the late 1990s, 'Fat Larry's Skank'/'Tales of
> the
> Basside' co-produced with Benny ill from Horsepower and released on
> Tempa
> records in 2002, and 'Babylon', opening track on the highly acclaimed
> Dubstep Allstars Compilation in 2003, to be released on 12 on Tempa
> again
> later in 2003.
> 
> www.kode9.com
> www.hyperdub.com
> www.dubplate.net
> 
> **more info on Moonstarr**
> 
> Kevin Moon, aka Moonstarr, first started producing music and DJing at
> the
> age of 17. Now 25, he strives to push the boundaries of electronic
> music by
> defying any categories or genres. Citing influences such as
> Underground
> Resistance (Detroit Techno), DJ Premier (Hip Hop) and Banden Powell
> (Brazilian Bossa Nova), Moonstarr's sound keeps evolving and
> expanding.
> His first release, 1997's Hexed on Wha?naut Records, was well
> received by
> local DJs. The three Moonstarr tracks spanned drum n bass to broken
> beat and
> beyond. Following the release of the Hexed EP, Moonstarr saw a lull
> in the
> electronic music scene in Toronto. Seeing no outlet for his music and
> the
> music of his peers, he decided to found his own record label.
> On his way to his mundane day job, Moonstarr previewed friend's demo
> tapes
> while riding the subway. Moonstarr saw the potential and innovation
> behind
> these raw recordings and in 1998 he approached a circle of
> underground
> musicians and like-minded friends to form Public Transit Recordings
> (PTR).
> 
> The first PTR release, the compilation Code: 416, received heavy
> rotation on
> college radio stations across Ontario. Critics in magazines such as
> Now,
> Eye, Exclaim! and Peace Magazine praised the album and helped PTR
> make a
> name for itself. With the release of the vinyl-only EP Metropass in
> 1999 and
> the CD compilation The Blue Night Network in 2000, Public Transit
> Recordings
> and Moonstarr have established themselves in the field of electronic
> music.
> Moonstarr has also received support from the international music
> community,
> sharing one of two 12" singles with the UK's Cold Mission (aka Marc
> Mack of
> 4-Hero).
> After executive producing the LAL album in 2000, Moonstarr finally
> released
> his first EP Dupont last year. According to Moonstarr, Dupont "is a
> broken-down musical expression about the culture of the city I live
> in".
> Dupont is currently available on a double 12", and has received
> support from
> DJs around the world. Rainer Trüby charted the record in Straight no
> Chaser
> magazine and Gilles Peterson placed it on his list of the Top 50
> albums of
> 2001. German label Compost included Moonstarr's track "Dust" on the
> latest
> edition of its prestigious Future Sound of Jazz compilation. He also
> worked
> with Movement's John Kong to produce the bossa-fied "Future Visions"
> on
> Fluid Ounce Records.
> 
> With the great strides Moonstarr's has made in 2001, the year 2002
> looks to
> be a banner year for Moonstarr. Moonstarr's acclaimed Dupont will
> become
> available on CD for the first time. On this 12" Compost Records
> releases new
> remixes of the "Dupont EP". Besides a fantastic new Moonstarr remix
> of the
> track "Greed", this 12" also contains a superb remix by Nu Era, which
> is
> Marc from 4 Hero under his 'Detroit-ish' pseudonym. Expect more
> Moonstarr
> releases on Compost in the future!
> 
> 
> http://www.ptrmusic.com/artists_moonstarr.html
> sound samples:
> www.compost-records.com/sections/media/sounds/293.mp3
> www.compost-records.com/sections/media/sounds/294.mp3
> www.compost-records.com/sections/media/sounds/418.mp3
>

opps... conintued

the UN must simultaneously hold trust and respect between dozens of nations 
at a time. It might just be the greatest task ever given to an organization in 
world history, and yet just because it seems impossible does that mean we 
should all just ignore the UN from now on? pretend it doesn't exist? Should one 
Nation rise above all others and police the rest of the world with it's own 
values? If the UN has failers in it's missions that means it needs more support. 
If we take the iniciative away from it then we're making it's job harder to do. 
We're taking their respect away. It's basically like saying Thanks to America 
the world is now saved! All you other weenie countries can kiss my ass! You 
will all do as we tell you to and always asume America has the perfect moral 
values! America is a big giant hero country and all you other countries are just 
rubbish, especially France. World peace, or die motha fuckas! muahahahhahaha

Subject: [sfraves] SPAZ wins Best of Bay Area: Best Crusty Electronic Music Freaks

--=====================_7452343==.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

San Francisco Bay Guardian 2003 Best of the Bay Area awards.
http://www.bestofthebay.com/2003/e_ent.html


Best Crusty Electronic Music Freaks


We can trace our conversion to rabid electronic-music fandom
to an afternoon in Golden Gate Park when we heard a thumpy-bump
noise coming from the direction of the Academy of Sciences.  A
little investigation revealed a crusty DJ crew set up in the
Music Concourse, surrounded by throngs of boogeying kids.  That
was SPAZ (stands for Semi-Permanent Autonomous Zone), the BPM
pioneers of the dreadlocked nation of travelers, tourheads,
and Rainbow Family devotees.  Over the years we always
encountered SPAZ DJs wherever the sounds were freshest . hard
breaks in a basement club, hippie grooves in an abandoned China
Basin warehouse, glitchy home-brew electro at a SomArts art
opening.  But SPAZ are more than a sound system.  The Spazheads'
warehouse, one of a transbay string of such for-real live-work
spaces, regularly hosts multimedia arts events as well as
brunches, DIY workshops, and political teach-ins.  Dedicated to
personal freedom, personal responsibility, noncommercial art,
barter economies, and grassroots democracy, SPAZ are coming
soon to a semiautonomous permanent zone near you.



Moksha Tribe:  http://mokshatribe.net/jagan/


House Music 101:  http://livingart.com/raving/articles/housemusic101.htm

"Security is mostly a superstition.  It does not exist in nature, nor do 
the children of humans as a whole experience it.  Avoiding danger is no 
safer in the long run than outright exposure.  Life is either a daring 
adventure or nothing."
-Helen Keller

"Compassion is not a relationship between the healer and the wounded.  It's 
a relationship between equals.  Only when we know our own darkness well can 
we be present with the darkness of others.  Compassion becomes real when we 
recognize our shared humanity."
-Pema Chodron

"It's taken me all my life to learn what not to play."
-Dizzy Gillespie

U  
--=====================_7452343==.ALT--

Greeting's

Allow me to introduce myself, my name is Tim aka djCITRIK from Tempe, Az. I 
will be performing at my first Cali gig this Saturday Aug 2nd at a event 
called "Rendezvous"(bay area) 12-1 second stage. For promotional purposes I 
will be giving out Free Cd's at this show. If you like to recieve one, 
please email me your name at audioistik@hotmail.com and will have one on 
reserve for you. Will only be taking a limited # on reserve. The rest I will 
be handing and throwing out at the event.

77 Minute Journey of Hardhouse, Hardtrance & Melodic

--- FLYER ATTACHED ---

yo!  as we all know, Burningman is fast approaching, and we can't wait to 
get there.  so, in the meantime, come take a seat around the Peace Melon 
circle, share your thoughts, and dance yo' a$$e$ off to the sound of some 
AWESOME DJs in an effort to support the crew who will be serving you BEATS 
and ICE COLD VODKA soaked watermelon on the playa........the PEACE MELON 
camp.  details are as follows:

The Date: Saturday, August 16th.
The Place: Cafe Cocomo
The Time: Noon - 7 p.m.
Entry Fee: $7
Line-up (could, but probably won't, change a little bit):
+ Gabriel Alexander
+ KENichi
+ Scott Carrelli
+ FauxQ
+ Headliner (one of these three people: Jerry Bonham, MissE, Samira)
+ A Possible inclusion of Tyler Reed


and as if all that wasn't enough, rest assured that the people kickin' it 
at the party will all be TOTALLY awesome, and ready to have a rawkin' time 
dancing all day long!  i hope to see you there!

.  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .  .

The war on terror is not that simple.
It's about American foreign policy, 
and both Republicans and Democrats share the blame.

The terror attacks Bill Clinton expirenced as president was directed
toward the United States regardless who was president at the time.
When the buildings fell in Africa, the terrorists didn't give a hoot who
was President.
All they wanted to do was hit America.
Mr.Clinton just happen to be the one who was President at that time.
And they still would have done it, 
no matter who was president.
maybe even with more determination if Bush was President.

Who was President when 9/11 happened?
Did that stop them?
And now were being told they're after us again.
So much for the shock and awe effect of American might!

The only difference was Bill was smart enough not to be so trigger happy
as Bush is.
Even half senile Ronald Reagan was smart enough to realize the Middle
East was a quadmire, 
and had enough sense to get the hell out of Lebanon when Marines were
killed there back in '84.
You see, it doesn't matter how smart your weapons are,

Bush hasn't learned the Vietnam lesson yet.
One reason because his daddy fixed it so he wouldn't go.
If he did go, maybe he wouldn't act so much like a cowboy.

Middle East, who can kick some serious American ass.

some of these terrorists.
These locos arn't afraid of us.

and you know, they will.

and we will have to suffer because of it,

Clint Eastwood movies are not a good foundation for foreign policy.

It starts with a "B" , not a "C"

office and became belligerent and started to act bad ass toward the North
Koreans.

corner.
Can you understand why North Korea, maybe Iran too, wants to build, or
already has, nuclear weapons?
It's called self survival.

And if we dare attack North Korea,
Seoul will be destroyed,
Tokyo will be wiped out,
and Possibly San Francisco will be in ashes.
Oh, we'll nucke North Korea all right,

falling all over the world?
 
Not a very bright foreign policy to me!



   "The only way to stop these issues is to  carry a big stick and not be
afraid to whack people with it."

Bush has, what I call a "corner the racoon and strike it" policy.
Anyone who deals with wild animals has enough sense to know not corner an
animal if your going to catch it.
A cornered animal will fight back.
You might kill it, but it will leave you pretty fucked up in the process.

The meaning of this is, if you hit people,
someone will hit you back.
America is not imune to the laws of karma.
Don't like that word?
Sounds too metaphysical/hippyish/new age to you?
Let's try another word, 
It's also called, "what goes around, comes around."

All we are doing is not addressing the real problem of terrorism.
We're just exaberating it more by acting like a street thug.
Fine for our American ego,
but sooner or latter, someone will find our Achilles's heel and bring us
down.
And like the saying goes about the giant in "Johnney And The Bean Stock"
story,
"the bigger they are, the harder they will fall."
America is the world's Golliath,
and someone will eventualy find a rock big enough to take us down.

If you want to live the thug life,
you need to realize that someone, someday will eventualy out thug you.
That's the law of the jungle.
So goes the thug life!

You assume wrong fucknut.  I have no problems with gays, gay marriages,
or gays in the military.  Would you like to see the pics I took at pride
in SF in castro?    

I don't particularly care why they "hate us".  The ones that do are
idiots like you.  The rest of them like us and I get along great with
them.

I'm not going to bother to respond to the rest of your stuff because you
assume too much about me.  

For the record:
I am a centrist.  I vote for who is best.  I believe in smaller
government and states rights.  The ONLY thing the federal government
should specialize in is international intelligence and a federal army.
The rest should be left up to the state. Bottom line.. I believe in
issues, issues, issues.. not political parties.   

I belong to at centrist organization and our motto is:
http://www.centristcoalition.com/index.php?module=ContentExpress&func=di
splay&ceid=4&mid=-1

The Centrist Coalition is a gathering place for moderate Americans who
have a certain distinct vision of political leadership in our country.

We believe strong leadership involves a bold mix of views drawn partly
from the right and partly the left.

On the one hand, we embrace an economic agenda focused on growth and
fiscal responsibility. We believe in free trade, fair competition, and
limited government.

On the other hand, we embrace an inclusive social agenda that celebrates
the rich diversity of American life, and seeks to avoid imposing one
person's choices on another. We are pro-choice and pro-civil rights.

We endorse candidates with a bold mix of views consistent with this
vision of a prosperous and inclusive America.
